Opaque, light brown head, good lace. Chocolate, roasted, sweetish, very bitter. Dry mouth feel. Flavourful and powerful.
Let me make this simple- hands down the best black IPA Ive ever had. Hard to imagine one every topping this.

Draft. Pours nearly black with creme head that lingers. Strong hop aroma with little carbonation. Nice coffee flavors up front with hop bite on the back. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Purchased this one in a liquor mart on the Sunset Blvd. in L.A. Pours a dark brown colour with a frothy beige head, extreme retention and creamy-soapy lacing. Smells like an IPA with the pine aromas, grapefruit and warm alcohol grass of an Imperial one. Not much roasted malts felt (just seen so far). Wet mouthfeel with not much dryness from the hops and medium-bodied. Hard to even taste the roasted dark malt or any malts. Feels just like a strong American IPA.

Bottle @ home, from Whole Foods San Francisco.
Dark, deep brown pour, with beige finely bubbled head, which lingers.
Mainly mocha in the nose, some pine.
Rich taste; coffee, hazelnut, heavy bitter hop finish. 
Love the style, love this beer.
Taste is amazing close to perfect. Pour is pitch black and a nice brown head. Delicious beer and beautiful appearance.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2014 Poured from a 12oz bottle. Some roast in the aroma, but I caught more citrus and piney notes than anything. The taste is great. Roasty and coffee notes hit first followed by the citrus hops. Just enough malt to balance out the bitterness from the roast and the hops. The alcohol is well hidden. Very nice beer.

This is a great example of a black IPA. It has tons of fresh hop aroma. I would guess centennial, Amarillo. It starts will a slight sweetness followed by a firm bitterness. The finish is slight sweet and smoother mouth feel than you would typically get in an IPA. There is light to no roast, but a very different flavor than an IPA. Overall, it is a great beer.

Bomber poured into a plastic cup. Appearance is nearly opaque black topped with tan head that has legs but wont stick to this cup. Aroma consists of citrus hops, pine resin, and roasted malt. Flavors are early citrus peel bitterness, roasty/cocoa malt sweetness in the middle, and a bitter lingering finish. Medium bodied, medium carbonation, crisp yet creamy, slight boozy aftertaste.

12 oz bottle for 4 bucks. Pours black with an amber hue and a huge tan head. Aroma is mostly a strong floral hop with some fruit, vanilla and caramel malt underneath. Taste is pretty much exclusively hop flavors; pine and floral. Not much finish on this one to speak of either. Body is average, average carbonation. Im not really tasting any of the malt flavors in this one. It kinda just tastes like an IPA to me. Not bad by any stretch but it hasnt blown me away either.
Good lacing and aroma. A little boring in the taste, but a good ipa. good, but not great.
On tap at Alewife Baltimore. Pours deep amber almost brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is spice and fairly fruity. Flavor is cocoa and is somewhat bitter. Finishes very dry.
Great dark flavor. Not overly carbonated. Slight bitter after taste but not offensive. Fairly smooth

TAP at Chez Moeder Lambic during "Moeder Lambic Vs. Stone".
Only found back scores, not ratings.

Bottle at the Black IPA tasting in Beer&Beyond shop. Pours dark brown-black with a medium tan head. Roasted malts and fruity aroma. Taste - sweet, roasted flavors, chocolate, coffee, caramel, tropical fruits, hints of alcohol, dry bitter finish, rich and complex flavors. Medium-full bodied, smooth on palate. Very good.

The Sublimely Self-Righteous Ale earns its title. The brew pours black with a tan head that lasts a bit and leaves good lacing. The aroma is floral, licorice and caramel. The flavor hints at the high alcohol content, but just enough to leave you wanting more. The flavor features a toasty caramel up front with floral and spruce hops that shine through and well into the aftertaste. Overall this is a very nice beer.
Had it on tap. Pours black with a tan head. Nose is subtle. Pretty unusual hop/malt mix. Overall, pretty interesting.

Draft at brewery. Pours black with a khaki head. Leaves a fair amount of lacing. Lots of pine on the nose. Theres a fair amount of pine on the tongue but unlike a lot of beers of this style you still get the roasted, chocolate malt element especially as it lingers on the finish. Very nice!

Superb. Strong malt and hop mix aroma. Great dark color with bubbles and good head. Full malty feel that fills the mouth. Solid carbonation that added crispness to the hop experience. Roasted malt flavor with toastiness followed by piney bitterness. Seems to have a perfect balance. Top of the class for the style.

Poured from bottle into pint glass. Aroma is floral, hoppy. Taste is sweet up front with a citrusy floral finish that is a great balance between bitter hops and malt. Great beer, definitely would try again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours pitch black with a beautiful tan head that does not go away. Smells of roastiness and coffee with some fruit peaking through. Tastes roasty, coffee, chocolate, up front and then the hops jump in and kill it. Its almost like youre drinking a porter and then its just like "WAIT NOPE IM AN IPA LOL!" Fantastic beer.

22 oz bottle. Dark pour with frothy head. Bitter and hoppy dark ale. Very good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2013 12 oz. bottle. Black pour with a thin but stubborn khaki head, good lacing. Aroma is off the charts. Big piney hops with citrus, pineapple, mango, earthy dark roast with caramel, coffee. Taste is unique, burnt sugar, coffee plus a hop wallop and bitterness. The sweetness of the pineapple and caramel and bitterness of the coffee and hops play off each other very well. As it warms I am getting a chocolate note as well. Very hop forward but the subtle notes that make up the malt are not lost. Mouthfeel is medium, slightly viscous, smooth carbonation. Black IPAs are tricky and Stone pulls this one off almost flawlessly. Definitely the best and most balanced black IPA Ive had. ABV is sneaky like an imperial even though its not categorized as such. Hats off to Stone, great brew. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

650mL bottle purchased from Learys earlier this evening for $7.75. To stemmed wine glass, it pours a syrupy purplish-black with a soapy gold metallic head three fingers slowly but surely dissipate to just one creamy fingernail, in length. Lacemarks are remarkable on this one. Think late Pollock splatter paintings and Rorschach inkblots. Aromas of cotton, fennel seed, grapefruit zest, celery salt, cocoa powder, pork salt, black peppercorns, raisins, truffles, tobacco, lavender, semi-dark chocolate, earl grey tea, booze, fried cabbage, hops, and soot. Tastes the same only with the addition of figs, charcoal, London yeast, pine needles, and juniper berries by swallow. I dont care much for Greg Koch, but I do care quite a lot for this beer. Solid.

FROM NOTES: July 22, 12
Poured from a 22 ounce bomber into stone glassware. 

A: A very bold hoppiness dominates, but the sweet malts are there in the nose as well.. Nice citrus smell (grapefruit). Chocolate presence and maybe some very faint coffee flavors. 
A: Pours almost black, just barely opaque, with a creamy, thick, tan three-fingered head that slowly dissipates, leaving a very substantial cap and sticky lacing. They dont look much better than this!
T: A beautiful blend of the roasty, chocolate porter-type flavors with the aggressively hopped IPA. Ive tasted a LOT of American Black Ales and while they all strive to reach this delicate balance, few do it as well as Sublimely Self-Righteous. Initially, there is a porter-like taste, but the hoppier citrus flavors blend in and dominate the finish. The roast and chocolate flavors show up sublimely in the aftertaste. 
P: Medium leaning towards the thicker side with a bit creaminess with the hoppy aftertaste. Great carbonation with subtle warming notes of the alcohol. 
O: I am in love with this beer, it is the best Black I have had to date. I am so moved by it that I am on the verge of becoming a full-on fanboi of Stone!

Pours boot black with a very thick fluffy light tan head. Some lacing. Aroma is pine, citrus, biscuity - intriguing and quite nice. Taste is roasted coffee malt and grapefruit hop bitterness. Strong, but reasonably good balance for a beer that tries to do this much. Then again, sometimes doin one thing really, really well (Ruination) is a better bet. A noble effort though. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Fresh, I dont care for this beer one bit. Too hoppy and the malt hasnt really developed much. Too smoky and roasty too. However, I sat on a bottle for like 6 months, and gave it another try, and holy crap its amazing! It balances out so much better. The hoppiness dies down considerably, the smokiness too. The roasty maltiness tones down a ton too. Really smooths out and becomes extremely enjoyable.
Tap. Black with tan head. Nice subtle biscuity aroma. Crisp and clean, very well balanced. Right amount of bitterness. Very interesting. They got it just right-teous.

Black pour with tall beige head. Good retention and lace. Huge hop aroma. Pine. Citrus. Sweet citrus flavor up front. Orange peel. Zest. Evergreen copse on the follow through with a lingering dry, bitter finish. Huge flavor but wonderfully balanced. Medium bodied, soft carbonation. Terrific brew.

2013/10/27 - Pours an opaque, dark brown/mahogany colour with a medium, billowy, khaki head that leaves ample lacing. Aroma is citrus fruit hops, caramel and chocolate. Taste is coffee, caramel, cocoa and grapefruit. Mouthfeel is oily with medium, stinging carbonation and a bitter, drying finish. Great beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A: Dark Opaque Hue, Passes No Light, Off White Ring, Some Lacing

S: Dark Roasted Malts, Floral, Mild Chocolate, Mild Coffee

T: Dark Roasted Malts, Mild Chocolate, Mild Coffee

M: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Semi Drying, Mildly Bitter

Overall, I did a side by side with ST Iniquity and this one won by far.

Stone Sublimely Self-Righteous Ale has a very thick, foamy, beige head, a reddish-dark brown appearance, and pretty heavy lacing left on the glass. The aroma is of brown bread and citrus juice, and the flavor is of citrus (hop oil), bitterness, brown bread, brown bread crust, and sweetness. Mouthfeel is medium to heavy, and Stone Sublimely Self-Righteous Ale finishes semi-dry, somewhat thick, not so bitter, and delicious. Overall, this is one to have. RJT

12 fl oz bottle. Pours pitch black with a decent off white head and a nice grassy, chocolate, toasted aroma that mingles well. Big bitter hit in the flavour that isnt overbearing but fitting. Stone fruits and dark chocolate dominates the flavour with a hint of espresso coffee. Very nice beer.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2014 How: Bottle.
Where: SBWF 2013.
Appearance: Deep brown colour with a brown head.
Aroma: Malt, caramel, hops, fruit.
Body: Medium body and carbonation.
Flavour: Fruit, raisin, caramel, malt. Liquorice in the finish.

This ale has a nice floral aroma. It is very dark golden with a small head. The hop strength is full, yet it really doesnt overpower the caramelized malty taste. Overall, this is a strong tasting ale and is quite good.
Bottle, Wine Warehouse, CHO. Pours dark brown - almost black, with a large tan head. Frothy. Smells of chocolate milk. Tastes of heavy chocolate, dark fruit, and grapefruit. Nice hops.
Love it, love it, love it! Big, dark and rich, with a balanced body of dark chocolate, caramel, cascade hops, finishing with a long and delicious length. Spicy hops linger.

Tap at GABF 2013. Poured a clear dark brown with a frothy tan head. The aroma is orange citrus fruit with some grassy hoppy notes. The flavour is weak bitter with a dry malt spicy hop palate. The aroma was much better than the taste.

Pours a deep brown almost black color. Aroma is citrus, and pine with a good scent of the alcohol content. The taste of the alcohol content comes through initially, with a hoppy bitter aftertaste. A bit of moldy, wet taste on the palate after the swallow. A good beer for the style.

On tap, served in a pint glass. Pours dark black/brown with a small beige head. Nose is pine/citrus. Flavor is malt, cocoa, chocolate, with a bitter hoppy finish. Medium mouthfeel. Typically Im not a fan of black IPAs, but I thought this was quite good.

A - Poured a dark brown to black with a small tan head that lingers throughout.

S - Lots of roasted chocolate

T - Again chocolate comes through along with a nice bittering from the hops. Finishes with a strong bitter hop taste with a slight warm alcohol tinge.

M - Fairly light, but good carbonation. Not too heavy, but does have a good thickness to it.

D - Another great beer from Stone. Not an overally complex beer, but it goes down pretty smooth and if you like a chocolate profile youll like this one.
Pours black with creamy tan head. Smells of hops and malts. Tastes of hops, bitter, malts, and alcohol. Has medium carbonation and long bitter.

Bottle from City Beer, San Fransisco. Black pour, thick foamy tan to off-white head. Aroma of roasty malts, loads of fruity hops, floral and pine with caramel and chocolate. Flavor is creamy roasted, coffee, bitter floral hops, pine, spicy and smooth. Huge fresh hops, thick roasted body. Everything in a single beer, which makes it a bit messy, but its still great.

Almost black, medium to large frothy beige head, lasting with excellent lace. Solid aroma, hoppy, sweet, dank, caramel, kiss of chocolate. Flavor adds some additional pine character. Medium body. Solidly Hoppy. Blended roastiness. Balanced leading to a great finish. Mostly dry finish. A big, bold, great beer.
Sweet figs, hoppy, a little caramel. Taste very similar, a slightly bitter finish. Medium, creamy, balanced body.

660ml bottle @ home. Ordered from Ales By Mail. BBE 22.10.2013.
Superb Black IPA with very beautiful appearance. Stone knows how to make good beer...

Aromas of citrus and piney hops overwhelm the nose. It is hard to take a drink because it is hard to stop smelling it. Self-Righteous pours a dark dark brown when held up to the light, topped with a thick tan head that produces great lacing. Taste is wonderful, malty with a hint of cocoa but balanced well with a splendour of hops. Alcohol makes a slight appearance. Malt and hops compete for your palate with malt winning the first round but hops and its bitterness taking the final round. Overall this is one of the best, if not the best, black IPAs Ive had. From the aroma to the chic blackness to the sublime hoppiness, this beer has it all. A double must try.

Bomber into tulip. Stout like darkness and thick of white creamy head in the glass. Malty, cocoa nose. Full mouth, nearly like a hoppy, light porter. Not quite the ale I was expecting but I can see where the black ipa designation comes from.well balanced, more malt finish with a good bit of hops bit not overdone.dangerously easy drinking for 8.7%.
May 2010. 22 oz. bottle. pours almost black with a tan head. Aromas of dark roasted malt, citrus, pine and floral notes. Great mouth feel, near perfect balance and a hoppy finish.
Pours a dark beer-bottle brown color with a foamy thick beige head. Smell is very malt forward, with a hop afterscent. Taste is of roasted malt, strong and delicious. Not boozy at all. Fantastic beer

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2014 Draft at Khyber Pass (Sept 2012) Poured pitch black, though showed as a clear ruby red under bright light. Frothy off-white head. Black liquorice. Cold coffee. Blackberry. Currant. Dark grapes. Well blended dark purple goodness. Medium thick. UPDATE: Having again in the bottle in December 2014 at Good Dog. Opaque pour. Similar to before but feels stronger and more forceful than I remember. Not a shy beer, but has a great peppery roughness in the finish. Nothing to to be triffled with!

(bottle) pours a slightly hazy dark ruby-brown colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of herbal hops, milk chocolate, cappuccino, brown sugar, caramel and nettles. flavour is mostly the same, slightly empty and burnt, with notes of roasted malts, some alcohol and gooseberries in the medium roasted-bitter finish. slightly thin-bodied with average carbonation.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2014 12oz bottles, bought at Mondial de la bière, Mulhouse. Gorgeous dark red pour with stable mocha head. Exotic floral aroma promises an IPA suave as a cocktail of dark wild berries and elegant dark malts. Taste experience is as merciless as Stones sense of self-satisfaction, a power source probably strong enough to supply their brewery with everlasting smug energy: interlocking degrees of charred malt, liquorice bitter and class A hop pine and unripe citrus rind bitter, with some blackberry thrown in for good measure; counterbalance of slight malt sweetness and more subtle floral notes as it warms up; no trace of ABV whatsoever, hence masterfully executed like a clinical attack of the palate; lingering astringent aftertaste. A lasting relationship with this beer would thrive on the inherent sadomasochism of its recipe: Lots to admire, bitter hard to love, dangerous to find yourself craving. // Rerate aged bottle 06/2014: drinks alot like a lean, leafy, sharp ImpStout, having lost most hop exotics and with more roast malt characteristics coming to the fore.

Pours black from a 22 ounce bottle. Believe this is my first try at black IPA and can't say I'm a fan. Good aroma but just to much bitters for my taste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Good example of the style, but I think the bitterness is a bit harsh. I know a lot of people like the bite, but I prefer a smoother bitterness.
A big sexy black IPA. Deep dark color with a reddish hue. Hoppy aroma and a hop-forward flavor with a roasty-sweet backbone.
Smells great 22 oz bottle. Frickin souring on palate. Decent roast. Great use of hops. Meh on mouthfeel. May be bad bottle.
Spicy with a wee hint of floral on the nose. This is huge on the tongue with a spice kick with Christmas cake to the fore, also Dutch licorice, what a wonderful beer

This is a nice beer. I am a big fan of black IPA and this did not dissapoint. Nice subtle floral aroma, appearance is solid dark with good head. Good smooth taste. Stone is quickly becoming one of my favorite

Tan head, piney, resinous aroma with hints if roasted malt. Loads of hop flavor nicely undergirded by the black roasted malt. One of the better black IPA I've had. Very tasty goes great with pizza.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A high alcohol content Black, Double, Imperial India Pale Ale. Very dark, and very tasty. Worth the bottle price.

Appearance: Black with pearl colored lacing
Smell: Smell rye spices with a floral undertaking
Taste: A well balanced imperial ipa with the rye malt balancing out the west coast happiness
Mouthfeel: The spices of the rye give way to a slight bitterness in smooth imperial black ipa.
Overall: This is a great example of a double black ipa. Let it sit for a minute to allow the rye malt to come out in the beer.

Pours a beautiful black walnut color with just a bit of a lighter hue that comes through at the bottom and around the edges. The foam is the color of light brown sugar. Sits atop this dark body like a cloud and falls slowly to a cap and ring with a film on top. Laces well and constantly refreshes. 

Nose is out of this world. Its citrus. Grapefruit and pineapple. Some pine and a faint oniony quality. On the nose the malt is just nicely toasted with a good helping of brown sugar. It smells big and beautiful. 

Taste follows the nose to perfection. The malt is burnt and toasted, roasted goodness. Smooth and flowing underneath all that hop character. The pineapple is sweet, the grapefruit is tart. Theres some orange and some tangerine; pith and all to go with the pine. The onion quality is not bothersome on the nose nor in the drink. The malt is a little nutty and deeply sweet to hold up a very enormous bitter. The pine is sticky with resin and the bitter is dry. Floral hops are everywhere in this beer. 

Stone has really outdone itself if you ask me. This is one great beer that brings together dark malt with a bit of bitter of its own from the burnt and charred qualities and its signature hop bitter. This was fruity and tremendously sweet. That sweetness deepens on the nose and in the drink as it warms but it never surpasses the tart fruits or the piney resin. The brown sugar goes so well with the orange. Im in love. Sticky, sweet, full mouthfeel. I could drink this all day.
Its got a very powerful aroma of malt and hops. It is black with a chocolate brown head. There is a powerful floral taste with a combination of roasted malt, bread, and chocolate.

Just when I was thinking the other day that I havent had a real great beer in a while I stumbled upon this gem. Dark and complex. Had off tap at wob. Fantastic aroma. Creamy palate. Must try again soon!
Pitch black, thin khaki head. Earthy hoppy aroma of grapefruit and maybe licorice. Taste is same aroma with a bit of alcohol coming through at end. Very good black IPA.

quite excited to see this was on tap at berlinerbierfest 2013. dark brown with a purple tinge and a thin head; was served a bit too cold to get a lot of aroma out of but hints of swimming pool, pine, bandaids; some pleasant grapefruit bitterness clashed somewhat with a licorice flavour that tended precariously close to burnt rubber
Dark brown and faint hazy. Has an off-white head, lasting. Mixed aroma, roasted notes, malty and lot of herbal hops. Sweet starting flavor, more roasted notes and more hops, bitter finish. Fuld body.
Great tasting Ale. Just drank this with a great burgers. Good times!!! This is a around ale.

Medium brown head. Opaque black body goes dark brown at edges. Deep resiny citric aroma with earthy fruity notes. Sweet-dryish orangey earthy resiny taste with minty roasty notes. Fullish body. Soft, smooth mouthfeel with some heat. Dry roasty caramelly aftertaste with resiny minty pineapple notes. Traces of burnt chocoalte and lacquered wood, too. Lovely and complex. Highly drinkable, yet sharp and full of character and flavour. (0.65l bottle, from House of Trembling Madness, York.)

I may have to try this one again. At a Buffalo Tap in Savage MN serving this in a bottle in August 2013 on bottles with Enjoy By dates from December 2012. Despite that it has held up decently to the age.

Black IPAd are an interesting fusion of porter and IPA qualities. This brew is entirely too spicy and bitter for me. The hopping was not done as a complement here but serves to make this beer literally painful to swallow. Roasty notes with hop aroma and thick porter body. Jet black color with tan head.

660ml bottle from Beers Of Europe, pours almost pitch black with a fluffy tan head that stays. Smell is tons of mango and citrus aswell as plenty of malt. Taste is huge extremely complex, lots of roasted malt, liquorice, some coffee, off set with huge hop bitterness, plenty of grapefruit, citrus and mango. A very long and bitter finish, medium carbonation and medium-full bodied. Absolutely stunning beer, the best black IPA Ive had thus far and possible my favourite beer from possibly my favourite brewery.
ligth malty bread aroma,brown, off white foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish,
yes, im just now trying this. no, im not crazy. i dont like IPAs. that being said, this is very well done. its not for me, but i get the appeal, absolutely.

Aroma- Green pine and pungent. Almost like if a cat urinated on your christmas tree.. I dont mean this in a bad way i am just trying to express the power behind the smell.
Appearance- Deep deep red amber with lacy cream head. Good lacing.
Taste- Piney with potent hops and floral boquet. Very nice.
Palate- medium body with a smooth dryness.
Overall- Great "punch you in your taste buds" boldness. Like a mix between a porter and an ipa. Very unique and worth trying.

Draught @ Yard House, Long Beach, CA
Pours dark brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, citrus, grape, pine and hint of chocolate. Taste is medium sweet and medium bitter with a long warm, piney, citrus and grape finish. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

An interesting mix of IPA and stout. Fantastic color with a rich head. Tastes like a bitter IPA with a small hint of burnt coffee. As expected of Stone, it overpowers the palate, but not in a bad way. Overall a pretty tasty beer.
Pint at Tylers Apex. good aroma sweet roasty carmel. Pine. Grapefruit. Black color. Good head and lace. Bittersweet flavor. Thick body. Oily creamy mouthfeel. Bitter finish. Darn good.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Black beer with big luxuriant tan foam on top. Antigravity lacing that sticks to the top of a tulip glass. Big juicy IPA hop profile to the aroma, more floral than fruity or earthy. The roasted malts only really contributed to the aroma towards the end as it warmed up beyond serving temp. Well integrated black ale, the floral hop flavors go well with the stout malts. Bitter and charred aftertaste that lingers a bit too long. Thick mouthfeel with a bit of alcohol burn. Excellent beer!

35 cl bottle at Oliver Twist,Sweden. Black color, good foam. Roasted aromas, coffee, hops: high aroma intensity. Full body & high complexity . Solid bitterness
Very enjoyable

(From 22oz. Bomber to tulip glass) Pours a delightful cola color with a creamy khaki,light caramel head. A tinge of red in the brew. The aroma promises all the things to come. Clear earthy hops, with nice floral notes and a coffee and toasty malt backbone.There is a slight hint of the higher ABV at the end of the nosing. The first taste is delicious. The spot on grapefruit and floral hop flavors (hibiscus and lavender?) wash over the tongue. The coffee and bittersweet chocolate follow in nice balance. This is a substantial but approachable ale. The 8.7 ABV is hidden very well in the taste. The bitterness of the hops lingers pleasantly after the swallow and the underlying citrus is quite tasty. With all the flavors going on this is sublimely balanced. I think I would love this with like a beef stew or a roast beef with a horseradish sauce. On its own its a very good, big ale for a relaxing evening at home. Stone really brings it! This will please both hop lovers and dark ale/ porter lovers alike. It strides both worlds admirably.
This beer pours black in color with an off white head to it. The aroma is somewhat hoppy with hints of espresso & spices. Overall flavor was a good but not great for me.

Bottle.
Ar: hops, grapefruit, licorice, alcohol, roastiness, bread, distinct Stone yeast. 
Ap: black body, medium beige head, lacing. 
T: Very bitter, medium sweetness, salty, grapefruity, licorice, roastiness, ABV well integrated. 
P: medium body/full bodied, slick feel, soft carbonation, bitter and roasty finish.
T: great!
Flaska @ Akkurat. Mörk, brun vätska med högt gräddfärgat skum. Massiv gräsig, grapeig doft. Smaken är härlig med Stones lagoma balans mellan malt och beska. Mmm, mumma.

Draught at BBF13. Caramelly aroma, a little alcohol. Very dark brown colour, seems cloudy. Good caramelly flavour. Quite bitter and quite alcoholic, but well-balanced. Sweetish with a spicy hop note. Good.

Draft - Roast malts and grapefruit. A bit so spice, maybe anise? You can almost see through the dark mahogany, and a beige nice rich head. Big pine and toasted malts. Thin body and a bit of alcohol burn, not as I had hoped with the aroma. Not bad, but just ok.

Draught @ BBF13. Pours hazy very dark brown with light tan head. Clear aroma of malt, caramel, hops and fruit. Sweetish, malty flavour with regular hoppy notes and a touch of grass. Bitter finish. Good. Really good.

Good beer, or food, can evoke emotions. This beer is akin to an autumnal walk with the dog, through a damp, fusty pine forest. Whilst in the background someone is burning leaves on a bonfire. And some plastic, while theyre at it, as they cant be bothered taking it to the tip. Whilst eating a huge bag of liquorice sweets. (Me, not them). And I dont even like liquorice. Except in this beer. Which is really very good.
65 cl bottle @ home. Pours black with a tan head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is grapefruit, roasted malt, coffee, and pine. Flavour is much like the aroma  with a bitter finish.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2013 Bottle from Celebrations Carlisle. Pours a jet black with a tanned head that holds slightly. Lacing clings around the glass. Aromas up front of pine hops! Chocolate powder, roasted coffee and vanilla in there as well. This smells amazing. The taste is upfront a chewy pine hop bitterness backed by a strong dark chocolate presence. Roasted coffee malts, nuts and caramel come through as well. Bit of pepper comes about as it warms too. Dry chewy pine/chocolate bitterness clings to the palate. More dry black pepper coming through.  Just has me crawling back to the glass for more. I do believe this one lives up to the hype considering how far its traveled to get to Australia in this condition. Top shelf black ipa! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bomber bottle poured a deep dark brown hue w/ a medium creamy light brown long-lasting head and some sticky lacing. Big aromas of floral hop and roasted cereal. Initial flavor is a moderate sweet w/ a heavy bitter of long duration. Tastes are grapefruit, spruce, roast, rye, caramel, leather, nutty, and cereal. Medium to Full bodied, soft carbonation, creamy texture, and a light warmth in the finish.

Dense dark brown, nearly black pour, allowing no light to go through. Minimal wispy beige head. Huge aroma of spice, piney hops, roasted malts, bakers chocolate, espresso. Flavor is intense bitterness upfront with roasted and spiced malts in the middle, dark chocolate in the finish. Not for the faint of heart, but quite amazing.
This one is amazing very sweet with a nice hop overtone. Subtle roasted flavor sets this beer off.

Bottle thnx to Bytemesis. This pours a pitch black beer with a nice, semi big, tanned head. Aroma of coffee, caramel, piney hops and some roast. Flavour is spicy, bitter, hoppy and very rich on the palate. Very nice to sip and enjoy carefully. Great brew!

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2013 Cold bottle from Brewdog. BB Sep 2013. Black, small tan head. Up front there is resin, grapefruit, some coffee detectable. Finish is chocolatey. I dont have much to say about it because there isnt much complexity, but it is a nice black IPA. Good balance between sweetness and bitterness.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2014 24.07.2013, 0,65l bottle sampled @ BBGTC "best-before-last-summer-tasting" :
Big creamy longlasting head. Aroma is dark malts, hop pellets, wet leafs, pine needles, burnt caramel, almonds, butterscotch, rubber. Taste is slightly sweet hoppy, dark malts, hops, pine needles, rubber, grass, licorice, wet leafs, cellar. Longlasting mild bitterness, slightly dry mouthfeel. Nice.
Toffee, coffee, caramel and malty aroma. Rusty brown and thin in body. Delicious dessert

Pours black with no head from the bottle. Aroma of sweet roasty malt, pine hops and sweet candy. Flavor is smokey malt and some pine hop bitter. Lots of smoke for a non smoked beer. Medium mouthfeel with more than adequate carbonation. Solid beer, but Im not sure it belongs with the likes of Wookey.

Old bottle(bb01.11.12) pours a dark brown with a creamy liggt-tan head. Aroma is piney with hints of roast and liquorice. Hoppy. Taste is bitter and piney, resinous and mild roasty. If someone told me this was a black ipa, id believe em. Medium body and soft to medium carbonation.

Initially stark and bold, this Escondidian Black Ale warms to express smooth complexities and interesting juxtapositions, each serving inspiring a dream of fresh Stone 15th lining the shelfs of my frig as it once did

A black body displays thin copper highlights at the extreme edges beneath two inches of tightly structured light khaki head displaying several minutes of solid retention and a variety of widely spaced spots, dots, and short islands of lace
-
A fog of roast and dark chocolate is illuminated by sharp grapefruit and grass on a lightly creamy medium-light body producing a solid bitter residual, as the drink progresses and warms, the components merge while added complexities of anise, vanilla, and date introduce themselves, balancing the initial contention

12oz enjoy by 10/24/13 at 45º into Spiegelau Beer Classic Pilsner tulip (bottled around July 3rd)

Poured from bottle into a pint glass. Big aromas of roasted malt, coffee, bourbon and grapefruit. From the taste, you could easily be fooled into believing that this was a hopped-up porter, with coffee notes on the front and back end, and lots of hops in between and lingering through the very long and pleasant finish. This is a very good beer, and the one that all other Black IPAs should aspire to be.

Bottle on 062013, best before 080813. Pours dark brown with a small bubble dense tan head. Aroma is dominated by roasted malt and grapefruit, Taste is roasted dry bitter malt with some citrus hops present, light sweetness. Medium body and smooth carbonation. Finish has dry bitter chocolate with a hint of citrus and some hints of alcohol as well.

Aroma of chocolate, roast coffee, and a hint of nuttiness. Pours dark brown, almost opaque black, with a thick, foamy, tan head with long retention and fills the mouth with a creamy sensation. Tastes of bitter dark chocolate, earthy hops. Balanced toward bitter. Full body, slightly creamy, a little alcohol warming. Fantastic beer.

Black with light tan head. Aroma is pretty even of citrus/pine hops and roasted malt. Taste starts out with the hop flavors, giving way to the bitterness and roasted malt (only now having some mild chocolate and coffee notes). Thick body, low carbonation, creamy with a dry finish. Pretty good balance between an IPA and a porter

Pours an almost black color with a medium long lasting beige creamy head with good lacing. Aroma of citrus, orange peel, pine hops upfront with some good dark caramel chocolate malt. Taste is of dark chocolate malt, a bit of liquorices with a good amount of citrus hops. A medium to full oily body on the palate, slightly smooth with a sweet bitter sticky mouth feel. The finish is a combination of sweet dark caramel malt, chocolate some brown sugar, the ending is sweet bitter liquorices and citrus orange bitterness for balance. Caramel malt flavor shows through more as it warms up. Although a bit on the bitter side, it is an interesting combination of flavors, but still a very good and tasty brew, well done.

Simply one of the best beers in the known universe. Pours deep dark brown with tight tan head. Aroma of pine hops and roasted malt, charcoal and caramelised citrus. Tastes delivers and then some. Epic beer.
Bitter and dark as would be expected for a black ipa. Dont try to session this brew that smells like feline urine with an after taste like quinine.
muy buena,a la nariz malta tostada y algo de chocolate,al paladar mucho lupulo y regaliz con notas de naranja, una black ale como debe de ser,impresionante
user_location: SANTIAGO DE LOS CABALLEROS, DOMINICAN REPUBLIC

text: From 22oz bottle to shaker. Pours very dark copper, thick tan head. Smell is strangely hoppy for the darkness, also notes of coffee and malt. Taste is bitter, full complex body with light carbonation. First Stone brew Ive had, very impressive.
Black body, tan head. Aroma is rich with malts, some chocolate. Smooth mouthfeel, very light carbonation. Taste is also soft with slight bitterness. Overall its a very good beer.

Seems to be working for you Bish. Brilliant beer, a delight. When the sun comes out I want to be like Flea. A little man playing bass guitar. Someone said last night I looked like a man who was about to take a load of acid. Obviously I took that as a compliment.
Dark, hearty yet still hoppy enough to hold onto the typical IPA bellwether characteristics

Dark, dark brown colored pour with ruby highlights. Small tan head that lasts. Leaves a bit of lacing behind. Aroma is mostly hops. Some notes of orange. Creamy chocolate taste followed up with a nice citrus note of hops. Some hints of vanilla. Bitter in the back, but just a bit. Nice beer.

Bottle @ Max, 2 / 7 2013. Dark brown, small tan head that disappear fast, nice lacing. Aroma, roasted malts, chocolate, bit of hops, some alcohol and smoke. Taste, bitter, roasted malts, chocolate, hoppy. Leaves bitter dry aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours black, medium-thin tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, toffee, pine, leather, subtle overall. Taste mixed both mild sweet and mild bitter. Medium body, texture creamy, on the thicker side. Long, medium bitterness. Overall a good black IPA but not my favorite.
Mahogany clear appearance. Smells like piney hops and roasted malt. Thick creamy head. Flavors of roasted malt and chocolate with a hoppy aftertaste. Well balanced and smooth bitter finish.
Bottle. Pours opaque dark brown with thin toffee head. Aroma of intense hops. Taste of dark chocolate with a nice hoppy aftertaste.
Pours a black color with thin to medium off white head. Aromas of mild hoppy bitterness and flavors or well balanced hops and roasted malts. Leaves a slight stick texture on the palate.

pours a translucent black with an off white head. Aroma of juicy hops with some dark roast in the background. The roast is more prevalent in the taste, it is well ballanced with the citrus hops. Neither the roast or the hops are particularly bitter, this goes down very smoothly.

Wonderful sweet malt and hop aroma. Nice light brown head with sticky lacing. Very enjoyable, only wish the bitterness was a little less and not overpowering of the malt sweetness. Great beer in a great style.

Bottle (12 oz). Dark brown, almost black, with a huge creamy beige head and good lacing. Aroma is of roasted malt, resinous hops, fruity notes and dark chocolate. Taste is slightly to moderately sweet with roasted malt, resinous notes, citrus, dark chocolate, light earthy notes and moderate bitterness. Alcohol is well hidden. Medium body. Good carbonation. Moderately dry. Somewhat oily. Very good Black IPA. Probably one of the most successful IPA/Stout hybrid. Easily drinkable and refreshing!

22oz bottle. A: Pours black. Thick tan head with good retention and lacing. S: Hops, malt, dark chocolate, toffee, burnt caramel, espresso, leather. Complex but lacking intensity. T: Hops up front, malt, mocha, burnt caramel, leather. Lingering bitter to remind you its an ipa. M: Crisp on the tongue. Medium carbonation. Creamy finish. O: Fantasticly balanced black ipa. Highly recommended.
On tap at BBC. Pours nearly black reddish brown with thin tan head. Roast, earth, plums, alcohol. Moderately bitter and sweet. Full creamy body.

Exquisite poor! Opaque black with a big white head that slowly fades into awesome lacing retention. The aroma is lacking slightly as the hops are kind of mellow for such a powerful beer. This beer is big, bold, and beautiful! The taste is dominated by hops but in an exceptionally smooth way. The body is almost light and creamy with hops present throughout. Quite drinkable at nearly 9%. This is very, very good!
UPDATED: JUN 24, 2013 Very dark beer, Pours like a stout. At first it tastes like a stout with a chocolate coffee taste, then transitions to an IPA bitterness. Very drinkable and tasty.

Simple, smooth aroma with a basic appearance, spicy taste and growing spicy aftertaste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Creamy off-white good fully lasting head. Black colour. Heavy hoppy and moderate malty aroma. Heavy bitter flavor. Some chocolate notes. long heavy bitter fnish. Creamy palate.

I am yet to be disappointed with a Stone until now. I tried this one on a whim. It has a spicy aroma to it but not the usual scent im accustomed to. It has a bitterness to it that is too overwhelming. Its too simplistic. You drink it but then feel its burn. There is nothing more or less than that. In my opinion I say skip it and get a Hoptimum with a higher ABV.
[US West Coast Trip 2013] ännu en riktigt bra öl från Stone. Både aroma och smak var det klass på. Välhumlad, en viss sötma tittar fram. Kanske lite lakris. Välbalanserad. Klass klass klass !

The aroma is subtle and balanced. As a lover of true ipas the black ipas have yet to impress. But this one is so balanced its hard to not like it. Nice dirty hop stick but with a light chocolate malt mixed in. Nice beer stone. Still not a big fan of the style but definitely a clean good beer.
Fairly bitter with hints of smoke. Medium body. Solid, although not overly complex.

Appearance: opaque black, little foam from the draft, minimal lacing on the glass
Aroma: slight hoppy smell, not very aromatic 
Taste: hoppy and bitter, not very overwhelming flavor, not as chocolate or coffee taste as expected
Palette: bitter 
Overall: this is an excellent beer, different than what I expected but pleasantly surprised 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A black IPA that is still an IPA. It's far less contrived and ham handed than many other examples out there. It still has the grassy bite and subtle fruity hints of a west coast IPA, but the malt backbone is rich and bold. The dark flavors are ashy and woody. The mouthfeel is medium. Very little head and a light but respectable degree of lacing. All the while I got the feeling that this was truly to style rather than a DIPA/porter mash up. Confident, phenomenal, sexual beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at the Most Arrogant Bar Bash in SC with reg Koch.

Very dark mahogany  with a head that coats the glass and lingers. 
Smells quite hoppy, with more pine than citrus.  A precursor of the black IPAs running rampant these days, and better than almost all of these.

Not really fair to rate this with other Black IPAs, because like most Stone brews its nearly a double, @ 8.7% and 90 IBUs. A big nose of piney and perfumey hops with some roast malt in there. Awfully well balanced, a touch of sweetness plays with fragrant hops, and then the dark malt and hop bitters intertwine seamlessly. SuperYum.

From a bottle. Pours opaque dark brown with a foamy tan head. Bitter, hoppy, complex flavor. Tastes like toffee, coffee, licorice, cool and crisp. Smells like floral, pine, and grapefruit. Medium body and low carbonation.

Bottle into snifter glass.  Black with light tan head.  Aroma is pretty even of citrus/pine hops and roasted malt.  Taste starts out with the hop flavors, giving way to the bitterness and roasted malt (only now having some mild chocolate and coffee notes).  Thick body, low carbonation, creamy with a dry finish.  Pretty good balance between an IPA and a porter.  Nice.
Jet Black in appearance with a creamy white head. Hoppy on the nose with hints of roasted malts. Really good balance with the roasted malts and the standard IPA flavours. Geat beer!

This beer was on cask and served like a REAL ale should be served. Many black IPAs dont add enough black malt to make the beer anything else but a dark IPA. This beer has great roasted flavors that blend with the hops and truly create what I think a black IPA should be. Nicely done Stone.
This is a very good beer but its definitely over hyped. Like many of Stones beers.
Wonderful rich aroma, flavour and lingering bitterness. Dark black colour with nice head. Rich flavours, and long lasting mouthfeel. A great beer.

Bottle. Nice bitterness in the nose.  Deep brown black pour with a quick fading head.  The flavour is deeply roasted malts and bittering hops but with near perfect balance.  The roasting bitterness and hop bitterness almost fade together to form a nice middle ground.  This is a truly great ale.

Effluves houblonnées et torréfiées, plutôt épaisse et crémeuse, elle est bien corsée en bouche, laissant dabord la place à lamertume, puis aux notes chocolatées, ce qui semble contraire aux habitudes. Plus mince quil ny paraît en bouche, elle est très savoureuse et manifeste sa puissance pendant de longues secondes. Un exemple de ce que les Américains font de mieux.

Opaque dark brown pour. Thick tan head. Tons of lacing. Lots of grapefruit, citrus, and pine hop aromas. Mild coffee and chocolate roastiness. Thick mouthfeel. Super drinkable. Sweet flavor. Hop flavors are still there but not as dominant. A milky flavor to it. Maybe brewed with lactose. There is a roasty flavor but not the typical bitterness of the dark malts. Very impressive beer. ---Rated via iPhone

When I first smelled this I was instantly like "wow. This is good!". I normally don't buy darker beers and if I would have realized this was  a porter I probably wouldn't have bought it. If I didn't see the color I wouldn't have guessed it was a darker beer. Maybe I just am getting different taste buds. Anyways. Has mild chocolate or very slight toffy. It is on the bitter side of darker beers but very good balance. Loved this beer and a beer I would buy again. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Somewhat subtle malty aroma belies an intense hop character in the palate.  Amazing hop flavors eventually give way to bitterness and malt.  This is in many ways several beers rolled into one.
floral hops embeded over a caramel toasted malt. warming alcohol undertones. well balanced overall but arrogant bastard is better

22oz bomber. Pours a rich dark brown/black color with a half finger of fluffy tan head. Massive aroma of piney hops, roasted coffee, and dark chocolate. Taste is strong piney hops up front, followed by rich roasted coffee notes, and dark chocolate. I love this beer!!

Bottle sample at a tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks Yoav. Dark brown-black and opaque, a little wine, a little roast and coke aroma, Bitter, malty, very bitter and a little coffee taste. Full body, dry finish. Tasty.

This beer is absolutely amazing.  At first pour I had my doubts as it didnt have the best smell, but dont judge this beer on that alone.  What it lacks there it gains in its appearance and taste.  Overall amazing.  I may have my new favorite beer.
A cerveja é excelente, mas não na minha opinião não merece nota 100, degustada durante reunião da Confrabacon em Ribeirão Preto (SP), Brazil.
Alchy and hoppy aroma. Black  black  blackness color wise.tan head. Surprisingly balanced! Vanilla hint with malty nut after feel. I. Love. Stone. Fucking great beer!

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2013 Awesome. Pours black. Lots of aroma here: notes of toasty malts, faint chocolate, faint smoke, woody, and hoppy. Taste is sweet, malty, toasty, bitter pine, nutty, and faint caramel. Complex. It really develops and begs for another taste. Finish lingers just slightly but really nice. Its a mind bender... enjoy.

This is the GOAT! It's bold but subtle regarding Hoppiness and ABV%. It plays tricks on my mind because its a DIPA, but it looks like a stinking stout. I simply adore this beer. It's also the reason I love craftbeer, Stone Sublime was my first. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone so go have a DIPA!

Bomber pour to pint; with a meal- pork loin and sweet potatoes.  I have had this several times but did not rate it.  I always enjoyed it.  Very persistent foamy head; cola black color.  Roasted maltiness with a bit of smoke and sweetness. Very good.
Wow...ran into this little gem a few mins ago at locust tap!  Never seen b4 so had to get..holy smokes its delicious black ipa... hoppy bitter goodness..yay

Pours black with a medium tan head and some lacing. Aroma is a lot of pine and citrus notes with chocolate and coffee mixed in. Flavor is roasted malt, caramel, milk chocolate, coffee, grapefruit and citrus with piney hops. Medium body with medium carbonation and a nice bitter finish. Very good brew.

Aroma: Dark roasted malt, espresso and an odd mosquito-spray smell - my guess is the hops.
Appearance:Black with a small tan head.
Flavor: Roasted malt and caramel - moderately sweet.
Palate: Full bodied with soft carbonation and a silky texture.
Overall: Very impressed with how well balanced it is for the typically unbalanced style.

A - Pours completly opaque even when held up to the light. A dense 2 finger tan head presents excellent retention and random patterns of lacing.

S - Resinous pine surrounded by grapefruit zest and sweet tropical fruit. Perfume-like alcohol vapors, hits of roasted dark malts and cocoa.

T - Oily piney hop juice all the way to the middle then instantly turns to aggressive grapefruit pith, tropical fruits, and mint. All the while the roasted, almost burnt malt holds on and adds some smoky sweetness. Bitter fruit and slightly sweet with burnt chocolate on the finish. Aftertaste seems different with every drink but grapefruit seems to dominate.

M - Full bodied, very rich and creamy, moderate carbonation hops coat the mouth with bitterness.

A multitude of hop flavors with good black malts behind it. This is on the edge of being unbalanced on the hops side but the malt comes through just enough.

Serving type: bottle

03-24-2011

This is...well... Not quite heaven, but I suppose that sublime is apt.

This brew cuts a perfect balance between the roasted notes and hoppy bitterness that others have performed with less success.

Pours an opaque ebony with bright and decently persistent head.  Aroma of pine and hints of chocolate.

Taste is roasted barley and a faint chocolate with flower-forward west coast hop varieties.  Smooth and balanced on the mouth.  Yup.  New favorite (at least one of them)

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft. Woah. I am astonished at the high ratings here. I found this overall to be very derivative and unexciting. This has got to be the most overrated brew Ive tried in several years. Minimal head does not stay long. Deep blackish brown. Hops. Hops. Hops. Thats all I get. A faint twinge of roastiness. I dont get it.

12oz, $3.50 from Total Wine, BB 5/15/13. Pours inky black with a 1-finger light tan/off-white head. Aroma is typical Stone-stle hop punch: floral and pine dominate. Taste is boozy, roast malts, cocoa powder, and a big floral hop punch, although not as bitter as some. Nice cocoa/hop finish that lingers for a while. Mouthfeel is fairly light and silky for the style. A good food beer, but a bit too dry to stand on its own. Excellent, but truthfully, a little overpriced. Some equally good beers can be had for a few dollars less.

Bomber. Jet black with tan froth and loads of lacing. Aroma gives loads of pine and juicy citrus alongside some dark roast coffee and dark chocolate. Taste explodes with juicy fruity hope and pine resin, before dark chocolate and roasted malt take hold. Great balance. Some coffee in there too. Lots of citrus and blood orange - so juicy for a BIPA. Full mouthfeel. Touch of booze. Lingering roasted notes and pine resin bitterness. This is top notch.

Elle est brune très foncée, alors quune mince, mais dense, mousse flotte au-dessus de celle-ci. Le nez est de résine et de zeste dorange entremêlé de céréales grillées. Au goût, cest amer et ça devient graduellement agressif. Au travers cette intimidation, on détecte du café noir et du chocolat noir qui frayent au travers un caramel. Louis sest lâché lousse dans les offrandes (556-120113)

Decent biege head dark dark pour soft carbonation aromas strong fruity esters piney hops rich malt floral notes rich perfume like very hoppy goodness the flavours fruity tastes floral sweetness grapefruit peach lemon the piney hops sweet caramel sharp tasting right through medium bitter crisp a wonderful balance classic bipa the finish few superior of this style class alround hops malt bitter and sweetness simply first class on the taste buds wonderful ale

Great citrusy aroma with malty balance. Definite grapefruit notes. Loved it.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at Taps in Petaluma. Pours a dark black color with a bit of a head. Good strong bitterness and roast Ed malt flavors. A nice amount of sweetness to balance it. A great black IPA.

brown, smooth tan head. spruce, herbs, peppers, citrus, chocolate, toffee. very bitter, salty and savory. medium body. ill need to revisit this, its the second hoppy thing ive had tonight thats tasted strangely (and almost excessively) savory, salty, and peppery. maybe my tongue is off tonight, i liked it more when i had it half a year ago.

Pours a super dark mahogany/brown with a pale khaki head. Lots of floral hops on the aroma, some citrus (lemon, grapefruit) and other fruit, slight chocolate and coffee notes and roasted malt. Lots of malt up front, toasted malt, a bit of milk chocolate, lots of hops (mostly citrus) with a bit of a pine taste as well, some peach and mango, and hints of dark fruit. Medium bodied, very good balance between the huge hops and the tons of malt.

The color is a very dark brown (some light does shine through) with a large off-white head, and the aroma is VERY hoppy with citrus and resin notes shouting out the loudest. The taste is quite (read: overwhelmingly) bitter, slightly sweet, and a touch sour; also, the palate combines a long bitter finish, soft carbonation, medium body, and a sticky texture.

Appearance is jet black with a nice creamy tan foam cap.  Aroma is very nice pine and earthy hop notes, Taste is deep roasted chocolate, with plum and dark fruit. Malt is a bit sweeter than an imperial stout, but with similar deep roasted cocoa notes. Sweetness of the deep malt blends into smooth bitterness from the hops that becomes more intense on the swallow. Mouthfeel is medium to heavy, with a definitive creaminess as opposed to the dryness.  Bitterness from the roasted malt and hops lingers on the finish, with a warming from the alcohol. Overall, this is a great Black IPA

10oz glass on tap.  Walnut black color, translucent, tan persistent bubbly medium head, adhesive.  Strong hoppy aroma - smells fresh!  Stone descriptions are pretty wordy, but suffice it to say this beer thinks its better than you.  Its got huge taste where some black IPAs come up short.  Ill be trying my darndest to clone this soon.  This is wonderful off the tap if you can get it.

Pours a dark brown with a couple inches of thick, creamy head. Aroma of roasted grain and hops. Flavor is a balanced combo of toasty roasted grain and hop bitterness. I like it, but Ive tasted better.
Sell was citrus hops taste was of hops and roasty.  Color was very dark with a 2 finger head that held
First black ipa, great balance and hoppieness. Dark, it is black for sure. I would buy this again.

Pours nearly black, with a medium-size tan/off-white head. Gorgeous looking beer. Aroma of chocolates, grains, slight citrus. Very flavorful, lots of malt and chocolate notes upfront and a nice bitterness at the end. Some chocolate, raisin, and pine notes as well. Nice smokey aftertaste. Really good, another fine beer from Stone.
Nice hop aroma with malt.  Very hopppy on the tongue.  Not a bad flavor.  very hoppy black ipa.  Black IPAs usually are not hoppy this has obviously been over hopped.  Nice brew.
Closest to perfection as me. Lots of good flavor and aroma. The aftertaste is good and there is still a long time.

Bottle. Served in Duvel glass. Pretty old bottle, I should mention that. Two weeks after "enjoy by date". 
Dark as night. It has a big, slightly brown, tanned, almost creamy-looking head but disappears pretty quickly. The head leaves some nice lacing on the side of the glass. 
Aroma is actually sweeter than I would expect: Toasted/roasted notes: sweet, milk chocolate, breadiness, earthy. Not that big a hop profile as I expected but there is some.
Mouthfeel is between medium and full-bodied - very nice. 
The taste follows the nose fairly well, but here, the hops are clearer though, which is nice but its not a hop monster. Roasted malts, coffee, dark and sweet chocolate, and a slight touch of the alcohol and earthy notes. In the aftertaste you get a nice bitterness that I suppose is from the hops. It tastes pretty good! Would love to try this fresher.

12 oz. bottle. Black, with a small, tan head. The aroma is tangerines, bitter chocolate, and resin. Very bitter flavor, sweet, and a little spicy. The body is medium, sticky, and grainy. Overall, this is a hoppy, roasted beer. Good, but not great.

Stone Sublimely Self Righteous Ale should be more accurately named Extremely Facetious.  Faint aroma of maltiness even when properly served in a tulip glass.  Nice dark color and a quality head.  Unfortunately, the taste was of extreme bitterness and not much else.  Every so often there is a hint of hop character, but it is washed away by bitterness. No roasty notes like one might expect from a dark IPA.  Not terrible, but not noteworthy either and definitely nothing to brag about.  Sorry, Stone, not a fan of the black IPA.
Dark translucent brown color with small tan head and no lacing. Aroma and flavor have rich roasty malts and strong hop presence with a light bitter sweet finish.  Good overall

Pours deep, murky brown with a thin tan head.  Nose is apple, pear, dates, toffee, a little coffee in the background.  Grapefruit hops.  Bitter.  Nice, thick malty backbone. Lingering smoky finish.  Tasty.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2013 Black with a lovely mild tan head. Aroma is mild mocha and hops. Taste is surprisingly mild - bitterness from hops leads into burnt flavours. Palate is a lingering bite of hops and roast. As it warms, the flavours come together even more. Thought I was going to be blown away by this one and instead it was just a good straight forward black IPA.

Black with cream head. Burnt malt with earthy aromas. Medium carbonation with moderate to heavy and super creamy body. Taste is chocolate malts with light pine to go with rich earthy hops that have a satisfying bitterness.

Pours an opaque, very dark brown with a foamy, persistent, root beer head. Aroma is conspicuously absent, given the gorgeous presentation. Some raw grain, some citrus hop notes. Nice, evenly balanced mouthfeel between the fullness and the carbonation. Flavors are comprised of spooned mashing grain, lemon, pine, and grass. Some dark roasted barley. Finishes with some faint pine and unfermented sugar. Big beer, but not because of any one big flavor. This is my favorite Stone brew. Thats not saying a lot because I think most are deplorable. But, I do like this one a lot.

Bottle, many thanks to coldbrewky. Almost black color with medium beige head. Aroma of dark malt, grapefruit, resin. Taste, dark malt, grapefruit, grapefruit zest, caramel, piney hops. Resiny finish. Alcohol is dangerously hidden. Very tasty beer.

Bottle from Kroger upper Arlington. Pours black with tan head. Nose is grapefruit and a bit of sweetness to keep the aggression at bay. Full bodied and notes of hops, citrus, smoky raisins, hops and more hops. Reminds me of a dark less balanced hopslam- minus some of the honey. Very well done sirs. 

---Rated via my mouth
Wow. Dark brown to black with light tan head.  Aroma is like peeling a grapefruit.  Taste is biting into the rind. Little sweet, lot of bitter bite.

Heavily skewed towards the hop end.  Bitter, lots of clear additions.  Its great but I think theres a bit of stones reputation figuring into that 100 rating.  Not too balanced, but a nice bite with a hint of roasted malt.

My favorite Black IPA.  It's the profile standard as far as in concerned; and perfectly balanced.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A very dark beer that would make you think it is a stout.   Nicely bitter and hoppy.  Once again stone always makes a great product 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Good dark color with nice creamy head.  Lots of pine notes in the nose with the taste matching it.  Plenty of hops across the palate and possibly some chocolate notes in there.  The body is medium and the finish is beautifully bitter.  Love it!  Great beer.
Pours black with a tan frothy head. Hop and roasted malt smell with some pine. Bold flavor. Hops, roasted malts and pine. Full body and bitter. Surprisingly good.

6/14/11
Aroma: pine, citrus, coffee and chocolate
Palate: good.
Flavor: pine, citrus, raisin, coffee and chocolate.
Poured from bottle at rockwells. Jet black with little head. Buscuit earthy and nutty aroma. As smooth as a black IPA can get. Amazing balance of hops, malt, and goodness.

Beautiful dark beer with a light head.  Sweet chocolaty spicy full taste.  Smooth finish.  Overall a very good Nd interesting beer.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Its interesting to taste this beer, its boozy, hoppy and has a lingering bitterness to it.  It also has a bit of an oily texture, pretty good, not a 100 though.

Bottled	01/03/13.  A black beer with a little off-white head.  A typical Black IPA US hoppy aroma.  A long and strong beer.  Very bitter and hoppy in the mouth with suggestive deep coffee flavours.  More bitter than most Black IPAs.  Quite a malty comfy finish.  Good stuff.
Dark black body, tan fizzy head. Excellent balance of malt, bitterness, and alcohol.

WOB, Coconut Creek, FL. Okay, I know I said the last beer was the best of the evening, but this is even better. Great aroma, smoky, pine infused maltiness with generous, but not over-powering hops. One of the best beers I've had in a long time.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

PS, Would taste better with a few tablespoons of sugar....we hear it helps the medicine go down.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2014 12 oz bottle.  Pours black with a light tan head, nice retention and patchy lacing.  Smells and tastes like citrus hops, spruce and roasted malts.  Medium body, smooth and creamy with nice carbonation and feel.  Its hoppy all the way through, but still balanced enough with a nice bite and a dry finish.

- Bomber bottle. Poured dark black with tan medium head. Pretty good lacing patterns. Aromas of chocolate, caramel malt, heavy piney hops, and light grapefruit. Flavor was most of the same. Medium carbonation with a nice creamy finish. Good hop bite too. In my top 3 from Stone

660 ml bottle. Pours an orangeish-brownish black with a resilient beige head. Smell is black coffee, caramel, hops. Flavor is dark chocolate, figs, coffee grains, licorice(?), black cherry, and I may have perceived a touch of smoke in there, too. But maybe that was my mind, just plain jubilating. Very solid dark chocolate, black coffee bitterness, lingers on for a while. Medium to thick body, oily, sticky mouthfeel. Rather weak carbonation. All I can say is...quite sublime, indeed!

From a 22oz bottle. Poured a dark brown with a medium tan head. This may be the perfect combination of IPA and porter. It tastes  and smells like no other ale Ive had and leaves me wanting more, every time.

This is the real deal! The best US BIPA for sure! Bottle from cotteridge wines. Pours a nice black with a thick tan head. The aroma was fairly muted which didnt really set me up for what was to come. Taste was a great balance not to heavy or bitter, spot on. Initial flavours of mocha from the malts and salted caramel. Then the citrus hit from the hops move in with its grapefruit tang and nice lasting bitterness In the mouth. Another great stone. Beer. As it say on the bottle, sublime.

This black brew poured into my Bama Jelly Jar with a delightful chocolately malt aroma and a tight, light tan head of foam. Tastewise, it isa  very will balanced dark ale with a bitter cocao type finish. Its a fine beer!

From bottle.  Thanks to my brother-in-law for sharing.  Pours almost black with a slight red hue.  Small tan head that is almost completely dissipating.  No lacing. Bottled. Pours dark brown, nearly black with a red glow and a medium sized tan head that leaves some excellent lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, grapefruit, grass and piney notes. Sweet flavor that ends up dry and solid bitter. Medium bodied, oily texture and soft CO2. A great black IPA. ★★★★

65cl bottle from Cotteridge Wines.Poured black with a good sized tan head.Caramel malt aroma with hops,pine and citrus also coming through.Nicely balanced taste of malt and hops with coffee,pine and lemon.Coffee in the aftertaste giving a nice bitter ending.Tasty beer.

Poured into a pint glass out of a 22oz bomber.

Pours a nearly opaque dark reddish-brown with a one finger tan head. Despite the smallish head there is outstanding head retention and nearly a solid wall of lace all the way around.

Aroma punches hard with pine resin and some tree bark. There is also a slight influence from tropical fruit but it is far behind the pine. There is a pleasant malt base with dark caramel, toast, and just a slight hint of coffee.

Tons of hops upon tasting. Pine mixed with a little bit of orange and lemon really dominates hardly letting any malt flavor through at all. Some sweet caramel along with dark toast and a faint hint of cocoa. Not nearly as much roast as I would expect given the dark color. The dark malt really shows more in the sweeter, heavier mouthfeel than in roastyness. Very bitter along with a full, somewhat sticky mouthfeel.

Overall, a really good Black IPA but I want more roast. There is not enough here to firmly set this apart from a normal IPA. That complaint aside, an excellent beer all around.

A bold blackish looking beer. superficially  appears like a porter though it obviously isnt. The raw resiny nose was pretty intoxicatng and the head billowing and foamy. August 14th, 2011 - I love Stones commercial descriptions. They were my model for beer reviews when I first started writing them, and they still entertain me today. Some breweries take themselves too seriously, but Stone obviously doesnt, and they have a small empire with which they could be very serious about. As for the Sublimely Self-Righteous Ale - it is the synthesis of the dreams of black IPA fans, moon shine distillers and alcoholics. This is, by far, the booziest black IPA Ive ever had. And thats not a bad thing. With its dark mahogany glow it practically growls with alcohol induced rage, and its scent is boozy, with a dry, old wood aroma and a cranberry dryness and bitterness. The taste is no less forgiving, with its dark, musty dryness, a sharp edge, considerable graininess and maltiness, and not too much in the way of residual sugars to lighten the load. THe bulk of this beers sharp anger is strictly on you, the drinker, which makes this tough and intense drinking. Some nights call for a tongue lashing, and I think the Sublimely Self-Righteous is the right weapon for the work.
UPDATED: SEP 18, 2014 Dark pour, tan head, nose is coffee, taste is coffee, some vanilla, smooth, awesome.

I always tend to associate piney hops with the East Coast and citrusy hops with the West. So its really surprising that Stone Sublimely Self-Righteous Ale is one of the pineyist beers Ive ever considering this brewery is the king of the left coast. Its a nice change of pace coming from them and its a delicious beer to boot.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a tulip glass.

Appearance: Opaque black body with a large, khaki colored, creamy head which is slow to dissipate and leaves gorgeous lacing on the glass.

Smell: Strong pine needle aroma with a subtle coffee scent. Some sweet orange juice concentrate as well.

Taste: Its been a while since I had an IPA that really accentuated the piney hops, so Stone Sublimely Self-Righteous Ale really caught me off guard. As soon as it hits the tongue theres intense bitterness that only increases as the swig follows through. Light and rustic at first like pine needles which gives way to a richer, stickier, bittersweet flavor of pine sap and a hint of dark chocolate. The ending is just like the beginning with even more sharp dry bitterness that lingers on the tip of the tongue and leaves a dry aftertaste. 

This is definitely the kind of uber-hoppy brew you expect from Stone. It doesnt let your palate rest, thats for sure. Though not very complex this palate never grows old. The only flaw, if I had to find one, is that it drinks so much like a regular IPA I almost forget its a black IPA. Though there are subtle coffee and dark chocolate flavors theyre not as overt as most brews of the style. 

Drinkability: This is definitely not a beer for beginners. Between the intense bitterness and robust palate its not something you simply gulp down. Though the mouthfeel is comfortable with a slightly creamy texture, it still has a strong presence. The hops definitely linger so this isnt a refreshing beer, though it would stand up to hearty meals well. At 8.7% ABV Stone Sublimely Self-Righteous Ale is actually light on its toes as it has no alcohol presence in the palate and doesnt go straight to your head, either.

Bomber bought through Systembolaget. Pours very dark brown with a frothy goldenish brownish white head that slowly dissipates while leaving some thick sticky lacing on the glass. Smell is fruity and roasted with heavily roasted malts, pineapple, salty liquorice, grapefruit rinds, pumpernickel, guanabana (soursop), roasted cookies, burnt caramel, resinous wood, pine, vanilla fudge, passion fruit, tropical fruit hard candy and lemon zest. Taste is slightly sweet, bitter and fruity with roasted malts, grapefruit juice, dark roast coffee, pineapple, guanabana, lychee, burnt cookies, bitter chocolate, pine, resinous wood, anise seed, toffee, lemon zest and orange peal. Mouthfeel is soft, smooth, round and medium bodied. Finish is tiny sweet and bitter with roasted malts, pineapple, lychee, anise seed, ark bread, grapefruit rinds, pine and orange peal. Great, smooth and balanced. I can see why this is the Black IPA benchmark.
Very citrusy nose, however it tastes exactly like Im drinking a liquid Sucret Sore Throat lozenge.  Not worth $7.85 for a big bottle.
Form a 22oz: Poured a dark brown with a small head. Piney and citrus aroma with nutty malt character. Deep malt taste with spice and citrus notes.

Very dark with a slight hoppy scent. The malts are more noticeable in the brews aroma & taste. The bitterness has a bite here. It sticks around after a taste. The great thing is that the bitterness isnt unpleasant. I also taste and smell wood notes in this ale. This is a very fine drink.

One of my favorites, always satisfies and never disappoints. Them Stone boys know what theyre doing. Read my comments on Headforbeer.com.
Thanks.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2012 Bottle from Systembolaget.
Pours dark brown, close to black with a 2 finger fluffy brown head which leaves nice lacing on the glass.
Aroma is citrusy and floral hoppy, some soapy notes as well. 
Taste is dominated by loads of piny bitter hops. Roasted malt and some coffee notes play in the background, some warming alcohol at the end.
After taste is really bitter and long lasting.
Medium bodied, medium carbonation.
I had expected more from this one, not very complex and the alcohol shines through a bit too much for me.
Bottled. Poured dark brown in color with off-white head. Citrus, some pine and roasted chocolate in aroma. Bittersweet in taste, pepper and citrus mostly. Nice.

Smells exactly like its name suggests it would. As well, it taste exactly as its name suggests. Plus, good. Not great but damn good. Its full of the bitter and chocolate and coffee and with piney and citrus and blah blah ba frackin blah. Its a real good black IPA. Id recommend it.

Vigorously poured from a 22oz bottle into a Spiegelau tulip glass. Produces a thick fluffy tan head reminiscent of a latte that clings to the glass like brown lace - not lasting throughout, but dissipates slowly.

Hop aromas mix with earth and roasted spice on the nose. 

Full mouthfeel is well balanced and rich - highlighted by coffee, smoke, and a pleasant bitter hop note. Slightly creamy and lingering finish.

Overall - a great representation of the unique Stone brewing tradtion. Not a beer that you open for your neighbor - this one should be held out of sight - for your eyes and enjoyment only. Cheers!
Very Brown color, roasted flavor. Aroma is sweet, caramel. Gets better at the end. Fruity.
Pours a dark black color with light brown head, looks better than it taste. Smells of pine and leaves a bad hop aftertaste. Stone is great beer but this one isnt for me!

Bottle from Ninas Mini Mart, Edinburgh 011012
Black...big frothy tan head, good lacing
Aroma - Grassy piney hops, bit of citrus, slight floral note, soft dark roasted malts, bit of chocoalte, some resins, quite complex aroma
Taste - as aroma, not as hoppy as excepted, mainly piney resinous hops, little fruity hop, lots of stouty characteri in the background, soft rich roasted malts, chocolate, alcohol is very well hidden. Its good, but to be honest, I expected the taste to be better
Palate - soft carb, medium to full body. Finish - bit dry, some bitter grassy resinous hops with roasted chocolate malts, touch of warming alcohol, bitterish linger
Overall - I really liked this at first but it after a well it wasnt working quite as well, I just wanted some more citrus fruitiness. Perhaps I had Buxton Imperial Black in my mind when drinking this. This just wasnt as good by a noticeable margin. Maybe this needs a re-rate one day
Bottle (Stockholm Beer Festival 2012) - Black in colour. Plain chocolate, roasted malt, coffee and liquorice in the aroma. Hoppy, soapy and roasted taste with notes of pine, liquorice and orange.

Bottle, pours black with medium tan head. Aroma is citrus, pine, some roasted malts, some coffee, some chocolate. Taste is firstly hoppy notes then comes the chocolate, coffe and licorice notes.Medium bitterness, pretty balanced. 
Nice!
@ Basunen: Stor gräsig doft, tjock vätska med gräsig humle och en trevlig lakritston. Lite salt eftersmak.
12 oz bottle...pours black with thick head...am beginning to drop off in my preference for black IPAs...this was just okay...nothing super at all...mild nose and taste...

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2015 I may lose credibility here on this rating. I have two cats and this beer smelled like Smoked cat piss to me. That may make some of you hop heads come running for this. I myself am a hophead but have never been a fan of stone beers in general. This another one to add to the disappointments. Seriously it smells like cat piss. Thank goodness I did not have to pay for it. re rate what was i thinking?????

Black with a big and lasting dark brown head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, roasted malt and moderate hoppy - citrus and peach. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Dry and rather bitter finish. 300912

Bottle. Very dark brown with medium beige head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, hops, citrus and grapefruit. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, citrus, grapefruit, pine, little sweet, pine and quite bitter.
Bottle. Huge creamy head with excellent duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are rich hops, roast malt, coffee, chocolate, pine, flowers and has a long heavy bitter finish.
From a bottle, poured almost black with a thin tan head. Bitter hops rule, with some malty sweetness upfront. Strong alcohol taste. Very good to drink slowly.

DArk black pour, light tan head.  A brutal dose of hops in the nose mixed with alcohol and burnt malt.  Sweet malt and bitter hops play tug of war in the middle; the hops win.  As the beer warms the dark roasted malt pushes back, but this still the "hop show".  Dry, long, and bitter finish.  Not for every occasion and not for the timid.

Out of the bottle from Uptown after the Stone tasting. I didn?t get to try this one so I bought a bottle and I am glad I did. Pours dark brown, almost black with a thick tan head. Extremely hoppy smell and taste which is a huge upside. Slightly malty finish, but not overpowering. Hoppy taste comes right back with the next drink. High ABV but doesn?t taste like it. Excellent!

Another palate demolisher from the devious Stone Brewing.  The beer rating session comes to a screeching halt. This is one knotty, piney, resin filled son of a bitch. It looks like stout but I can barely detect malt. Oil black, and suspiciously not heady. Flavor will consist of old, burnt dark roast coffee and unsweetened dark chocolate. Also pure bitterness. Body seems very heavy, but can only be weighed at finish due to extreme bitterness. The only thing more insufferable than an unqualified braggart is a well qualified one. Score another one for Stone.

Bottle.  Super dark brown, just about black with a medium light brown head.  Aroma is strong resin hops with a fairly small roasted malt aroma.  The stout character is much more present in the taste, lots of coffee, caramel and some chocolate.  Taste is medium sweet, heavy bitter, dry finish.  Medium bodied, soft carbonation.  Good beer.

Location: 22 oz bottle from Buy Rite, 9/19/12


Aroma: The nose is fairly hoppy, has some fruity notes, and light roasted notes

Appearance: It pours a dark brown color with a foamy light brown head and lasting drippy lace

Flavor: Tastes lightly malty, minimal sweetness, fairly roasty, with a medium-plus hoppy/bitter finish

Palate: The body is medium, it has an average carbonation, and a rather lengthy, dry finish

Overall Impression: 
File this one away on the "I cant believe I havent rated this yet" list.  Anyway, this is a really quality beer that I have enjoyed before, and should most definitely have given its due rating before now.

Deep black pour with a frothy beige head. Aroma is charred malts - toast, coffee, dark chocolate. Silky smooth mouth feel with low carbonation. Flavours is quite roasted with coffee and burnt toast. Finish is a roasted bitterness with piney hops. Nice and quite drinkable.

From the bottle at Nosh in Portland, ME. Served a bit too cold for my liking; flavors would probably be more prominent at cellar temperature. Pours black with a nutty brown head. Held to the light it has a ruby appearance. Complex nose: pine, citrus, floral, malt. Medium-to-heavy bodied with a roasted, coffee-like flavor that finishes dry & bitter. A keeper.

Pours a dark redish brown with some lasting head.  Strong pine aromas with some citrus and leather.  Flavors jump out right away with bold fresh pine along with a mild sweet malt and a bitter finish.  Little burn and dryness in the finish, too.  Dont think I would know this is a black IPA, from the lack of any toastyness or burn malts.
Draft from awhile black. Pours midnight black with tan head. Nose/taste of roast chocolate malt, coffee, pine and resin. Well balanced roast and bitter hop resin. Medium body.
This one crept up on me.  Poured with a generous head, this is a velvet glove beer.  Dark and brooding.

I tried it as part of a sampler at Burgers and Brew in Sacramento, CA and I had to go home and find it on the internet at Total Wine on Arden.  I went and bought 3 22s cause thats all they had in stock.  Then the next week my wife found out that they now have a 4 pack of 12 ozs so I bought 2and tried 1 22 of arrogant bastard and like that one too.  You guys do an excellent job at brewing ale!
Love this beer.  this beer was a very tasty, strong and took me by surprise.  I will always pick this beer when given three choice.
Bottle - small foamy head, black color, nice citrus hop aroma and flavor, with a kick of roasted malt at the end

Bottle pour too many times to count, one of my all-time favorites. Concentrated on this as I tasted tonight, citrus-pine aroma that is surprising for a beer that appears so black.
