Coffee, mild hints of chocolate, delicious malty underlayer that counterbalances the bitterness.  Significant bitterness in the taste as well as the hoppy citrus aroma that kicks you in the face.  Anyone who has ever homebrewed understands why this costs what it does, so many hops had to go into a beer of this magnitude.  Just plain awesome.

22 oz bottle purchased at Stone Brewing Co.  Pours a dark, dark brown ... not quite black. Develops a half-inch deep tan head that dissipates to a film over a few minutes.  Aroma is that of pine, citrus and coffee. Slightly sticky. Average carbonation.  Bitter finish that lasts long, slowly tailing off.  Stone did a great job with this one.

Ar: Resiny pine, dank moss and woodiness, grapefruit rind.
Ap: Black, opaque - large light tan head with excellent retention and beautiful clingy lacing.
T: Bright bitter orange up front - some sweet and luscious dark caramel - deep flavors of pine, lemon, and black pepper - very bitter, with a slightly rustic edge - finish is grapefruit rind and smooth coffee.
P: Medium body with medium-high carbonation - finish is medium-dry.
O: This is a hell of a good beer - intensely hoppy with delicious subtle dark malt flavors.

Bottleshare BBQ at Dave Ls, PA - 27/05/12.
Black with a small mocha head.
Pine, citrus, hops, a little chocoalte on the nose.
Juicy hop flavour - slighthly floral, pine, chocolate backdrop.
Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, dry finish.
One of the better black IPA s on the market.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Draught glass at rattle n hum. Pours almost black with dark orange edges. Great oatmeal coloured cap. Aroma of molasses/licorice. Not much bitter aroma. Slightly rindy. But pure molasses, really. Taste is upfront roasted malt, and before your palate adjusts, it's a mouth smack of smokey malt. The smokey taste lingers in the palate, while its a bitter, dark fruit nutty type malt that's coats the tongue. Plum-y. A deep, lingering dry bitterness present. Cripes. The style really shines in the trailing palate notes. Absolutely. Such lingering palate. So good.

Poured from a 22 oz bottle into an ipa glass. Almost black with lom
Ng lasting light tan head  Citrusy ipa aroma. Toasted malt and coffee notes over hops. Very nice beer.
draft - pours black with tan head and great lacing.  Spruce nose and eventually becomes roasty.  Balanced taste-wise at first, but quickly dominated by the bitterness.  long bitter aftertaste.

Bout time I review this, Ive been glossing it over for a few months now, and I hope this is as killer as the 15th anniversary ale Stone did. 22 oz. bottle poured into a tumbler pint glass.

A: Pours a very dark brown color with faint hints of light coming through the body. The head is a two finger light mocha color with a great creamy texture and excellent retention. Nice rings of lacing are left on the glass.

S: Grapefruity. Im a little disappointed Im not getting more roast/coffee/chocolate - in fact, it smells mostly like a generic IPA, not just from the citrus rind/pine/herbal hop tones, but honestly a bit from the malt backbone, as well. It smells more bright than roasted, although theres a faint hint of chocolate to remind me its still a black IPA. Dont get me wrong, I really like how it smells, but I want a little more black and a little less IPA. Then again, I thought the exact same about Storm King, and I absolutely loved that one...

T: This is really drinking like a normal IPA to me, sadly...initial flavors are strong in grapefruit and orange rind, before giving way to a medium finishing bitterness. However, the hop profile is very well executed. Chocolate malt starts to make its appearance after several sips, helping smooth out the hops and providing a burnt, ashy (even vegetal, at times) edge to the finish. Still, it doesnt mesh together in the way Stones 15th does, and it becomes slightly too boozy as it warms up - drink this one cold, in other words.

M: Rather thin, with a dryness coming more from the hops rather than the roast. Theres a bit of malt stickiness throughout. Alcohol can be felt slightly on the tongue and stomach once it warms up, and it just feels weird all around. Drinkability is disappointingly low.

O: Im really disappointed its only okay instead of mindblowing like its (sorely missed) big brother. Im thinking maybe oldish bottle, but the Stone 15th I had was 6 months old, and it still blew me away. To be fair, that was clearly more malt driven - so Ill try this again fresh, or maybe on tap.

Bouteille 22 oz. achetée au IGA de Potsdam, NY. Couleur brune très foncée, presque noire, mousse beige. Arôme de houblon frais incroyable, un peu de céréales torréfiées. En bouche, malt torréfié, réglisse, houblon floral, café. Finale amertume longue, caramel brulé. Wow, une explosion de saveurs, odeurs et goûts. Excellente. Merci Stone.
It tastes more like a stout that an IPA, to me. Doesnt have the hoppy bite that I love about IPAs.

Pouring, it looked like root beer and had a foamy, creamy head.  The smell was hops in a huge way, I could smell them while I was pouring it.  There was the usual citrus/pine thing and what seemed to me to be a rye tone.  The taste was very strong, very bitter, with the hops playing huge and the malt smooth and rich in the finish.  The malt became more pronounced over the course of the glass, and by the end I was liking it very much.

This is one of those thin line brews between Black IPA/Imperial stout. Since this has two months before its expo date any hop flavor is barely present, I get fruity/piney hops in the smell, but not too much in the flavor. Now its roasted notes of creamy coffee/ espresso. Alcohol inst present. It does have a strong bitter finish. I like this either, Black IPA or Imperial stout, you be the judge.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2012 Pitch black, exquisite lacing. Resin hops on the nose and some hints of coffee and chocolate. Same with the flavor, really satisfying bitterness, super refreshing. The ipa component dominates but there is a subtle coffee component on the end that marries well. Very intriguing Beer. Would rate again.

Cask version made especially for GBBF 2012. Thanks for sending this one over guys. One of the best American casks at the festival. Slightly opaque dark brown, light brown and white bubbley head. Nose is big citrous grapefruit and mango, papaya, black sugar. Taste is bitter grapefruit, eucalyptus, pine, mango. Finish is combination of eucalyptus and grapefruit.

APPEARANCE: A dark brownish-black pour and a small off-white head with no retention. Minimal lacing present. AROMA:  A strong hop forward fragrance of citrus and pine open the sinus cavities. TASTE: Initially there is a wonderful hit of pine and citrus followed by some nice malt notes and a pleasing bitter finish. MOUTHFEEL:  Medium bodied with medium carbonation. OVERALL: This is a great Black IPA. Nice combination of hops and dark malts. Will drink again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Had on tap at Yardhouse and it is phenomenal. The blend of smoothness with bitterness of the IPA is perfect. Would like to try it in bottle.

Super hoppy, earthy aroma. Deep black with little foam. Massive earthy hops, coffee malts and boozy finish. Complex flavors with a light carbonation. Overall, an absolutely fantasic black IPA with a ton of flavor. Very hoppy. A rating.

Really nice offering from Stone.  I like the toasted caramel burnt roast maltyness. Cocoa nibs, coffee, hint of vanilla, and maybe some oak aroma/flavor. Lovely. The hops were folded in very covertly, I noticed them but truly light touch considering the dark malts. Awesome

Aroma - Hop forward aroma. Citrus and Pine.
Appearance - Black with white head. Delicate lacing on glass.
Taste - Intense bitterness from the hops and malty sweetness.
Palate - Moderate carbonation and medium bodied.
Overall - Great black IPA. As good as Uintas Dubhe. Very drinkable.

Black pour. Piney to cities hops are apparent but not overwhelming as in some blacks. Hint of pear as well. Toffee after the hoppy taste rolls into a nice bitter bite. Much more bitter than other blacks. Very well balanced. Nice stuff

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This beer appears black with a thick, light tan head. The head hangs out for several minutes before leaving a thick sheet of lacing on the glass. The aroma is of alcohol, hops, pine. The flavor is primarily of hops and pine, with chocolate and roast notes following behind. The feel is medium bodied with prominent alcohol throughout. This beer is a bit too hot, slightly degrading the drinkability...

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-21-2011
UPDATED: NOV 29, 2013 Very dark and very bitter this beer reminds me of a very bitter stout mixed with an ipa

A nice, rich ale with a strong and hoppy finish.  It looks great and starts off with a bit of coffee/caramel flavor before finishing with a bite.  Not for everyone and I'd label it more of a pale ale then ale but definitely a solid beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Black pour with a tan head and one of my favorites of the style, nice hoppy aroma with some citrus, pine and roasty malt notes.  Tasty with a hell of an awesome bite!

Pours almost black with a beige head that fades quickly.  Aroma is roasted, with chocolate, some coffee, fig, citrus, and pine.  Taste is dry and bitter.  Much more floral than the aroma anticipates.  Lots of pine and hops.  Grapefruit and lemon abound, but this still has some good malty undertones that are very apparent underneath all.  This one is actually more on the lighter side and somewhat creamy when drinking.  That is surprising since the alcohol content does not hide from you in this one.  Strong piney, hoppy, aftertaste that will not leave.  Excellent.

Black pour with thin tan head. Glass was coated in lacing while drinking. Great great scent, hops are perfectly blended aromas of citrus and pine with a hint of honey. Medium frothy mouth feel. Bitter and piney at first. Malt and honey come through/come back on the finish.
Aroma is american hoppy plus some dark malts, maybe roasted.  Flavor is a phenomenal black ipa, bitter and hoppy with some chocolate and roasted notes.

Draft to pint at Dutchs. Looks good; pitch black with nice beige lacing. Smells good too; hoppy. Tastes nice; a great balance of hops and malt. Good on the palate too; the abv is well-hidden. Very good beer!

Beautiful color black with a redish hue. a nice piney aroma combined with dark chocolate.  a nice medium to full body with a chocolate and coffee flavors. a exceptional clean finish with some piney flavor more chocolate really nice.

I tasted this side by side with the 11th Anniversary brew, so there is a five year difference between the two of these. Both poured pitch black in appearance with big khaki heads, however, the fresh bottle has much better lacing and the head is sticking around a lot longer. The aged bottle is noticeably more malty in aroma, with smells of figs, marshmallows, graham crackers, and toffee. The fresh bottle is hop forward with hints of grapefruit, pine, resin, roasted malt, cocoa, and coffee. Both have of tastes of roast, chocolate, and coffee, but again the aged is very barleywine-esque with flavors of, raisins, fig, and a light bitter finish. Fresh there are flavors of juicy hops, grapefruit, pine, big roast, and a moderately bitter finish. Also, alcohol is much more present in the aged bottle, but it held up really well. The body has really thinned out with age, but the Sublimely has a creamy texture with soft carbonation. I am basing my rating on the fresh version which is a well-crafted IPA, but the aged Anniversary ale is delicious in its own right, like a roasty American Barleywine. Very interesting comparison and a job well-done by Stone. Cheers!
extreme fresh hop aroma - nice molasses brown pour - extreme melange of hop flavors pine-grapefruit-orange-etc, nice malty hoppy finish

Pours a dark dark brownish black with a thick tan frothy head that leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is balanced between rich malt and bright hops with some roastiness. rich full mouthfeel with smooth creamy carbonation. Flavor is an amazing balance of malt and hop, malt has both caramel and roasty notes and the hop bitterness is strong up front but then transforms into an absolutely delicious hop flavor. Overall this may be one of my favorite beers to date, I cant get over the balance and the malty goodness then the hop flavor is right on... And its black and roasty... Gonna be hard to top this ipa.
Those guys at Stone know how to make a good beer, and they arent afraid to brag about it.  Dont pass this black IPA up.

A black colored beer, with a thick beige head. The aoma of dark fruits, with roasted malt and hop. The taste of dark fruits like prun, roasted malt, hop with spices. A little burny. The aftertaste is some sweet with bitter and a little burny.

I enjoyed this beer a lot .  Nice pour with a good amount of head and some lace.  Aromas of caramel, with a bit of floral tones and some funk.  A dark, rich beer with a surprising amount of hops.  The beer begins sweet and malty, more balanced roasted flavors in the middle, and then clobbers with hops at the end.

.66 bottle from brewdog. Black with a somewhat creamy head. Dark aromas, roasted, dark chocolate which transforms into something softer as the fruity pinyness emerges from behind. Body is soft with loads of pines, chocolate, roasted malts, even some espresso. Finish lingers, excellent stuff. Soft and nice.-- rated with lankku (N9)
Darker the beer, sweeter the taste!.....This is close to perfection.  What a way to combine the best of both worlds.........dark stout and ipa.....wow, insane or should I say sublimely delicious!

Tasted on draft at the 12 South Winter Warmer in 2011.  Pours opaque dark brown with an average tan head that slowly recedes to thin lace.  The nose is aggressively hoppy (classic Stone) bitter, with tons of underlying darkly roasted notes of dark chocolate.  The flavor is even more roasted than on the nose, with intensely bitter resin hops taking over.  The body is full with lively, stinging carbonation, and a long dark chocolate and resin hops, intensely bitter finish.

650ml bottle. Clear dark reddish brown with average to huge, firm, frothy to creamy, perfectly lacing, tan head. Underlying dark roasted malty aroma with massive hop overtone. Taste is similar, with additional notes of slightly sweet milk chocolate and the typical black IPA hop and malt combination resulting in carot-like notes. Very good.

Pours a dark black with an off white head. Aroma of hops, brown sugar, caramels and roasted malts. Taste is a sweet hoppy goodness that coats the mouth with just a hint of peat. Roasted malts and some chocolate notes follow. Nice carbonation. This is what a black IPA strives to be. The  sweetness and hops balance very well. Finishes with a resiny citrus hoppiness that goes on and on. What a treat.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2013 Striking beer. While drinking, my wife and I like to talk about the beer. After a sip of this she told me not to talk...she just wanted to enjoy drinking this one. Dark brown stout looking pour. The aroma explodes with citrus hops, but falls into some chocolately malts. The taste follows with a perfect amount of piney and citrusy hops to balance the sweet roasted maltiness. Has a nice twang of bitterness in the aftertaste. Medium bodied and carbonated so it is easy to drink. Great stuff, indeed.

On tap at Quarry House Tavern in Silver Spring, MD. 

Opaque, nearly black brown with creamy tan head and excellent lacing. 

Aroma of grapefruit and pine hops with some chocolate and coffee roasted malts.  

Taste of strong pine and citric hops balanced beautifully be sweet roasted chocolate and coffee malts. 

Full/medium body and medium carbonation with a very smooth creamy mouthfeel. 

I've tried several iterations of the beer, both bottles and on tap.  This is by far the best. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from Brewdog shop. Black color, beige head. Roasty taste with coffee, caramel, toast. Very roasty finish. Awesome ale!

Excellent... And if you don't think so, then you don't know hop! I am a sublimely self-righteous beer snob and I say so!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Wonderful example of the style!  Enticing, heavenly hop aroma from extensive dry hopping/late kettle additions.  Flavor is equally sublime.  Alcohol and bitterness are both high, but take a back seat.  One of my favorites!

Bottle. Pours black with a bit of red. Clear with a large tan head, good lacing. Aroma is a wonderful mix of grapefruit, roasted malts, and pine. Taste is heavy on grapefruit as well, with roasted malts and a touch of chocolate. Finish is strongly bitter and warming alcoholic. This beer came damn close to cracking my top ten list.

Bottle 22oz from Total Wine. Pours a very dark brown / black, nice head on pour but diminish quickly. Aromas of malt and some caramel, lots of grapefruit and piney hopps. (Great aroma). Taste of medium sweet and malt with a big grapefruit sweetness. Good full body, creamy slick texure with a well rounded bitter finish.

Black body, big off white head. Great heavy bitter aroma with pine as well as burned toast. Full body, well carbonated. Bitter grassy with pine, along with a dry roasted malty with coffee flavour. Great.

Pours dark chestnut brown with a big pillowy tan-tonged cream head. Notes of resin, cardamom and lemon pith on the nose. Carbonation is fairly soft allowing notes of chocolate, orange essence and a pile of orange pith to be tasted. Sure theres bitterness but its backed up by plenty of malt to reign in the burn. That alcohol is wondrously disguised too. Little sign of dark malt flavour either, a true, fantastic BIPA.

Dark brown/black with brown frothy head, nice lacing - very attractive ale. Punches you in the nose with citrus and pine, lemon, and honey, cloves. Taste is citrus and hops and finishes with dark chocolate. Great beer.

22 ounce bottle. Dark brown, black transluscent color topped by a foamy tan head. Lovely roasted malt aroma with hints of molasses, smoked meat and dried fruits. Burnt caramel malt flavor, hints of licorice, sticky dried fruit and subltle piney hops. Sticky mouthfeel that lasts forever. this is a special brew. Very flavorful, yet subtle.

From the bomber bottle, pours black with a thin off white head.  Thick syrupy molasses sweet aroma. Molasses, chocolate, alcohol, dark malts. Really well balanced, easy to drink without crossing the line into watery. Not sure this is a hundred percenter, but a very good beer.

A mahogany beer that lets only a little light through around the edges feature very long hasting head and decent lacing. The smell is very full and rich with spiced apple grapefruit dominated but well rounded hop bouquet. Theres a strong cookie malt and a little grass to ad further dimension. A little sweetness in the soft foamy mouthfeel quickly is taken over by a wallop of dark roasted grain and pine bitterness that tries to dry it out by the end. Top fucken beer.
If you arent a fan of dark beers this isnt for you. Very dark, thick beer, very good tasting, great aroma. Strong with a mix of pine and chocolate taste, better version of Guineas.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2012 The double dry hopped version on tap at Proof. Pours a dark black with small tan head and good lacing. Aroma is grapefruit and citrus hops. Taste is really hoppy with a nice malty roast finish. Superb beer! Normal is pretty damn good as well.
Tap at Oak St. Pours black with a lasting off white head. Strong pine and sweet chocolate aroma.  Pine is prevalent in the taste but there is also a lot of roasted flavor as well.  Very good.
Molt de llúpol i regalèsia amb nas. Cremosa i molt ben equilibrada en boca. Es podria confondre perfectament amb un Imperial Stout. Boníssima.

Pours a beautiful black with a light brown head and some nice thick lacing. The aroma is dank hops and roasty chocolate syrup. The taste is amazing. The perfect balance of hops and chocolate malt. Nearly perfect in every way.

Pours jet black with a tan head that coats the top forever. Lots of long lacing. Nose is big pine hop hit with maybe a hint of sweet chocolate. Mouth initially light sweet, then some espresso and lots of bi bitterness on the finish. Medium to light body with lots of carbonation. Awesome!

Pours an opaque, super dark brown color.
The pour produced a copious amount of rich dense foamy head thats tan in color. This tan head is slow fading leaving sticky lacing in its wake.

Aromatics are wonderfully pungent with sticky hop oils. Hop bouquet leans towards earthy and floral.
Beyond the hop pop there is very sutle roasted malt nuiances.

Taste is rich roasted malts up front, sutle, not overpowering with some hints of chocolate and coffee. Sweet upfront.
Hops take charge next with a pretty desent hop bite and a good, fresh hoppy flavor. Bitter at the end. 
A good medium bodied ale. I detect some fine grittiness. The bitterness is stong and lingers deep into the aftertaste.

A good looking beer, a good smelling beer and a good tasting beer. What more could you want.

Tap at iTap. Pour is near black with a thin tab head. Aroma is dominated by pine hop with a crisp roasted malt backbone. Straightforward and clean. Flavor also pine hop and roasted malt with some hints of resinous hop and light ash. Nice beer.

Bomber poured into snifter.  Pours a very dark brown which is almost opaque.  Gives a 1/2" inch tan head which reduces to a flat spot in the middle of the glass. Leaves a very fine lacing.  Aroma is very roasty and floral hops, a bit "chocolaty" and a quite bit of coffee (which becomes even more intense as the beer warms up).  Taste is medium-bitter wih some alcohol presence developping around 12 degrees Celcius.  Body is rather full with a slick/nearly oily texture.  Carbonation is average for this style.  Bitter finish which lasts quite a while!  This is a really, really good beer.  I have to confess that this is only my 2nd black IPA and the first one was really just "ok" and weighted in at 6% only.  So in my book, this is a "double black IPA" and is something really different from the last one I drank.  I like this one better!

Could be my favorite Black IPA. It looks like an Imperial stout, but smells like the freshest hope imaginable. Medium to full bodied, this shows roasty malted flavors on the palate. Seemingly endless hoppy finish.

It tastes pretty good at room temperature.  Imagine this: someone whispers and asks you to come here, they motion their finger so that you lean in listen, then they punch you in the face.  This beer has a high abv thats not forceful at first, but it packs a wallop with the big floral smell and the eventual effect on your senses.  Smooth and still bitter, I give this an "A" grade.

Pours almost opaque red with massive head that persists.  Mild smell of smoke, alcohol, and wood.  Thick, bittersweet smokey flavor with coffee, caramel, chocolate, hops, charcoal, butter, lots of citrus, and much more.  Light, sticky finish.

Appearance: A deep brown color pours from the bottle but becomes absolutely once its in the glass and light isnt getting through this at all. Very deep and solid looking. Its almost a little intimidating. Theres a great dark beige head that towers at three fingers. The bubbles are massive and they stick around forever. Looks great in the glass.

Smell: The hop profile is strong on top but this beer has got secrets. Theres caramel, malt and a smooth breadiness that are lying just under the surface, playing over a strong smoke scent. Stone really knows how to make some aromatic beers and Self-Righteous teases the nose with the best of them. 

Mouthfeel: Rich. Theres a refreshing, crisp quality here that still manages to be creamy.

Taste: Hops hit first and refresh more than anything. I was expecting a much more bitter hop expression and while theres bitterness here, its just smooth and clean. The tartness of them help hold the beer together. Lots of grapefruit and tangerine. A bit of lime is hiding in there too. As it passes the center of the mouth, the caramel, malt and smoke steal the show. Really, really well balanced. As it warms, I start to sense a coffee flavor. The beer ends as refreshingly as it began with a tart hop profile. Very enjoyable. 

Overall: A well balanced but still hop forward black ale that surprises with its complexity? Check. Decent price? Check. The fun of Stone brewery? Check. Another hit from Stone and another delicious hop-heavy black ale for the world.

Appearance was clear root beer black with creamy diminishing off white 1 finger head, no lacing. Aromas are wild here with coffee ,caramel, coco and nutty malts. Hops of citrus pine, with herbal spiceyness and yeasts of dark fruits of cherry and fig. Taste where sweet chocolatly coffee roasty malts. Hops are shinnig through with lemons and herbal spicy citrus orange and cherries, complement the hops and malts well together. Palate was silky creamy carbonation with a medium-full like feel. The glorious rich,full, and hoppy average length balanced finish.  Yummy, yummy love in my tummy...
Nice dark brown color with a long lasting foamy white head.  Fairly bold bitter taste with a smooth long cola coffee finish.

Bottle from Phictor, fuck you!! Pours dark brown, nice two finger dense brown head. Aroma is lovely hoppy with grapefruit, citrus, zest, a good malt profile with cocoa, caramel, very simple, but very balanced. Taste is very bitter and hoppy, lots of alpha acid. Exquisite malt profile - sweet caramel and cocoa notes without providing bitterness - that's up to the hops, the malts are merely complementary, which is exacty what it should be in a black IPA. This is the best black IPA I've had so far. This rocks!

Immense flavor!  Hard to call this simply a Black IPA because it is so much more.  The richness approaches some of the best Imperial Stouts while the hop-balance is on par with a great Double IPA.  One amazingly complex beer and highly recommended.

22 oz. bottle pours a very dark brown with a lasting tan head and good lacing.  Smell is all piney and citrus hops.  Aroma also has roasted malts, pine, rye bread, peach, and a bit of coffee. Taste is slightly sweet at first with the hops kicking in on the bitter finish, with alcohol evident soon after. Full bodied with an almost creamy mouthfeel and not too much carbonation.  An excellent black IPA/IIPA which almost lives up to Stones usual hype printed on the back of the bottle.

Let this guy warm up a bit and youll be able to appreciate the interesting hop profile that hides behind the bold malts. Flavors of hops, roasted malts, pine, coffee, and rye bread. Very nice aroma of dank hops and tropical fruits. Good stuff. Share with a friend because a whole bomber gets to be flavor overload.
Bottle. Color brown with big brown head. Aroma malt, caramel, chocolate, hop, grapefruit. Taste sweet, hop, peach, bitter, grass.

Bottle to chalice filled with espresso with a large fluffy tan head and significant lacing.  Aroma includes strong grapefruit presence, piney hops, and hints of freshly brewed coffee.  First sip reveals the layers of flavor including bitter sweet chocolate, roasted malts, and notes of citrus.  Really smooth finish with slight smoke and bitterness lingering in the mouth.  Perfectly blended Black IPA.

A - pours deep dark almost opaque cola syrup brown with high fluffy tan head that lasts a while. Strong lacing. S - hops hops and hops. But subtle. Grassy and piney up front. Centennial hops? M - full bodied beer with a nice palate. Lingering sweeter malty finish with a nice bitter finale. T - nice well rounded ipa. Centennial hops, grassy and citrus hops up front. Nice transition to a sweeter malty palate. Nice notes of quiet roasted malts and  a hint of chocolate. O - very good clean black ipa. 7+

Pours a very dark dark brown but seemingly clear beer with a tan head that lasts a while with great lacing. Aroma of citrus with maybe some fruit and roasted malt. Tastes of malt and coffee with a hint of chocolate. It has a great undertone of bittersweetness. There is a twang at the end that may be the alcohol. Not to sure how I like this initially but will see how it pans out with the full drink. Overall of moderate body and carbonation. Not sure how I like this beer overall but this is the first of this style for me so that may just be it. As time went on this beer did grow on me so I have modified some of the numbers.

22 oz bomber pours deep brown with a tan head.  Aroma of malt, citrus and a bit of pine.  Taste of the malt and very nice citrus hops.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22oz bottle poured into tulip glass.  No bottled on date.
Aroma:  citrus, fruity, floral hops, malt, caramel
Appearance: very dark brown color, doesnt let much light through.  1 finger milk chocolate colored head that faded rather quickly.  very small and tight packed bubbles.  laces glass nicely.  fairly clear once i drank towards the bottom of the glass and light could get through.
Taste: mild sweet, mild sour, mild bitter
Palate: roasty aftertaste, lots of malt and coffee with a twinge of bitter.  i like this alot.  Carbonation is average but feels right.  medium body and thin texture.  
Overall: I was afraid this was going to be extremely bitter considering the other stone beers I have tried but i was pleasantly surprised.  Also I wasnt expecting the roasty malt and coffee flavors which i also liked.   Some chocolate came through as well.  Not as hoppy as i expected either.  Just an extremely well balanced and tasty brew with a few surprises.  Very impressed!
Pours black with three fingers light tan head. Smell is very hoppy and a bit of coco. Taste is a bit of roast, some floral hoppiness, and that same bit of coco. Very well done.
Creamy, malty and hoppy. Dark and heady. Tastes and even looks almost like a porter. Minorly sweet and somewhat bitter. Deluctable

Nice dark malty ipa. Perhaps some citrus crispness but malt is what I noticed the most. 

On tap at rock n brews

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

US sized bottle from Beers of Europe into a pint glass at home.  Black beer with a creamy head.  Nicely hopped, citrus aroma, with a bit of extra zest to it.  A nice blend, smooth, potent and tasty.  Nicely blend of hops, bitterness, a hint of porter, alcohol and spice.  Tasty as its not been overhopped.

Bottle. Very dark brown - almost black, average and fully diminishing light brown head. Moderate, malty and sweetish aroma, some caramel, tropical fruitiness, lots of grapefruit - piney hoppyness. Body is medium to full, malty and sweetish flavor, some caramel and faint roasted malt, some tropical fruitiness, grapefruit - piney hoppyness. Finish is average, malty and lightly sweetish, light caramel with some tropical fruitiness, lots of piney hoppyness, light roasted malt. Really nice hoppyness in the aroma - flavor has bit too much caramel sweetness.
Amazing beer. Full body whit long bitter and smoky finish. It has a taste that I cannot des ribs right now. I need anotwher bottle. Wow it is strong on the alcohol side....bye

Bottle bought at Systembolaget, Sweden. Namned Stone Anniverary ale XI, opened 20 april 2012 (5 years old). Thick lasting beige head. Clear dark brown color.
Piny hops with dark roasted malt aroma. Dry, hoppy and medium bitter taste that  is well balanced and still fresh after so long time in the bottle! After some time dark chocolate present itself in the taste together with a lingering bitterness. A very good black IPA. Could be a litle more lively sparkle but with a fine medium body.
This one poured with a  very thick head for me. This bitterness of the hops is cut by the maltiness, making for an easier drink.
I havent been one for dark ales, but this one is fantastic.  It goes very well with dinner and has a nice kick to it too.
Pour is very dark with medium head. Taste is sweet with a hint of citrus and hoppy with a bitter finish that lingers.

Earthy, mulch-like complexity. Cranberry bitterness headlocks the tongue. Color is a sensational oak brown. Smell is of molasses. This brew is reminiscent of Stones Arrogant Bastard, but more peppery. There are only about 100 solid flavors going on in this black IPA. Youll need an archeological crew to unearth them all. This stuff is magic with a fleshy slice of German chocolate cake.

22 ounce bottle into tulip, best by 2/14/2012.  Re-reviewing my first rating ever from 6/3/2010.  Pours almost pitch black color with a nice 2 finger dense khaki head with great retention that reduces to a thick cap that lingers.  Some nice soapy lacing on the glass.  Aromas of grapefruit, pine, biscuit, chocolate, caramel, roasted malt, floral, and herbal hops.  Nice and well balanced aromas with good strength.  Taste of big grapefruit, pine, toasted biscuit, caramel, chocolate, roasted malt, herbal hop, and coffee.  Nice sized smooth spicy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of pine, toasted biscuit, chocolate, caramel, citrus, and herbal spiciness on the finish for a while.  Fantastic balance of hop bitterness to roasted malt flavor for a black IPA.  Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a fairly creamy and sticky mouthfeel.  Very smooth to drink but is still a sipper.  Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming after the finish noticed.  Overall this is a delicious Black IPA as expected.  Big hop flavors with a great balanced malt backbone that I usually prefer in black IPAs.

Black with tan, frothy head.  Nice lacing.  Roast, caramel, licorice, citrus aroma.  Roast, citrus, caramel flavors. , Full bodied with lasting bitter finish.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Havent had enough from Stone, but this has surpassed Ruination as my favorite from them.
Stones top brew in my mind. Great flavor. Dark brown basically black pour. Malty, notes of coffee, cream and spices.

From a growler. Dark thick pour. Roasted malts, light chocolate and coffee, with some high citrus notes. Hops come out in the middle, providing a fresh and bitter taste to compliment the roasty finish.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2014 Bottles Rehills, Newcastle and Beers of Europe in Norfolk. A black beer with orange marmalde, liquorice, blackcurrant, chocolate and whisky/vanilla flavours followed by a creay bitter-sweet slight roasted and floral hoppy, sarsaparilla finish. Fantastic!
Black with red touches. Aroma roasted malt, chocolate and pine. Taste  roasted malt, caramel and hoppy . Body medium, carbonation light with  bitter end. Very good

UPDATED: APR 21, 2014 From a bomber, pours black & tan head. Chocolate and biscuit malt aroma, pine, citrus hop, roasty. Comes together really well with a lively carbonation leaving a balanced bitter finish with chocolate aftertaste. As far as Black IPAs go, this is the best Ive had. As beers of all styles go, this is up there.

Beautiful black appearance with creamy white head. Very smooth and a bitter lingering aftertaste. Excellent overall.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Deep black color with a beige head that remains for a bit.  Hop aroma is faint but the roasted coffee smell comes through.  Tastes great.  Nice balance of hops with the dark malt.  Not very complex but exactly what a black IPA should taste like and I really like black IPAs.

Roasty, complex. Good hoppy aroma. Bitter finish. Great stuff would drink again.

-- Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone.

22 ounce bottle that poured a dark brown color, aromas of grassy hops, coffee, some chocolate, and pine.  Flavor is the same as the aromas, with a smidge of dark fruit and apricots coming through the coffee, pine and chocolate flavors.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2012 Poured from a bomber into a duvel tulip.
Dark brown with a 2 inch tan head that recedes to an inch and is foamy. Lacing is sticky. Aroma is toasted barley, citrus, coffee, and light floral notes. Taste is of toasted barley and light bittersweet chocolate. Orange peel, lemon, and strong citrus is there too. There is a bitterness that is dark coffee mixed with grapefruit. This beer is a malt and hop bomb. Mouthfeel is medium and a slight bitterness lingers. This is only my second BIPA but I think it will be one to judge others against. Very good.

Poured into a snifter. I admit Im not a fan of Black IPAs, but I figured Id give this one a go anyway.

3.5 A: Black color. Two fingers of frothy tan head. Retention is average for style and plenty of lacing is left.

4.0 S: Pleasant marriage of citrusy hops and roastiness. The two seem to get along better in this than in morst BIPAs. Lots of orange with pine and grapefruit in the background. Roastiness without muc chocolate or caramel.

3.0 T: The taste doesnt work too well though. Citrus with roasty burntness simply isnt a tasty combination. At least this isnt overly bitter like a lot of the style. Roasty foremost, orange and grapefruit second, and pine and char last. 

3.0 M: Lighter medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Lacking the creaminess that most BIPAs seem to have. 

3.0 D: Average for a below average style.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-03-2012 07:04:20

Meaty, leathery aroma, with hints of mint and pine. Medium body with dense, even carbonation; a very satisfying mouthfeel. Dark treacle and roasted malts leaf the assault that is followed up by masses of bitter, aggressive hops; pine, leather, some ash. The finish is massive and enduring, an exceptional black ipa.

Pours a dark brown with a slight brown head.  The aroma is very grassy and the taste begins very smooth but soon has a bite and bitterness with slight licorice and grassy hop notes.  A bit thinner than expected for such a dark IPA and the alcohol shows it presence late.  An enjoyable and smooth offering with nothing dominating but flavors melding well.

Bottle, shared with BBGTC. The No. 1 Black IPA in the world? Im admittedly excited about this Stone creation. :-) Pours a near-black brown body with a medium creamy off-white head. Aroma is grassy hops, pine, coffee and hints of dark chocolate and dates. Taste is bitter grassy hops, resin, hints of coffee, tar and apricot. Medium creamy mouthfeel. A very nice BIPA, but the best? Not completely sold on that one, Im afraid.
Bottle. Dark brown to black, tan foam head. Berry, dark fruit, sweet aroma. Oily, grassy bitterness, roast finish.

0.65l bottle from myBrewerytap. I really like the these bombers from Stone. Much for the design on the bottle, and the long and always interesting text written on them, but mostly for the content. This one pours a deep dark dark brown body with a massive almost fluffy everlasting chocolate head. Lovely hoppy on the aroma, but also subtle roasted tones with chocolate, licorice, espresso powder and a hint of mint (hehe). Surprisingly low on the carbonation this. Almost flat, but I think that suits the somewhat thick and oily texture. Oh, yeah. Its a India Black Ale alright; Tons of grassy hops blended with chocolaty malts, licorice and hints of cold coffee. Reminds me a bit of mineral water - like so many IBAs often do. Ends with a hint of bitter-burned coffee beans that goes and for ever and ever. A quite delicious one that just got better and better, and Im not even a fan of the genre. 27.02.2012
light sweetness, medium bitterness, full body, soft carbonation, oily feel,

Pours dark as night, with a thick brown head. Good Lacing. Burnt hops with a solid malt backbone. Citrus Notes. The roasted malt give the front a very fruity taste. Great big hop taste comes later.  Full bodied and creamy

Bomber from Finger Lakes Beverage, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. 
App.:  Deep brown-black with a large light mocha head.
  
Aroma:  Lots of citrusy C-hops, sweet and mashy like an American DIPA, boozy and vinous, fruity  berries and dark dried fruits, some pine and floral notes, a bit resinous, inky, thick molasses, rich, malty, boozy and hoppy.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body, moderately full effervescence with some prickly bubbles.
  
Flav.:  Huge, American DIPA character, all the big, boozy, mashy malts and in-your-face hopiness, dark dried fruits, caramel/brown sugar, C-hops, resin, pine, some inky, rich, sticky molasses,darker malts as it warms and as I get more used to it, starting to seem like Impy Stout meets DIPA; dry with good bitterness and a long, hoppy, lovely, malt finish.

Wow.  Huge.  Righteously sublime.  For itself.

Bomber @ home. Black color, mocha colored head, good lace. Aromas: resin, laurel/bay leaves, roast, coffee, some sweet malt, all strong, but somehow nicely balanced. Flavor is medium sweet and medium bitter, herbal, somewhat acidic. Medium bodied. Finishes roasted, coffee-ish and rather bitter. Very nice!
Dark dark brown. Roasty malt and resin. Great taste nice bitter bitter finish l, pretty dry. Probably the best of this style I tried.

Bomber. Surprising floral and citrus aroma w/ a bit of rotten plums. Hits the nose hard. Dark brown, nearly black. Slightly rocky tan head. Interesting balance, but hops predominate among coffee and roast. Medium body, w/ lively, tingling carbonation. Long astringent, somewhat metallic, finish. Very tasty. Fresh and rich.

Bottle. Pours a deep brown color with a nice off white head with good lacing. Aroma is chocolate, roasted malt, vanilla, and piney hops. Taste is roasted malt, hops, oak, chocolate, and dark fruit. Nice creamy mouthfeel.

This was really very good.  On a day of big beers this cut through and made a mark.  A style that seems to hit the mark for me, bold from start to finish with dark fruit but crisp and clean. Brought down a tick (for me) only by that lingering, slightly woody house character finish.

roasty, hay, nuts, floral, alcohol, skunky, vanilla.

Sort-of a cold vanilla smoke-and-flowers smell.  The aroma is fantastic.  

Taste is "sublime", though very strong alcohol.  Id like it better with a little less alcohol flavor.  Fans of barley wine will likely be happy.  I dont much care for the aftertaste.  Would be fantastic paired with a strong cheese, maybe blu cheese on a pizza?!

22 oz bottle.  A mahogany beer that lets only a little light through around the edges feature very long hasting head and decent lacing.  The smell is very full and rich with spiced apple grapefruit dominated but well rounded hop bouquet.  Theres a strong cookie malt and a little grass to ad further dimension.  A little sweetness in the soft foamy mouthfeel quickly is taken over by a wallop of dark roasted grain and pine bitterness that tries to dry it out by the end.  I cant believe I forgot how good this beer was. May fresh bottles always be on a nearby shelf.

22oz bottle split with Paul on 2.22.2012. Pours deep brown/mahogany with a tan head into goblet. Potent aroma of chocolate and malts. Tastes similar to the Arrogant Bastard imo. Notes of wood, chocolate and dark fruit; overall very balanced with a medium to heavy mouthfeel and a really refreshing start/finish. Some roast quality, but overall I did not really see it as a BIPA.

From notes.  First reviewed 5/9/2010.  Poured from a 22 oz. bottle into a pint glass. 

This pours a dark mahogany with a cherry tint, with a rocky light brown head. A thin film cap remains the entire time, with some sticky lace as well.

Typical Stone punch-in-the-nose strength. Strong grapefruit hops, with a distinct pine notes as well. 

Taste: A little bit unbalanced for me. I always expect monster hops with Stone brews, but a little more balance would do this one good. It starts off bitter, but black malt, roast coffee, and dark fruit have a subtle presence, before a citrus hop bite sinks in. A bitter pine finish. 

Creamy, medium carbonation wrapped in a nice full body. Alcohol is not present in the taste, but warms on the way down. 

The feel of this beer is great and helps make it evaporate, but this is a bit hop-heavy and does not really have any distinguishing characteristics over Arrogant Bastard or other strong ales for me.

Been looking for this ale for sometime after seeing it on their site. First reaction was that it had a great head on the beer. After tasting it was really strong with the taste. Heavy on the hops and even deeper in complexity. Obviously not something I would drink to much without a steak or dinner. This is to me is a meal beer. Something on its own would really be to powerful for the average drinker thats used to lighter beers.

1 Pt. 6 Fl. Oz. bottle purchased from Ale Yeah! in Decatur, Georgia. 

Ar - Immediately bombards you with a nose full of citrusy-piney hops. This is followed by a brilliant sweet, malty caramel and chocolate smell. For me, after a while the chocolate smell really starts to come through. 
Ap - Exactly what I would want a Black IPA or, as I prefer, Cascadian Dark Ale to look like. Thick and dark and when you hold it up to the light, an orange-red hue shines through the darkness. Poured a nice sandy tan head that dissipates to a thin covering. 
T - Amazing. Starts out with that great piney-citrus hop combo then gives way to the sweet chocolate notes and then finishes with some awesome hop bitterness and slight alcohol burn that balances out the beer. 
P - The palate is perfect on this for me. It has a thick smoothness with just the right amount of carbonation to make it not feel like sludge running through your mouth. 
O - Overall a home run for me. One of the best beers I have had so far and the best Black IPA (that I have had). It is everything I want from this style. The hops and the malts pair nicely with each other and are melded together with the perfect amount of carbonation to make this a fantastic beer.
Draft. Pours black with a small tan head. Smells very roasty with some hop notes. Taste is medium bitter with a strong finish. Awesome.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2013 On tap at HopCat, Grand Rapids, MI.  Clear and black with a nice head.  Licorice and sherry aroma, very interesting.  Taste is alcohol, licorice, and roasty with a bite at the end.  Like an extra bitter Imperial Stout with some sherry mixed in.  I like it.

Deep mahogany brown color, crystal clear, with a beautiful tan two-finger head. Nose is crazy, deep prunes, raisins, sweet fruit, alcohol spice, and molasses. Taste is equally fantastic. Tons of roasted malt throughout, alcohol spice, and strong drying hops
Black pour with medium sized tan head. Aroma of pine and roasted malts. Taste is grapefruit, rasted malt, pine needles. Nice carbonation. Doesnt do much for me,
draft. seriously this might be my favorite beer. love black ipas and this is as good as it gets thus far for me.
Smells very hoppy.  Looks gorgeous.  Dark color with a cream head.  Tastes like an IPA mixed with coffee. LIngers in the back of the throat.  Overall, not too bad.

650ml bottle. Pours a thick black colour with a fluffy light beige head of foam. Lots of hops in the aroma with piney resinous notes bursting forth. The flavour is pretty full on and smooth and creamy in the mouth. Another great beer from Stone Brewing.

I really enjoyed this beer.  Always thought Stone IPA is good but not great.  This is really good, piny hops deliciousness.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft Black color. Tab one finger head. Great citrus aroma. Almost imperial like hoppy. Actually has a funny aftertaste. No need to try again. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

[660ml bottle shared with Simon at the Bootlegger, High Wycombe] Black with a moderate beige head and a light fizz.  Dominated by piney hops that verge at times on loo cleaner.  Theres a citrus hint in there too, but really its all about the pine.  The dark malts add surprisingly little other than a hint of coffee and a rich toffee mouthfeel - theres none of the roasted/burnt flavour youd normally associate with them.  The alcohol was rather too evident in a finish that was sweeter than I expected, although still with some dryness to it.  For me, the pine in this beer was a bit over the top, and it lacked balance as a result; however, after a poor start it grew on me and I was quite enjoying it by the end. Definitely a sipping beer though.

Pours pitch black with a nice tan head. Aroma is all hops, but I have had a few other batches (that probably werent as fresh) that smelled a little roaster. Taste is incredibly smooth for how aggressive this beer is with chocolate notes mixing with the dank, piney, grapefruity blend of hops used. Nice citrusy finish. Amazing beer, but I slightly prefer the hop profile of the similar Stone 15th anniversary imperial black IPA.

A very goddamn good beer in a style I outright loathe.  Nose hints at tobacco leaves and some dankness with a bit of cocoa. Taste follows logically, not too sweet and a lingering resinous hop finish.  One of my favorite cascadian/BIPAs and almost always a solid purchasing decision.
Floral aroma with molasses undertone.   Smooth initial flavor switches quickly to a kick in the mouth by a pine tree (fortunately not a real tree).  Pretty good.

Bomber to glass mug.  Pours an opaque very dark ruby color.  Doesnt look like theres any particles.  Initial scent is of evergreen & celery.  Sweet and smoky malts with enough citrus / piney hop flavors mixed in.  8.7% masked extrememly well.  Great mouthfeel.  Thick and creamy.  Fuggin awesome.

Tap. Pours deep, dark brown with thin, light beige head; decent retention and spare lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, dark fruit, earthy hops, and light molasses. Flavor is heavy malt, average hops, and average esters. Full body with medium carbonation and warmth.

jet black with tan head, aroma is pine hops up front with caramel roasted malt, taste is pine citrus hops, rich roasted malt, not extremely drinkable one bomber in plenty but one of the best CDAs ive had
Pours dark brown black. Aromas of roasted caramel & malt. Very mouthfilling, rich roasted malt and smoke. Good, but very, very thick and rich. Difficult to drink a pint of.

Pours a dark browm almost black with a light brown medium head.  Aroma is mostly hops with a little dark roasted malt, almost slightly burnt.  Initial flavors are that of a smoothed out ruination.  Very smooth and easy to drink for the style.  Your mind tricks you into thinking it will be malty and roasty, but the reality of it is just a balance to the ridiculous amounts of hops that stone likes to use.  The finish is dry and creamy at the same time.  What makes this beer so good is the drinkablity.  I could pound a bomber and look for more.  The fresher the better with this beer.  A dark beer that is right at home on the john deer in the middle of summer or as a warmer on a winter ski trip.

Picked this up at State Line Liquors in Elkton, MD. Paid just under $7 for it. No bottle date. Poured into a Tulip at 40 Degrees F and let sit for a few minutes to breathe.

A - Poured a gorgeous nut-brown to black colo with some amber tones. Very roasty looking with a 1 finger head with tiny bubbles with color that matches the beer.

S - TONS of hops and citrus in the smell of this beer. Im getting Orange and grapefruit and lots of dry hops that lead to a piney smell. Theres a tad bit of raisin coming through!

T - Citrus and hops is all Im getting. Theres a ton of fruit in here with some incredible hoppiness of a Double IPA. ts an extremely soft beer and so easy to drink!

M - This beer tingles the taste buds and is extremely smooth! The hop character isnt overwhelming but still best for sipping. 

O - Id love to have this beer again. Completely perfect and Im betting it would be magnificent fresh.

Pours dark, dark brown - almost black with a thick tan head. This beer looks fantastic. Aroma is of roasted malts, chocolate, and citrus hops. Taste to match the aroma. Full bodied with a smooth finish. Overall, excellent.

Probably one of my favorite beers from stone, i had the double bastard this year, and i would say similar, but this one just seems to have a better mouthfeel, poured out of a bottle, into a snifter, very dark in color, but the aroma is what gets you, mouthfeel is very smooth and very nice.

Pours a dark dark brown with a 1/2 finger. Aroma is a dark hop kind if aroma, if that is a thing. Taste is very balanced. Just a great black IPA. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: JAN 27, 2012 Bottle into s tulip glass, black with a small head. Taste of hops, malt, coffee, chocolate, and roasty smoke. Very good good ale stone is a great company.

A well designed bottle.  The aroma is pine with a hint of citrus.  An appealing dark color with a thin tan head when poured.  Nice lacing.  The taste is resin and a hint of toffee that quickly is over-powered by a strong pine after-taste.  The after-taste is so overpowering and lingering that it was largely the cause of a lower rating.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
650 ml. bottle.  Pours almost black with a small tan head.  Aroma of hops and citrus.  Taste is pine, citrus, some chocolate, and some roasted malt.  Delicious.

Pours a nice black with a nice tan head and some lace.  Aroma is of citrus, citrus hops, notes of orange, rosated malts, resin and wood.  West coast hops, orange, roasted malts, some carbonation and a little alcohol bite.
bottle pours black with a thin tan head.  Aroma is dank hops and piney citrus.  Flavor is chocolate covered hop cones haha.

Keg at Brewdog Camden. Dark brown almost black colour with small creamy beige gold head. Aroma is pine hops, oats, bit of smoke, roasted coffee and malt and a bit of chocolate. Taste is roasty, not as much bitterness as I expected, just a touch at the end. Quite creamy, bit of vanilla in there. Creaminess almost covers the booze, but you can taste it still. Subtle bitter finish.
Black ipa, apparently. Aroma is stone ipa   but black ipa  anywwya   this beer rocks, of course.

The word of moment OVERRATED!.  This one really needs hop flavor and aroma.  All I get is an extreme unpleasant bitterness and roasty ash like finish.  Dry and lingering bitterness.  The aroma has some hop presence and isnt bad but the taste is too harsh.

pours very dark with quite a bit of creamy head.aroma is very floral with an obvious hint of grapfruit and pine.heavily carbonated.i drink ipas only on occasion and got to say the hops on this is very balanced.flavour of grapefruit and pine with a subtle sweetness.bitter with a pleasant dry finish.i would add this to the ipas ive enjoyed.

650ml bottle. Pours opaque black with a generous frothy head - like a frothy cola in appearance. The nose has a hint of nuts and chocolate initially, then this is completely washed away with pine and grapefruit pith. The taste is again in two phases starting with the creamy chocolate (more obvious than on the nose) and then the pine zing again. The palate is multi-dimensional as described in the two phases above - rich texture and full bodied with a dry finish. The alcohol is also dangerously well hidden. Overall, this is great though it engages my brain more than it does my tastebuds. Basically, the bitterness at the end is a little too extreme for me, though I appreciate what a complex beast this is.

22 Ounce Bottle at home, 7th January 2012.   Poured dark mahogany black, reasonable head, with good lacing. Aroma is coffee alcohol some hops. Taste is fruit, hops and you can taste the alcohol, all the same this drinks well.  Agree with comment further down, all the Kernel Black IPAs are superior to this, the reason they do not score quite as high,( 84 -99) as this is due to accessibility and limited production, for which I am lucky enough to have here in London !

Pours black as night with a diminishing tan head which leaves lacing. Grassy, complex aroma. Notes of burnt toast and slightly citrusy hops. Full bodied with good carbonation. Finishes dry and bitter.

[bottle]
Very piney hops aroma with a very faint malt character. Almost opaque clear garnet-black under a tan ring and dots. Flavour begins with a blast of pine and grapefruit peel hops and then develops into a smooth, gentle roasted barley vanilla. Slightly salty. Light to medium body, moderate carbonation, slightly bitter finish.

Based on its status as top ranked black IPA on here Id been looking forward to trying this out. An extremely pleasant beer but lacking the hop attack I like in my preferred black IPAs. Not much on the nose but reassuring malty sweetness. Overall Id rate any of the three Kernel black IPAs released so far ahead of this brew. None of those are in the top 50 though, go figure!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
user_location: The big bad LDN, Greater London, ENGLAND

text: Super dark color.  Nice head on this with lots of lacing.  Aroma is very much hops with a little urine mixed in.  A little thin in mouth.  Taste is very bitter, but for a hop head, I love this.  This is very tasty.  Super easy to drink.  Self-Righteous indeed.

Pors a dark brown with a cnice tan head and aroma of hops and grapefruit. Great flavor in this brew, taste is very hoppy along with tastes of grapefruit, toasted malts, and pine with a heavy and long bitter finish. Great brew from Stone.

Pours black as night . Small creamy chocolate head. Aroma is sensational, hoppy and like a fresh cut grapefruit. Taste is majestic with hops and bitterness bursting on the palate , bitterness mellows and than the citrus predominates. The body is heavy and finish medium to long. Great IPA but the brewers at Stone knew this already. Cheers !

Yeah, this was good. This is the first black IPA Ive had that met my apparently outrageous standards, or I guess what I thought the style should be. Very very dark, only a little brown on the edges. Nose is big hops, dank, west coast. Taste is supremely bitter, but yet theres a nice little malt sweetness in there. Palate is really smooth, luxurious, complex. Awesome I finally found a fresh one in my area. It reminded me of Oracle, but darker. Thats what Im talking about.

Pours brown-black with a fluffy off-white head. Aroma is creamy, dark fruits, alcohol and vanilla. Flavor is big; alcohol and dark fruit dominate ; not as bitter as Im used to from Stone. Some cocoa and coffee as well; roasty and some herbalness. Smooth and delicious.

Bortled. Thx to my Secret Santa for this. Dark Brown coloured with red gleam. Aroma of roast, grass, herbs, cocoa, spice, chocolate and spice.  Spice, roast herbs, grass, flowers, chocolatl in the flavour. Medium to full bodied. Ends on a roasted and herbal bitterness. Nice.
Great beer.  Aroma is amazing, smells of crisp clean hops.  Taste of cleans hops and slight malty sweetness.
Bottle. Sold beer pours a dark red/brown color with nice head. Has lots of hops,bit of roast taste and smell good over all.
Bottle. Dark brown with big mocha head. Very nice aroma of piney hops (and pencil shavings?). Lightly roasty nice dryness. Clean palate. Yum!

22 oz bomber pours a dark black color with a nice off white head.  Aromas of citrus, grapefruit, pine, and some roasted malt in the background.  Full bodied, with chocolate and malt coming out, with a nice bitter finish. Outstanding.

Pours a deep ruby tinted brown color with a nice off white head that leaves nice lace on the glass. 

The aroma is catty and has a good grapefruit and citrus rind aroma. Generally this just smells of pungent hops, awesome. 

The flavor has a lot of bright fruity hop expression, and the beer is very bitter while holding off on much astringency. There is a light roastiness to it but only very light. The beer is punchy and dry and delicious. 

Been in the mood for this kind of hoppy beer lately... heck Ive just been in the mood for hoppy beer generally for the last six months. Am I turning into some kind of hophead? Gracious.

Pours very dark brown to black, foamy khaki head. Fragrant, bold nose, with aromas of wet hops, blackberries, cinnamon, mint, wood. The body is above medium, perfect carbonation for the style. The flavor is a menagerie of roasted and smoky malt, grapefruit, piney hops, bitter black coffee. The finish is incredibly long and powerful, with slight acidity, huge West Coast hoppage, and a perfectly smooth palate. Certainly the benchmark for a hit or miss style.

Un bomber partagé avec Boul et Patrick. Bière noire avec une mousse beige. Le nez est tout en chocolat, ensuite, après avoir été impressionné par ces arômes, vienne les effluves de de houblon (pin). La bouche est puissante, avec du chocolat, une amertume longue ferme la marche. Les saveurs de cascade sont bien perceptible. Jaime !!!

Served from bottle

Aroma: The best I have ever experienced in a beer. Smells exactly like I opened a package of hops and stuck my nose in it. Perfect!

Appearance. Pours black with a thicker tan head that quickly dissipaters to a thin layer. Moderate lacing noted. 

Taste: Finally a Black IPA that suits me. Taste is firm hop bitterness equivalent to a DIPA. Tart grapefruit notes balance perfectly with a solid malt back bone. Very balanced. Would of liked just a tad less bitterness to appreciate the malt profile. 

Palate. Decent mouth feel with a strong finish. I get that smack you up side the hop head sensation even though I dont find this beer overly bitter. I think this is from the fantastic aroma gives the sensation there are more hops there. 

Overall I truly enjoyed this beer. It was simple but yet complex. I very much enjoyed the perfect hop aroma. It is very well balanced and finally showed me that a balanced Black IPA could exist.

Une tête mousseuse brune flotte sur un liquide à la robe noire.  Un nez solide de houblons fruités avec des pointes de résine sur une base maltée intelligemment rôtie et caramélisée.  Des saveurs qui se partagent entre des notes amères de torréfaction et des notes amères de houblons.  Une présence chocolatée, des grains de café, des fruits tropicaux, de la résine : un superbe tableau.  Une bouche superbement construite : un corps dense, un pétillement juste et contrôlé, une texture huileuse.  Une finale complexe et spectaculaire : la maîtrise et le savoir-faire de Stone.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2011 Very spicy in aroma, taking over all of the aroma.  In flavor the hops and malts are very balanced with a deep chocolate flavor to it.  Cant really say theres anything at all wrong with this, the very best in the style for sure.

I love black IPAs and this is one of my favorite.  The appearance of a dark thick beer opening up to a lighter, fruitier taste and aroma.  The grapefruitiness is tempered by the malts, but this is a beer defined by its excellent balance of hops. (7/1/2010)

Bomber into shaker . Notes from September.  Black in colour with a thick foamy head.  Smells really malty and hoppy.  Lots of citrus, lots of roasty malt.  Incredible example of the style.  Very drinkable at 8.7%

Bottle.  Black pour with a half inch tan head.  Aroma of grapefruit, sweet lemon, and other sweet aromas I cannot describe.  Taste is of sweet malts, a little black licorice and some coffee grounds.  Finish is bitter.  Medium to heavy body, and low carbonation.  Very good.

Picked up a bomber bottle at Henrys in San Diego, CA.  Tasted from a snifter.  Pours a very dark, dark brown with a frothy tan head.  Piny hop aroma and flavors.  Flavors also have a big fruit-and-herb character that offers a strong bitterness, but mellows into a coffee nuttiness.  Body is a little over medium.  This is very tasty, and a lot like the Stone 15th Anniversary Black IPA.  In fact, I suspect that the 15th Anniversary is probably a souped-up version of this beer.  Regardless, both are very tasty.

Old ratings. Pours black with a small bubbly brown head. Nose is roasted malts, orange, grapefruit and earthy hops. Flavor up front is sweeter roastiness, coffee then quickly going into the signature Stone strong hop character and bitter finish.
Pours black with a creamy light brown head.  Citrus aroma.  Big citrus and pine flavors.  Chocolate, orange, and toasted malt notes.  Medium body with a creamyouthfeel.  Medium to high carbonation.

Pours black with ruby highlights and a two finger frothy off-white head.  Aroma is a nice hop bouquet of resins, citrus, and pine and faint notes of dry roasted grains.  Taste is bitter throughout with a nice balance between hop bitterness and bitter black malts.  It finishes dry with a soft mouthfeel.  Overall, its everything that you want in this style.  Delicious beer.

Cerveza color café obscuro, casi negro, aroma intenso con notas de malta tostada y frutas tropicales (Por el alto contenido de Lúpulo, cabeza firme que se retiene hasta que terminas la cerveza, cuerpo completo, alto contenido de lúpulo, alto contenido alcohólico; en cuanto al sabor, es cremoso, maltoso, con notas de café y chocolate, pero a la vez tiene notas frutales por el Lúpulo, digamos que tiene el sabor que obtendrías de mesclar un Porter con una IPA.

Simplemente una de las mejores cervezas que he probado, Stone Brewery no deja de sorprenderme, toda su linea es altamente recomendable.

Bottle:
Small airy light brown head on top of a black colored beer.
Smell is very hoppy, with hints of citrus, resin, soap, pine, bit sharp.
Taste is hoppy, citrus, pine, strong bitter, hint of fruit, resin, light sharp, hint of liquorice, some slight hints of coffee and toasted/roasted malts and some spices.
Good firm bitter aftertaste with hops, herbs and some darker ingredients.
Medium carbo, soft tingly mouthfeel, full body and light watery texture.
Firm bitter with a hint of darker black ingredients.
Its good but it seems a bit too bitter, but thats good.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: This SSRA ale gives a punch to the tounge due to its 90 IBU rating. These guys are masters at mixing hop varieties and utilizing each varietys attributes. The first surprise is when you pour and think "Did I buy a stout by accident"!  The dark color arouses the curiosity then the hop aromas start enticing for a good mighty gulp.  Very roasty/hoppy mix of a palate. I dont know what they use as far as malt and dont care !Tthey are right ! I am not worthy  !!!  Beatiful, artful craft beer !!!!

Aroma is citrus, pine and roast. Appearance is black with a hint of red. Small tan head. Taste is pine and citrus hops. Some grape sourness, blueberry. Roast is present but just behind hop bitterness. Palate is medium full. Aroma hops, bittering hops and some roast linger. Overall a very nice beer. Many flavors all balanced nicely.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours opaque black with small dark brown bottom highlight with nice inch and a half head.  Some lacing, medium body, and good carbonation.  Taste is roasted malt and then long pine finish.  I like this better than most regular IPAs, still not a fan.

Pitch black color, tan head. Some lacing falls in slow-motion back into the glass, some stays in reaching patterns. Very light, but crisp carbonation. So, so bitter, it has an almost acidic texture to it. A roasty, resiny hops aroma beneath the intense bitterness.

Damn what a way to have fourth course BGBBD at sierra. I can still remember 11th coming out and everyone being like... this is no 10th. Well maybe it took the 12th being NOT an ipa for people to want this one back. So flavorful and smooth for its percentage and what hops! Black IPAs are rare but this one showed so much character that its a wonder why nobody else is picking up on this style.

Half pint at Brewdog Glasgow:
Dark hops upfront that are quickly followed by some mild malt notes and tropical fruit aroma that lingers on the nose. It is a rather fruity smelling dark IPA.

Black with a 2mm thick, tan head that stays the same throughout.

Some dark hops and malts, the hops being stronger. The same tropical fruit taste from the smell. There are hints of spice towards the end too.

Medium bodied & with minimum carbonation, the beer has a bit of a kick to it and has a dry finish that lingers in the after taste. The drink is smooth & good on the palate.

I found this one a nice introduction to the Black IPA style of beer and rather enjoyed this one although it didnt really blow me away in any respect but still a nice, solid dark IPA.
More @

Ill save the detailed analysis of flavors for others. Lots of hops, lots of roasted malt.  All I know is this beer makes my mouth happy, and I make sure I have a pint whenever I see it.  This has raised the bar on Black IPAs for me.

Nez très fleuri. Houblonné. Une petite touche litchi
Belle tenue de mousse. 
Arome resineux et peristant.  Lamertume maltée revient en fin de bouche. Leger arome fruité.  
Lalcool nest pas trop présent au gout.

Pours dark black/brown with a reasonable off-white head. Aroma is intense - hops, pine, citrus. Taste is almost overwhelmed by hops, with some notes of grapefruit, spruce. Long bitter and slightly dry finish with hints of fruit. Not really my thing but seems to be a good example of the style.

Sampled at SBWF. Stockholm, September 29th, 2011. 

Hoppy aroma with some grass, grapefruit (among many fruits), chocolate and roasted malt. Its a creamy rich and really smooth aroma. The taste is filled with coffee and fresh bitter and flowery hops. Rich and creamy just like the aroma suggested. This is how I like my black ales!

Bottle. Very dark pour, almost completely black, with red highlights and a lasting frothy tan head. Aroma is a little roasty and very hoppy with notes of pine, dark chocolate, grapefruit and mint. Flavour is roastier than the aroma and features more dark chocolate and espresso, but otherwise is very similar. Thick, creamy mouthfeel with moderate carbonation and a long bitter finish. This is a very good Black IPA; rich, strong and self-assured, yet very easy to drink.
Bomber @ "Dive Bar" Wexford, Pa.  Pours black with thick tan head, lots of sticky lacing.  Definite hop aroma and taste, full body...very smooth.

Poured from a draft into a pint glass. Color was dark black. Maybe an inch o head. Lots of lacing on the sides. Lots of film on the sides that stayed throughout.

Immediately smelled citrus and fruity hops. Pine and caramel in there as well, albeit weak.

Smooth, malty hops in the taste. Citrus is involved, but not as much as the smell. Bitter aftertaste.

Medium body. Lively to fizzy carbonation (above average). Smooth feeling.

Not a bad beer to end the night. Would definitely give it another chance.

Pours black with amber around the edges. Small off white head. Aroma is slightly roasty and grainy. This is some good stuff, very thick and malty, caramel, brown sugar, alcohol, and roast with a little more piney hop bite than you would expect. A very well balanced ale. Yum.

Bottle. Thats definitely a big boy. just after you look at the label  youll already be having an idea of what you are going through. once the cap is off, a strong flavor hits your nose. muscular aspect: solid black body with no mercy for the others colors, cappuccino big rocky head. The aroma has so many sides: hops (a lot of it), grass, resin, vegetables (mostly onion. not so fresh bottle?), roasted burnt malt, chocolate, coffee, toffee, dark fruits. With the taste comes the masterpiece: a damned perfectly brewed  BIPA. so, what im drinking, an ipa? a stout? none of them and both. anyway malt, chocolate, coffee, hops, dark fruits, resin a little bit vanilla. The body is massive, the oily mouth-fell sticks your tongue out; its not easy to finish it, but you cant stop drinking it, cause it damned good.
I had so many wannabe BIPA so far, but just few of them got the result. The Sublimely Self Righteous Ale just watch them and laughs ruling the style. As i wrote above, this wasnt a fresh bottle, so i didnt get all the citric, fresh fruit aroma that have been noticed in the other reviews probably. but the point is: this beer deserves a very high score when is not in a perfect shape. I can only image what could be my score for a fresh bottle...  stone: we are not talking about craft beer, thats the best, perfect way to brew beer
Awesome, smooth beer with a taste of big time hops at the beginning... One of my new favorite beers!
Bomber. One of the best India Dark Ales I have had, though I am still not a big fan of the style. Complex, rich and hoppy with a full body that is well balanced. A lasting bitter finish.

Dark plum with tan head. Nose of sweet dark fruits, a touch of smoke, some piney hop notes.  Medium body, good carbonation.  Some chocolate, dark fruits, a bit of booze, a little chalky. Pleasant musty fruity finish.

Pour black with great tan head good lace. Aroma pine, citrus, roast, chocolate, coffee, grapefruit, resiny hops. Taste roast, hint booze, grapefruit, citrus, pine, resiny hops. MF medium t full body nice carb. Really good brew however bottle couldve been fresher but still quite good.

Nice thick tan head that lingers...sounds kind of sexy..its been several minutes now and has not collapsed. Nice gunpowder  with chocolate and roasted nut aromas.  Lighter flavor than you would think by looking at the dark almost black color in the glass. Pour this in a glass and let your friends guess, but have them close their eyes....they will be surprised by what they see....definitely not a stout.

So black IPA?  When I first had this it was listed as an ASA, which I think might have affected my perception of the beer.  What I have in front of me now pours black.  Aroma is cocoa and roast with some pine and forest.  Flavor really highlights a nice chestnut, dry black chocolate, and roastiness at first.  As it settles and warms, I get more and more sap, so that it really is perceived as a Black IPA by the end.  Good, I wish I had tried it with the 15th anniversary ale in my left hand.  Unfortunately I cant compare them from memory as its already faded, but I suppose I could compare the reviews if need be.

Sample at SBWF 2011. Bottle. Clear, black liquid with brown edges and small-medium tan head. Aroma of grassy hops, citrus, floral hops, grapefruit, roasted malt, caramel, toffee and coffee. Taste us dry, roasty and highly bitter. Some floral, grassy hops as well. Medium bodied with nice carbonation. Almost a bit creamy mouthfeel. Wow, this ones great. Got a good balance that many BIPAs lack but still isnt boring and in a way quite aggressive. Really deserves being at the top of the list.

4/10/2011 on tap @ Rattle n Hum, NYC (2011-518)
Very dark brown cola-like beer, creamy small beige to brown head, pretty stable and adhesive. Aroma: fruity first impression, pineapple, hint of caramel, but just very faint. MF: good carbon, full body, bit creamy texture. Taste: fruity, citrus start, peaches, bit of cough syrup, sugar, some alcohol, turning to bitter. Aftertaste: mixture of fruity bitter hops, sour pineapple and a mocha to coffee touch in the end, which holds on for quite a long time.

Bottle. Black with a large tan head. Aroma of stone fruits and kumquats, some tropical notes and a hint of dark toffee thats probably my eyes telling me what I should be smelling. But theres some burnt toffee and a little chocolate in the taste giving a platform for the fruity hops. Slightly oily mouthfeel is the only real hint of its strength. Lingering bitterness has citrus and some herbs (including mint and ?menthol. Theres no subtle charm here, but its not overflavoured and its dissonant but not cacophonous.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2012 Bottle.
Pours dark brown, verging on black, with a firm beige head.
Very hoppy, rich aroma, lots of roasted malts, coffee, fruit, lightly smokey, spicy.
Off-dry, full bodied, high bitterness, balanced CO2.
The taste is very rich and hoppy, lots of spruce, grapefruit peel, roasted malt, chocolate, smoke, ashes, earth.
Among the most impressive black IPAs around. (2011-10-08, re-rated with slightly higher scores on 2012-10-20)
Pours dark brown, with a medium tan head. Aroma is hoppy, with floral hints. Taste is rich, complex, hoppy, and smooth. While Im not overly fond of hoppiness, this one is well worth it. Thumbs up.
Pours a dark, dark brown, with a thin fleeting head.  Aroma of hops, citrus, floral, malt, coffee, vanilla.  Taste is a great bittersweet, resiny hops comes through. Fantastic IPA.

22 oz bomber poured in pint glass:  burnt malt aroma, resin, chocolate, citrus; pitch black, with frothy brown head and good lacing;  very bitter, medium sourness, like pineapple and grapefruit with some syrup;  full body, creamy, sticky, soft carbonation, bitter, long finish, maybe the finest brew Ive had.

22oz bottle, as both XI (Vintage 2007) & Stone Sublimely Self Righteous Ale.   Black pour, heavy cream head.  Aroma of roast and alcohol.  Flavor contains loads of chocolate malt, sharp bitterness, earthy hops, pine bitterness, and a burnt roast finish.  Coffee flavors dominate the palate.  Full bodied, heavy and hearty.  Glad this offering is a regular item.  It truly is the Sublime & Self-Righteous brother of Arrogant Bastard!

65cl, as Sublimely Self-Righteous Ale, new American brew Anno 2009, from Geers Oostakker, complex bitter brew, malty/fruity and slightly sweet/roasted, not too heavy, very balanced, clear, rocky head, very good brew, yet expensive

Gelungene Mischung zwischen Hopfen und Malz, die den Antrunk gleichermaßen für sich beanspruchen. Rund, der Hopfen setzt sich nach und nach durch. Dabei ist das Schokoladenmalz noch im Hintergrund schmeckbar. 12/12/11/9//11

On bottle at Öl&Whiskymässan, Nacka Strand.
Poirs black with low head. Aromas are fully hopped with citrus and burned roasted malts. Great full bodied palate with a loooong bitter ending. This fully hopped Black IPA is really really good.

Draught @ Stone vs Moeder Lambic event in Brussels. Pure black colour with an off-white head. Smells hoppy, chocolate, coffee and roasty. Tastes hoppy, grapefruit, roasty.. lovely. Perfect carbo, full body.

Say hello to my little friend! This being my first Black IPA, Im thinking that the bar has been set high by the folks at Stone Brewery! While at the beer store the other day I needed something to round out the selection that I was purchasing and saw this one out of the corner of my eye. Last bottle, so off with me it went! When I first opened it up I knew I was in for a treat because the aromas were just, well, intoxicating! Definitely one of the finest smelling brews I have yet to enjoy!  Being a malt-head this brew is just the right choice; thick, rich, flavorful, awesome. This is one of those fine brews that should be paired up with a juicy porterhouse steak or a succulent rib-eye steak!

66 cl bottle, enjoy by 14.06.2011
Rather hoppy aroma with resin, some ripe fruits and coffee‐like roastiness. Flavour has also lots of resin and roastiness, and it has just the right sweetness like other Stone beers do. Also some coffee and ripe fruits. Reminds me of Nøgne Ø #100, which is a bit richer on flavour though. Very good BIPA, even when the BBE‐date has gone three months ago.

Quite thoroughly black with a bit puffy beige head that laces well. It has a really nice, crisp aroma of citrus, pine, roast and coffee. The taste is coffee IPA; malty and roasted with a substantial, but not overpowering, bitterness. The body is medium and smooth, the finish long and bitter. This is an excellent blend; extremely well done.

Draft @ Stone. Pours a dark brown, almost pitch black. Smell is highly hopped with slight smoke nose. Very well balanced ale. Hops are piney but play well with the dark flavors going on. Stone has this listed as an american strong, for what its worth.
