Draught at Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas during the three day Stone Event, 16-18 september 2011. Pitch black opaque color, white head. Smell hops, grassy, mint and fresh. Very nice fresh grassy taste with a lot of hops. Good carbo, medium to full body.

Bottle sample at Stone tasting at Beer Temple. Deep dark brown to black, off white head. Aroma of roasted malts, laurel, resin, hops. Flavour is of a typical Black IPA, roasted, pine, resin, laurel, very hoppy. Medium bodied. Its tasteful, but the flavours of this "style" just dont mix imo.
Tasting at beer temple.  Black pour with medium tan head.  Grapefruit, hop aroma.  Flavour is grassy hops, grapefruit and a little grapefruit.  Amazing!

@ beer tasting @ beer temple Amsterdam.
Thin off white head.  Deep amber pour. Lovely bitterness.  Yummy.

Aroma of moderate grapefruit and pine with chocolate and caramel malts. Appearance is black with light tan head. Flavor matches the nose; some additional roasty flavors and a light fruit finish. Palate is bubbly. My expectations were high, this was good, but I wasnt wowed. Just good.
Thin black with a hoppy nose. Roasted malts with a hint of bitter coffee. Lots of flavors going on.
Black in color, hops primarily on the nose. Hoppy flavor with roasted malt flavor. No hint at all of the alcohol.

650 ml bottle.
Pours a dark brown, almost black colour with a thick beige head. Aroma of fresh floral hops, licorice and some roasted malts. Flavour of excellent fresh floral hops, roasted malts, salty licorice, grapefruit and pineapple. Hops kick in after a while. Full bodied and a lovely oily mouthfeel with a lingering finish floral hops, licorice and sweet fruits. This is an awesome Black IPA.

Completely awesome - the standard by which all other black ipas should be judged. Incredible on the nose, tastes like no other beer. The first time I had this, I went straight home and slept for 4 hours such was its power...

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Point.

Appearance: Near black with thick foamy tan head and nice lacing rings.

Aroma: Very hoppy and roasted aroma. Pine, citrus and molasses are at the forefront. Somewhat floral as well, like roses.

Taste: Roasted malt backbone with molasses and coffee. Complex, bitter hops override the malts, especially on the finish with loads of pine and grapefruit. Doesnt mesh quite as well as I hoped.

Palate: Moderate carbonation, pretty smooth body with a dry, warming finish.

Overall: This is a style that I really like when it strikes the proper balance between roasted malts and citrusy hops. This one just misses that balance, but is very good nevertheless.

65 cl bottle @ Euston Tap, London.
Rated on 20110721.
Pours dark hazy red colour with small off-white head. Aroma is licorice, dark roasted malts, orange peel, mandarin, mango, caramel and distant notes of toffee at the end. Flavour of licorice, roasted malts, orange, mandarin, caramel and a bit of vanilla. I have to admit my expectations on this one were quite high, sadly there werent anything that would have separated this from other good black IPAs, but definitely one of the best Ive had. Sort of like a mix of Nøgne Ø #100 and #500.
5516

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2013 Pours a medium brown with a foamy tan head.  Smells floral, citrus, roasted nuts, a bit like herbs.  Taste is bitter and sweet, dark chocolate, citrus hops, hints of spruce and licorice.

taster at trinity brewery in Colorado Springs.  Looks rather black but brownish red in the light.  Good soapy light brown head.  Smells of toasty hops and bitter complexity.  Tastes very clean, with dark bitterness that is "gwarming".  Love this beer.  overall 9.5 of 10.

Totally black with a small tan head, not much in the way of lacing.  The aroma is great, very fruity and lots of bubblegum, really good.  The flavor is overly bitter, but has some nice pine and roasted malt flavor filling it out.  Definitely one to visit again.

Tan head, some lacing and dark black colour. Aromas are all classic stone brewing with leafy hops dominating the aroma. I also get potatoe chips (higher alcohol note for me), not much in malts..giving the style and super fresh and big. The palate is big hoppy notes big IPA character with some burnt charcoal. They do make a great IPA but lacks real complexity.

650ml bottle. Nearly black pour with a mocha head. Huge citrusy/sprucy hops on the nose with a licorice edge. Theres almost no detectable maltiness at all. Surprise, surprise. More of the same on the palate. The licorice notes play a much bigger role. Ballsy with almost no malt presence besides a deep coffee note in the finish.

Tap at the Blind Tiger, NYC. Pours rich black with a creamy, dense tan head. Big dirty hop character. Good roast and dirt in the nose, some aggressive citrus and pine. Flavor is medium sweet, plenty of roasted malts, earthy, dirty and resiny bitterness. Full bodied with average carbonation. Finish is sticky, more dirt and pine, lingering earth and burnt wood. Excellent beer.

A: Dark brown body with a darker off white head that approaches a soft sand-khaki. Spotty lacing remains as the head slowly subsided.

S: Roasted malt, chocolate, pine, fresh grass, and bark.

T: I am really not sure what the appeal is with these "black IPAs." The nose hinted at a harmonious marriage of darker roasted, toasted, and earthy malts with earthy, resinous, pine hops. Unfortunately, the flavor doesnt really come together as well. The malts used here added a bit too much sweetness and contrasted a bit harshly with the hops which sliced their way forward, but with a bit inconsistency.

When dealing with IPAs/dIPAs I like to think of malt as a canvas and the hops as paint. A quality canvas is necessary for the paint to adhere to, standout from, and leave a lasting impression. That said, the malts dont need to be bland, boring and hidden. But the canvas cant be full of ridges and valleys that alternately shed and pool the paint. Here the malt did just that, spiking out at times with too much malt, and at times just assaulting with bitter hops.

All said, it wasnt unpleasant. Just a tad frustrating with what "could" have been done here.

M: Medium bodied. Prickly carbonation. A bit of excess sweetness in the finish that could have been more crisp and defined.

D: A good, style-bending beer. Not sure if the experiment works for me in the long run though.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2011 From the bottle and from a growler. Poured almost black. Smells of roasted malt and smoke. Taste has lots going on, from malt up front to fruits in the background to lingering hops.

just when you think stone cant make another amazing world class beer, well i shouldnt be thinking that because they just keep getting better, beer gods in my opinion, but enough praising. pours black slightly see through when put in front of light. smells of pine, orange peels, and hops with a slight roasty chocolate. taste is similar, hops, orange peels and pine up front, leading into a strong malt back bone paired with a bitter sweet dark chocolate with slight roastyness, finishes slightly sour and dry. hats off again to stone. cant wait to try the 15th annivers. imperial Black IPA.
Bottle.  Lemon, peach and pine hops aroma.  Murky brown color with large tan head.  Sweet chocolate malt and moderately bitter pine hops flavor.  Damn tasty.

Tap @ 775. Black, tan head forms a ring, good lace. Big, hoppy aroma, some dark fruits / roasted malt. Robust carbonation and a fairly dry finish. Medium body. Lightly sweet up front, caramel, not much roast, big hoppy finish towards pine and harshness. Tasty.
UPDATED: MAY 25, 2012 So incredibly delicious. in every way.  Too great to describe. Just get some.
1/2 at the Brewdog pub. TIDY. Thick and earthy. Jammed with hops. I could never tire of gear like this. One of th finest beers Ive had.

Pours dark brown decent beige head. Smells oily with some pine a little smoke and roasted malt. Floral hops turn to pine turn to citrus, this is a great IPA. Some bouquet like florals with a light pine and grapefruit, very easy drinking for alc. Lingering roasted malts battle with a smooth green pine with no bite, and a little flowery. This should be a standard of Black IPAs.
Bottle at Brew Haven festival. Grapefruit / pine hops and sweetish caramel malt aroma. Black brown with a moderate tan head. Nicely balanced sweet caramel malt and resinous hop flavor. Medium body.

On keg at the Brewdog bar. A black beer with a fair tan head. Nice resinous hop aroma with piney notes. Toffee is also quite prominent on the nose with coffee, caramel and some malt. Sweet, malty flavours with coffee and caramel again and tropical fruits. Moderate carbonation with a light CO2 prickle. Lingering chocolate and dark malt flavours. Nice.

Pours jet black with big lingering foam cap head.  Aroma is nearly all hops with floral / vegetal undertones. Flavor is fairly 2D (hops, hops, and some burnt rubber). Finish is more hops with a little grapefruit acidity. Im perplexed by the high scores of this beer, for its just as unsophisticated as a BMC, except where they overload corn - here its hops.

22oz bottle. Poures dark brown with a nice light brown head. Aroma is very complex: a lot of citrus and grapefruit, also some toffee, pine and melon. Well balanced between the citrus/pine finish and the darker roasted elements. Sublime.

Pours jet black with 1 finger tan head and incredible retention.  Aroma is rich molasses, resin, cocoa, espresso, citrus, truly incredible.  Taste is bitter roasted malt, resin, then pine and grapefruit on the finish.  Body is medium-full, creamy with avg carb, dry finish.  Overall, super awesome Black IPA, great example of the style but I still prefer Beer Heres Dark Hops.

Dark ruby brown, with a khaki head. Aroma of the good ol Stone hop character...floral, citrusy, a little resinous, and a whole lot bitter. And slightly grassy as well. Aroma finishes out with some simple black malts. Taste was just too dang bitter. Like, chemically bitter. Dark grain malt and black malt, and roastiness apparent in flavor as well, but it is overwhelmed by hop bitterness, and didnt jive well anyway.  Couldnt finish mine.

22 oz. bottle, consumed on 7-30-11. Very nice, strong, appetizing aroma features plum, chocolate, and blueberry muffin scents along with a mouth-watering hoppy dryness. Pours dark brown with a moderate amount of short-lasting beige/taupe head. Flavor features coffee, dark chocolate, and carob elements. Dry, dirt/mocha/chalk finish. Sawdust and wood in the aftertaste. Medium to slightly heavy body. Oily in the palate. Stone Sublimely Self Righteous Ale is quite good and enjoyable.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2013 Yet another favorite from Stone. Pours dark brown, almost black, with big tan head. Lots of lacing. Aroma is dominated by the hops: pine, grapefruit, citric tones. Still not as floral as a pure IPA and the malt definitely comes through with some roasted tones and caramel. Taste is much the same, dominated by a rich and refreshing bitterness from the hops, yet with a subtle underlying touch of roasted malt, caramel and maybe a hint of cocoa. Mouthfeel is excellent, just the right level of carbonation and a rich, creamy body.

Bottle from Stirchley Wines, Birmingham. Pours with a nice thick head. Smells like a subtle beast. Mouthfeel = crunchy rather than smooth, with brickdust, coffee grounds and powdered steel. Great, ripping hop taste and very dry roastish finish. Obviously excellent.

22oz bottle. Pitch black color, tan head. Some lacing falls in slow-motion back into the glass, some stays in reaching patterns. Very light, but crisp carbonation. So, so bitter, it has an almost acidic texture to it. A roasty, resiny hops aroma beneath the intense bitterness.

Interesting brew. Loads of pine and grapefruit in the nose, as expected with a good IPA. Also, there is a bit of roasted malt, caramel and chocolate in the nose. Definitely in the background compared to the hops, though. Looks like a stout or porter; very dark with a tan head and viscous lacing. Tastes is mainly hops (grapefruit and pine) with some roast and caramel malt in the distance, like the smell. Quite superbly done.
Black color.  Mild roasted malt aroma.  Flavor is very well hopped with a dry, herbal hop finish.

From notes: poured opaque black with a deep tan/mocha-colored head-resembles a stout or porter (as others have noted).  Aroma was pretty much all hops, mixing grapefruit and pine notes.  Medium to slightly thick body with a nice depth to it.  Citrusy hoppy taste up front that gives way to nutty and chocolatey notes in the finish.  These become more pronounced as it warms.  Worth finding.

Very dark brown with strong tan head.  Interesting aroma of pine and grapefruit-like hops conflicting with toasty malt.  Full body, alcohol is sort of noticable but not overwhelming.  Kind of a smoky malt flavor, minimal sweetness, ends with nice dry bitter citrus hops.  Pretty unique.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2012 Bottle pour ---> Goblet. Rich smooth black pour with a nice silky head. Aromas were pungent of pine, hops, grapefruit (ZEST) and some spices. Id say it smelled like a fresh Christmas tree. The flavor was intense of hops, both bitter AND roasty that gave it a sour twang to it, awaking the tastebuds. The alcohol wasnt well hidden, and that helped the roasted malts provide a robust deep sweet spiciness. Unlike anything Ive drank or smelled - and a beer that has to be tried at least once.

22 oz bottle from Binnys (Bolingbrook, IL). Finally grabbed this. Just never committed since its always around. Pours a pretty blackish hue with dark suntea brown bottom and edges. Not opaque, letting a brownish glow come through the bottom and edges well. A decent sized lighter brown frothy head stays as a decent layer, laces ok overall. Aromas are a prominent citrusy hopping. Grapefruit meets roasted malts, some toffee, cocoa. A light coffee appeal with more lemons and fresh green hops. Dry florals. Really nice, as the sweetness makes an appearance and the roast doesnt become overbearing. Initial is medium bodied offering that telltale clash of bitter green hops, lots of grapefruit and citrus mixing with roasted malts, dry florals, and dry roasty coffee. Touches of cocoa as the middle sweetens things up a bit more, caramel and toffee, sweet and sticky with cocoa lingering on. Drys up more and remains roasty in the finish, though I feel the hops take control over the roast, which I rather enjoy. A lot of people dont really get this style or like it.. but I think this is a great beer, great example of the style offering a healthy hopping that hangs on for the ride and doesnt let the roast or toast overtake it. Its about the hops, not the roast and coffee, cocoa and sweetness. Well done.

Keg at The Brewdog Bar, Edinburgh. Black with cream head. This is certainly an interesting beer, initially lots of liquorice and aniseed notes, charcoal, then a fruity, lemony hop to top it off, my wife said a Catherine Wheel of flavours. It finishes with a long bitter dryness whilst still giving off a fragrant hop. Plenty happening and mostly very good.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2014 It does pour like a porter, espresso black but not crude oilthick like a stout, and develops a decent head that accurately hints at the level of carbonation that will come once you sip the stuff. The aroma is rich of piney hops but also sweeter, fruitier ones, yielding notes of pine needles as well as peach, mango, and citrus. Theres also the roasted character, with burnt sugar, some caramel, hints of coffee, and a touch of dark chocolate. The taste follows, with lots of bitterness balanced out by a nice sweet character. Its really powerful. The hops handily overpower the roasted malts. The body is not thin but not thick, either, with soft carbonation that gives it a creamy palate feel. Also, I could not find a trace of alcohol in the aroma or in the taste. Quite an achievement for a 8.7% abv beer.
no sabia que esta birria era tan famosa pero que bueno que la encontre.  la semana siguiente mas

Pitch black ale, with thick and creamy head that lasts a long time.  The hops smell super fresh, doesnt seem like this one sat on the shelf too long.  Taste has plenty of the citrus, pine going on with a slight bit of honey.  This is one badass ale.  And I mean that in an uncompromising way.  For serious hopheads only.  Only slight malt backbone, provided by the coloring.  This is a supercharged IPA not to be messed with.  Finishes very bitter and chewy.  Undeniably the most narcissistic ale on the market.  Weakness:  Wouldnt have hated more roasted barley notes.  Enjoyability: 5/5.

bottled. pours black with a moderate light tan head. aromas of  mango, oak and roasted malt. it has a good amount of bitterness. medium bodied, lively and slick in the mouth. it finishes with astringency. pretty decent beer.

dark brown color, tan head. aroma is completely dominated by a bitterness that i have a hard time describing. also just a hint of alcohol. flavor is nicely bitter with strong notes of raisin. very long, dry, and bitter finish. I also pick up hints of dark chocolate. im sad to say that this beer just didnt work for me.

650ml bottle.  Pours black with a large head.  Aroma is piney hops, mango and a little bit of roast.  Taste has mango to start.  Piney hop, strong bitter finish with a little roast coffee on the aftertaste.  Very full in the mouth.
Pours very dark brown almost black with beige head. Some malt on the nose mixed with pine and citrus hops. Taste is well balanced, licorice notes with pine, grass and citrus fruits. Delicious

Bottle looks strange, but good. Beer in the glass very dark, almost black. Nice head. Malty-dry aroma. Starts strong malty, gets drier and drier, fine roasty-malty, bitter background. Finish well balanced, dry, a bit dusty, some fruity hints of raisin. Good beer!

22 oz. bottle purchased at Central Market in Mill Creek, WA....poured into a brandy snifter.  Aroma:  Sweet roasted malt and coffee.  Flavor:  Sweet roasted malt that is way more forward than the hops.  THIS BEER IS AWESOME!!!!
drank at mondial 2011 in mtl. pours dark brown with a med-dark beige head. roasted malts, smke, fresh grassy cones, toasted caramel. average carbonation, medium body.

First off, I love black IPAs.  That said, I love this beer.  Beer pours almost black with a totally retained, tan  colored head that produces copious lacing.  Aroma is really nice with pine, chocolate, and roasted nuts.  Flavor is initially sweet then finishes dry and hoppy.  This really is a world class beer, IMO!!!

Dark red to brown pour with a large, creamy off-white head.  Aroma is heavy malt, chocolate, and fruits. Flavor is strong on fruity sweetness and counter-balanced grapefruit bitterness.  Texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Nice thick tan head sits atop a pitch black beer.  Interesting aromas. Piney, Grassy, fresh hop aromas, some roastiness and bready also.  Very full bodied, malty/stickiness, lots of carbonation and alcohol warms the throat all the way down. Outstanding malty sweetness and hop bitterness, and although not harmoniously balanced, it is a very enjoyable beer.

Pours a deep deep brown. Aroma of peppery spice and a hint of black licorice. Taste is peppery and spicy from the start. I definitely taste the use of rye. In the middle of the taste is a bit of chocolate followed by a dry bitter finish. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy all of which is enjoyable.

A black pour with brown head.  The aroma is full of pine and grassy hops along with some faint bubblegum.  The medium body has an oily texture with average carbonation.  The taste begins bittersweet and is followed by a long, bitter finish.

Poured black with an inch of head. Smells of piney hops. Tastes like I bit into a fresh strawberry.  It was served too cold and it muted the malty character. I didnt enjoy this out of bottle, but its much better on tap
Draught @ Stone World Bistro. Pours dark black with a thick tan head. Aroma of hop and liquorice. Complex smoke taste with a bitter finish.

Pours black with a nice 1/2" thick white head. Smells of citrus, dark chocolate, pine and cut grass. Dark roasted malts,chocolate, coffee, grapefruit, pine and citrus. Mouthfeel is medium and the finish is long and well balanced between the roasted bitterness and the hoppy bitterness.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a deep dark brown, almost black with a good thick tan head.  Aroma is of very citrusy hops and maybe a little toffee on the end.  Tastes of roasted malts and piney/citrus hops that finish quite bitter.  There were maybe some subtle coffee and cocoa aspects as well.  There is a known alcohol presence, but not in the taste.  Overall, a very nice IPA and probably the best black IPA I have had to date.

Ha well I tasted this without knowing what kind of beer it was and guessed Black IPA.  I thought it was an IPA with a touch of Barley Wine and a bit of Porter.  It pours black and smells of chocolate, citrus and hops.  The taste is much darker and richer with notes of alcohol and that sweet malt that you get from a Barley Wine.  Hoppy and smooth going down.

Beautiful black pour, with only the deepest of ruby-fringed hues.  It has a lasting, thickly coating tan head that leaves thick soap lacing.  The nose is chocolates, tobacco, a touch of astringency and roasts.  The flavors are similar, with a roasted coffee malt, deep bitters, a hint of alcohol to finish, and some biscuit flour alongside neat whiskey notes.  The body is round, with a smooth, creamy palate and satiating, almost vinous mouthfeel.  Plenty of substance here, and a very good black-roasted IPA.  Lots of coffee grounds, grains and charred roasts to enjoy.
Great dark black color with minimal head. Nice hop scent and a great smokey flavor, wish it was a little less bitter.

Pours a deep dark chocolate. Hop presence immediate in the nose, almost bizarrely for something this dark. Mouthfeel is medium to full on. Some hints of chocolate and dark fruits, but Im always looking for something more from the American Hop Slam gang and this doesnt quite do it for me.

Bottle. Poured a jet black color with a two finger creamy tan head, that retained throughout the beer. Left some lacing as it went. Aroma was smoky flavors with grass and pines. Burnt flavors, with a nice spruce hoppy finish. Oily and sticky mouth feel very hoppy in the finish. An above average beer.
It poured a midnight black color, with a small light brown head. The aroma was of strong cascade hops. The taste was strong initially of hops which mellowed to a nice warm finish. Very good beer.

Bottle. Dark mahogany appearance, good head retention. Instant citrussy hop aroma, develops into molasses as it settles. Subtle chocolaty malt flavor, a touch salty, strong bitter grapefruit hop in the finish. First black IPA I tried and instantly impressed.

Bottle.  Pours almost black with a creamy tan head.  Smells overbearingly of pine.  Tastes just as it smells with a lingering bitter finish. This beer does have an excellent consistency, but that alone doesnt make up for the flavor.  Ive had some other Stone beers I found much more agreeable.
amazing black IPA. Usually im not a fan of black IPAs, i feel they lack aroman and bite, not the case here, great IPA in general. Do it.

dark brown pour with a thick tan head.
aroma is piney, nuts, light spice.
flavour is piney, roasted malt , medium bitterness. 
some coffee.

An opaque brick of ebony sits sublimely in my glass with a nice head of tan.  You can smell the hops right after popping the cap: smells like a pine forest full of sweaty men (As strange as it sounds I smell a hint of BO/cheese).  A perfect medium body of coffee, bittersweet chocolate and a hint of sweetness.  Finishes long and tingly with spicy pine and all that glorious hoppy bitterness.  Im amazed how balanced this is considering how hoppy it gets in the finish.  A solid Cascadian!

Pour is a black with a large tan head.  Aroma is a nice hop with some burnt malt and a small wood smoke.  Flavor is agressive hops with a small chocolate malt toward the end.  Very tasty and one of the better black IPAs Ive had.  Most of the beers Ive had of this style the dark malt kills anything the hops have to offer.  This is the opposite.  The hops are here in a big way and kinda hide the malts.

Most of the black ipas have been shall we say, less than stellar, which made me a bit hesitant to purchase this one.  However, Ive heard through the grapevine that this beer is an exception to that rule.  So here goes.  Dark brown almost black pour with a disappating head.  Notes of green grassy earthy hops with a healthly dose of black malt.  I have to say, Im somewhat impressed with this beer.  It seems to meld the two styles together better than most of its counterparts.  Good effort on a hard to nail style.

Poured from a 22oz bomber. Pours a nice dark black with a thick head. Aroma is fantastic Very fresh and clean hops. Flavor is also great! Not overly malted for such a black beer. Very clean flavour, with perfect bitterness. Palate is full bodied, and finishes long and dry. Overall this is a great beer. Im really digging the Black IPA style, and had to try the best!!

To say that Ive been looking forward to this beer is an understatement.  One of my buddies happened to pick this up in Denver last year but he of course didnt share.  22 ounce bomber poured into an oversized wine goblet.  Comes out of the bottle dark brown (think cola) with a frothy long lasting tan head.  Wish the head was a bit thicker, but the high ABV probably makes that difficult.  Aroma comes across as this dank and earthy hop character, with big notes of pine.  Its huge!  Roasted grain and chocolate are buried in the nose.  You have to work your way past the incredible hop aroma but theyre in there.  Then theres the whole matter of taste.  Hops shatter the palate first, with a prolonged bitterness in the finish. The first taste is all hops.  As you acclimate youll be able to start to pick at the malt profile a bit more, but the first taste is jarring.  I like the mouthfeel as well.  Its slick and despite all the hops never gets sticky.  This beer finishes very dry (something Ive noticed with most Stone beers), as the malt character never goes overboard into sweet territory.  Instead it opts for roasted and nutty, with a slight bitter coffee note.  Thats not the best description.  Let me put it this way Ive toasted pine nuts, getting them to the point where theyre almost too dark, and thats what this malt flavor reminds me of.  Its not burnt, but is right there on the edge.  Theres also some definite alcohol warmth but Im not picking up any fusels in the nose or taste, very impressive.  Its not often that I find a beer that lives up to my expectations when trying it, but Sublimely Self-Righteous does that and then some.  Not sure if its possible, but this is a textbook example of an emerging style.

Bomber. Duvel tulip. 

APPEARANCE: Pitch black. Hues of deep dark brown only barely discernible at the edges when held to light. 

Head is dark beige, creamy, has lengthy retention, minimal lace. 


AROMA: Citrus (grapefruit) and grassy hops, lightly roasted malt, light coffee. Hops more prominent than malt. 

Hints of dark bitter chocolate.

TASTE: Citrusy and some grassy hop taste combined with hop and roasted malt bitterness. More roasted malts on taste than on nose, however hops still more prominent than malt. 

Hints of chocolate malt. 


MOUTH FEEL: Medium bodied. Moderate carbonation. Alcohol well hidden behind bitterness and roasty characteristics.  


OVERALL: Bitter finish a tad more bitter and longer lasting than would have preferred. Like drinking an Americano with grapefruit peel.
UPDATED: JUL 14, 2012 definitely good, and when I had this two years ago, this was the best black ipa Id had, but the Firestone Walker Wookey is the bomb
Big bottle.  Brown, clear, foamy head.  Very rich and strong, high alcohol is well masked by the taste.  Complex aroma, good pick for a strong full flavored ale.

10 May 2011, tap. dont know what to make of the nose. for some reason all i can think about is urinal cakes and tin. dark red/brown. med body and slightly fizzy. coffee and bitter hops. really puzzling over this one.

Keg at BrewDog, Stone night! Pour is deep, deep brown, almost black. Small beige head, massive lacing. Big resinous hops on the nose, lots of fruit, some smokiness. Slightest hint of coffee. Taste is slightly fruity, slightly liquorice. Big bitter finish, but less fruit and more roast. Very nice.

Sampled at the private tasting during Opening Night Party for VCBW (Thanks G.I. Matt!). Pours a dark brown with little head but decent lacing. Aroma is lush, chewy hops. Taste strikes a great balance between oily PNW hops and caramel malt. Taste is consistent start to finish. Would have believed this to be an American Strong since there was little dominance up front for the malt. Still wonderful.
A mix of my two favorite beer styles, Imperial Stout and Imperial IPA. Toasted, hoppy goodness.
My first black IPA.  Great floral hops presence.  Slight astringently bitter aftertaste.  Seems to overpower the "black" in this black IPA.

Got this beer as a gift and man what a gift.  Very dark/black color with very thick head which keeps its foam for pretty much the entire pint.  Aroma is fully of hops, and with eyes closed, could easily mistake this for a strong IPA.  Tastes like a combination of IPA and brown sugar... a little sweet but no overdone.  Very smooth and no aftertaste that many IPAs have.  Well done stone... well done...

Appearance is not quite black, but has a great brown head that sticks around for a while. The nose is amazing. Full of great toasted malts, brown sugar, as well as nice citrus notes. The taste is very similar. Very sweet with the brown sugar and theres also a great hop balance with citrus and floral aromas. The mouthfeel is medium to heavy bodied with above average carbonation. Overall, a great brew, definitely impressed here and will have to buy again soon.

This definatly has that singature stone taste/armoma.Its fairly black. With a red hue held up to the light.Of a 22 oz bomber the first pour was less head maybe 1 finger as the second pour is usually more,2 finger for this one.Some lacing,head stays all the way to the bottem.Foamy tan head.
 The aroma is the signature hop smell some yeast grain alcohol.
 The taste is a light medium robust arragant light-med bodied some mild slick mouthfeel with mild coffe,chocolate, but definatly dark choc or black malt bitterness with the hop bitterness continuing on the roof of your mouth.

pours nearly black with some ruby colors showing through. nice tan head. aroma is well hopped and roasted malts poke out as well. taste initially is powerful bitter hops which seems to be a staple of stone beers. towards the end i get nice coffee and roasted malts. well rounded american black ale. definately one of the better ones ive had.

Pours black with a 3 finger, rocky tan head that has great retention and leaves nice lacing. Aroma is huge on floral and citrus hops, caramel, chocolate, sweet malt, stone fruits, light nutty notes and maybe a touch of roast. Flavor is, again, big on citrus and floral hops, toasted nuts, bittersweet chocolate, roast, a little char, sweet malt, a touch of pine and tree fruit. Bitter, chocolate crystal malt sweetness to the finish. Palate is medium bodied, creamy, neutral entry, moderate, not to sharp carbonation and dry somewhat astringent finish. Good stuff, out of the handful of Black IPAs I have had this one seems like the most cohesive product as the roasty, chocolaty notes really blend nicely with the big dose of hops.
Ive had a few other black IPAs but this is the only one that really stands out. Tastes of strong hop bitterness well balanced with a porter-like malty undertone. Absolutely delicious.

Pours dark brown, almost black, with a medium tan head.  Aroma is all hops, with pine, floral, and citrus elements.  Flavor follows the aroma closely - deliciously hoppy - but with a mild roasted malt undertone.  The hops dominate, but this is amazingly well-balanced.  By far the best "black IPA" (or whatever the current name of that trend is) that I have tasted.  Excellent.
Pine, citrus, big black body and well hidden booze all make this the best black IPA ive ever had.

Very dark red beer, thin head. The aroma is wonderful, rich hop and slightly burnt nose. Flavor is not nearly as hoppy as the aroma (or the brewers reputation) might suggest. Its generally sweet with a bit of fruitiness and a smooth bitter finish. Very drinkable.
My first five.  This beer was absolutely fantastic.  These Black IPAs are unreal. Cant wait to getmore of this one.
Aroma of cloves and fruit.  Appears very dark with almost no head.  Tastes of spices and roast hops.  Yet another triumph from stone.
caramel, pine,floral, alcohol, black, cloudy, white foam, medium bitterness, slick feel, slick feel, light body, average carbonation,

Poured a very dark brown color with a generous light cream head.  Smells of hop flowers met the nose instantly.  Aroma is dominated by hops and a slight roast malt.  Taste is medium bitterness.  Medium body.  Creamier texture, slightly oily.  Long bitter finish.  Fresh powerful hops once again dominate the taste with some roastyness in there.  Once again Stone puts out a winner. They deserve to be Self Righteous...

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2014 Had at The Monks private tasting. Pours black with some faint red tinges on the edges. Great lacing down the side of the glass is left from a small tan head. The roasted malts are restrained compared to most brews of this style. This allows the hops to come through as the leading aroma with a nice balanced backing of roast malts and coffee. The only way to describe the taste is sublime. The best beer of the night. Simply amazing

Scents of cereal, chocolate, coffee, nuts, resin, citrus, and earthy tea invite a sip.  I take a draw from the tulip glass, letting the dark brown ale greet my lips through the pillowy tan head.  Such a well balanced ale, the dark malt traits are restrained, sharing the lead with the delicious hops.  
A long tea like bitter finish leaves you craving more.  SSSRA is wings and horns above any other Black IPA Ive had, and always a pleasure.

bottle; black with red hue and thick brown head; aroma-sweet, roasty, mostly pine, some grapefruit; taste-moderate sweetness, mild carbonation and strong bitterness. Pine come through again. Wow-I could drink this until the end of time.

Bottle @ Cask Pub and Kitchen in London. Pours an almost pitch black color with a frothy beige head. Aroma is very hoppy with alot of grapefruit, balanced out by roasted malts, along with some slight liqourice and coffee. The flavor is initally loads of grapefruit, followed up by the roasted malt, coffee and liqourice notes along with some dark chocolate. The body is medium with a nice creamy and slightly dry mouthfeel. Overall one of the best Black IPAs I have ever had!

Bomber:  Pours a dark ruby color with a thick long-lasting rocky tan head, roasted malts and grapefruit in the aroma, starts and ends bitter with a roasted ending, medium bodied with subtle carbonation.

I love a heavily hopped IPA and this is my first experience drinking a black pale ale.   The fact that the dark roasting of the malt doesnt overpower the heavy hop flavor makes this a truly delicious blend.  I have tried most of the Stone Brewery products and think very highly of their beers.  Right now this one is my favorite, what a great find.  I came across this gem at the Avenue Pub on St. Charles Ave. in New Orleans while on vacation.  If you like hoppy Pale Ales, do yourself a big favor and try this one. Its very hoppy, blended with moderate dark roast characteristics in a truly "sublime" blend.

Pours a black color with a tan head. Aroma is of roasted malts, caramel, chocolate, coffee, a hint of citrus hops, and some dark fruits. Flavor starts off with the roasted flavors but gives way to the citrus hop finish. Not overly hoppy but its blended well. Not too much of an alcohol warming.

Black, tan head, good lace. Citrusy hop nose (Centennial?). Very little roasty dark grain character compared to other black IPAs. Very long finish that does have some dark grain characters to it. The most regular IPA-like black IPA Ive had. Not sure if that is the point, or if these beers are supposed to be a combination between stouts and IPAs.

Huge nose of orange and pine, and as I was drinking it (watching the Final Four 2011 of Kentucky v. UConn in the semi), at one point I thought I was smelling a combination of female B.O. and hairspray on the woman next to me...turns out it was the aroma as I got close to the glass.  The flavor did reveal some actual dry dark chocolate (more than I expected) as it warmed, though there was still plenty of hop bitterness dominating the profile. Reasonably dry, though I had also had a taster of the Double Dry Hopped Sublimely next to it, and that was not markedly but sufficiently different--softer in palate (was it casked?) and quite a bit softer in its hop profile too.  That was surprising; much less an IPA, more of a sense of it being a sophisticated DIPA.  This may be the best example Ive had of a black IPA (or the Cascadian IPA or whatever it they call it further up the West Coast).  On tap at the Muddy Pig, St. Paul, MN.

Pours deep, dark chocolate brown with slight tan head.  Diminishes to leave a thin blanket atop the beer throughout.  Some sticky lacing throughout, as well.  Aroma is heavy pine and citrus rind with nutty roasted notes and touch of dark chocolate. Pine aroma overpowers, but a nice swirl brings out the malt nose. Taste of candied nut quickly leads way to resinous, piney hops.  With a rather bitter, though not at all unpleasant finish.  Medium bodied, mildly carbonated and a bold introduction to Stone beers.
Black pour with a white creamy head, lots of lacing.  Aroma of some hops and coffee, flavor was more hops in the finish, mouthfeel was thick, somewhat like Guinness with hops.

(bottle)  Pours black with a thick light tan head that settles fairly quickly to a medium cap.  Aroma is pretty strong of piney and citrus hops, with plenty of grapefruit, light lemon, and some orange zest.  Slightly resinous.  Mint shows up to the party.  Does resemble OFF bugspray from time to time with the heavy hopping, and the malts are really dialed down, with only a suggestion of roasted malt peeking out underneath the hops.  Malts are more prominent in the flavor, with a roasty and chocolate undertone pairing well with the otherwise Double-IPA like flavors.  Pine, grapefruit rind, and juniper all show up here, and the finish is appropriately bitter.  Mouthfeel is medium to slightly full, with toned-down carbonation.  Overall, this is decent, but nothing really sets it apart from the majority of  other beers of this style.

Bottle, thanks to my parents for bringing this back from Vegas for me. Ive been trying to track this one down for a while. Pours very dark brown, though not quite black; excellent clarity, thick pale tan head, very nice lacing - which seems to be rather a hallmark for Stone. Nose is big grapefruit and sharp pine notes, which is fine as I feel the softer hop notes are hidden by the darker malts, as opposed to being entirely absent. I get just tiny flashes of florals or stonefruit, but its gone just as I try to pin it down... Further nosing reveals dark roast, lightly soapy, which seems to be playing off a bit of soapiness from the hops as well as the malt. Flavours of big bitter grapefruit, light soap, some really intense pine notes, roast is way in the background, and comes out as a lightly coffeeish note in the finish, though it is present all the way through. Strikes me as Arrogant Bastard with more Roasted malts, and more pine-driven hops, as opposed to softer, more citrus-juice driven ones. Well-balanced, clean finished. Just another beer in the "Stone Hoppy Beers" spectrum, which is as predictable as it is excellent.
UPDATED: MAR 30, 2011 Tap. Black pour with a khaki head. Awesome pine hop nose and taste. Well balanced with caramel malt. Just overall great.

had a few bottles of this, but kept tasting off to me. I guess I have to be in the right mood to enjoy a dark IPA, b/c right now this beer is drinking real good. dark pour with medium sized, dense head. Nice arouma of hops, pine and roast. Sweet upfront, with nice silky smooth caramel malts, balanced by dark smokiness, dark malts, astringent finish with some alcohol burn. I have a bottle of 11th anni that Im planning on doing a side-by-side tasting of.

Bottle to snifter. Brown black pour which is black once in glass and has a nice creamy kahki head that dissipated to film/collar. Aroma is awesome pine citrus grapefruit with a crazy caramel smoke malt scent as well. Taste is creamy smokey and malty and an awesome bitter pine. Palate is medium feel and creamy with a chaulky finish. I really enjoyed this one and the alcohol is well hidden.
Wow. Great beer. Loved it at first sip. leaves a toasty hoppy finish in my mouth. Wonderful beer. One of my favorites =)

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2016 Quoi dire de plus sur cette véritable bombe de Stone brewery? Son arôme laisse présager linvraisemblable, la fusion parfaite entre une Impérial IPA et une Impérial Stout. Impossible de faire mieux pour le style.

This is a great beer. Aroma is mostly hops, appearance is black w/ tan head that fades quickly. Taste is bitter roast then hops on the finish a nice piney spicy hop flavor that lingers on your tongue balancing out with the roast very well. Its a nice mouthfeel, not too thick to ruin the refreshing finish but not too thin either. Overall If I could find more of this I would drink more of this.

220z bottle poured into a snifter.  I cannot beleive I have never rated this one.  Love this beer.  The aromas is of hops, but also some roasty character/  The beer pours a nice black with a brown head.  Taste is very IPA like, but then you get the malts....very bitter...notes of grapefruit in there, best to let it warm a bit.  Palate is medium and carbonation is medium.  Overall, this is a great brew anytime.

The beer pours a dark brown with decent head. Almost two fingers of light tan head rises, lasting a couple minutes. The lacing is pretty solid. 

The aroma is pretty light giving off a nice smooth hoppiness. 

The taste is super hoppy from start to finish with a very bitter finish. There is slight earthniess to this that separates it from being an ipa, a nice change of pace.

Overall, pretty decent.

It pours as dark as night and has mild hops on the aroma.  Upon sipping, the hops hit you heavy with subtle hints of banana.  It finishes with a lot of hoppiness but is still very drinkable but not really sessionable.

Great pour, bottle opened with a pop, almost like a cork, tons of carbonation, looks and smell fresh, smells of hops, fruity, and a touch of malt/coffee.

Once it settles down, the first sip does not disappoint.  Fresh and hoppy, fruity as well, sort of explodes, nice bitterness as well, then the malty backbone is excellent, pretty perfect IMO.  Not sure you could do a black IPA much better, from start to finish its smooth.  ABV virtually undetectable.  Awesome.

Poured into a snifter. Beautiful obsidian color with a light khaki head. Nice head retention on this one. Moderate lacing. I read the bottle and it said IPA, but this appearance is throwing me off. Strong floral hop aroma, sweet pine, and a light dash of citrus. I am pulling some tart green apple. Some sweet malts makes this remind me of a barley wine. Very hoppy, slight citrus with a very sweet yet subtle malt characteristic. Great grapefruit taste. This makes me crave a barley wine for comparison. Definitely more hoppy than a barley wine but the malts are wonderful in this. The mouthfeel is a little on the dry side for my liking, but understandable with the high alpha hops. Mild carbonation. A nice treat. I am going to try to age one of these just to see what happens.

Aroma: Caramel and nutty malts, with hints of floral hops underneath.
Appearance: Black with a thick tan head.
Taste: Medium bitterness with a hint of sourness in the finish.
Palate: Full bodied with lively carbonation and a long finish.
Overall: Its a really solid beer worth nursing. Im not blown away, and dont get a sense of too much complexity, but it tastes quite good and would certainly find a place in my fridge.

Pours from the bottle like a strong tea, results in a black beer.  Three-finger latte head with near complete lacing.  

Sticky, piney, pineapple, grapefruit hop aromas.  Super sweet and lush smelling.

Hops and malt come through big together.  Dry and sticky from the hops.  The hops follow the aroma and the malts are a cocoa dusted almonds.  Dark and dry malts combined fruity, sticky hops.  Yum.

Pour black with ruby tones against light with huge tanned head nice lace. Aroma is BW like, dark fruits, raisins, malty,  Tart fruity mouthfeel. Flavor is balanced, hoppy, crisp, malty, alcohol, acidy, raisin. Peppery tart palate. Finishes balanced longlived fruity tart bitter.

pours dark black with nice thick tan head and good lacing, aroma is strong hops and slight chocolate/coffee. taste at first is sweet then goes bitter but not too bitter with nice hops then leaves a nice bitter chocolate finish, surprised on how much i enjoyed this cuz im not much of a hop head, i prefer more stouts and porters, but this is a must.

Had this on tap at the Nail Creek Pub in Utica.  Pours black, cant see through it, with a nice light brown head with nice lacing. Strong hoppy aroma of pine and citrus mixed with chocolate coffee. Taste starts off hoppy and finishes with chocolate and coffee. Long nicely bitter coffee finish.

Dark mahogany pour with a thick tan head that left more than a few sheets of lacing. Aroma is very sweet. I definitely get some chocolate, coffee, toffee, and dark fruits. Taste is again more sweet than bitter. There is some citrus hop character, almost leaning towards tropical fruit. Palate is definitely full bodied. I honestly thought this was a stout or barley wine before looking it up. Very delicious, but I didnt find it all that bitter, and its not really what I was expecting from a Black IPA.

Pour is black, with a decent sized tan head. Nose is of hops, with a little caramel note from all of the malts. Taste is hoppy throughout, though very controlled, and not palate killing like normal IPAs. Rather light considering it is literally pitch black, with decent carbonation

Pours a murky brown with a thin beige head. Sweet roasty caramel malts as well as a load of piney, citusy hops. Pretty complex but the flavors really compliment each other. Great smooth body and soft carbonation. Long bitter finish. Delicious.
UPDATED: DEC 3, 2012 Its a normal heavy hop profile, bitter finish with notes of roastedness in the main flavor. Interesting mix, makes a tasty beer

Bottle at The Rake. Pours a dark cola, with a medium beige head. Aromas of roasted malt, citrus, pine, tropical fruits and orange rind. Tast much the same with roasted malt and pineapple and lemon being dominant. Fantastic beer

UPDATED: APR 9, 2012 Pours black, which should considering black is in the name of this style. Smell is of strong floral hops, very awesome. Taste of hops, lots of hops, bitterness with pine, some citrus and roasted malts. A great style with a great color. Not just a great black Ipa, but a great Ipa. Or should I just say a great beer.

Has an almost stout-like appearance with a very dark brown color and a creamy tan head.  Very complex aroma that is dominated by floral and citrus hops with sweet, almost burnt caramel and just a touch of alcohol.  Taste is sweet and malty up front with lots of chocolate, caramel, and some citrus.  The sweetness quickly gives way to burnt coffee and bitter floral hops, then fades to a long, bitter finish.  Creamy, medium body with soft carbonation.  As usual, Stones egotistical description is not unwarranted.  This one makes me a believer in a style that had previously left me dissappointed.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2011 The aroma is amazing. You smell the floral qualities. The taste is a caramely, malty sweetness with a big hop punch on the end. This is incredible. Im gonna flu for this style cause I love beers with big malty bodies and then that awesome hoppy balance. The palate is wonderful and the body thick and coats your mouth perfectly.

4-5-11 - I got to try the Double dry hopped Sublimely Self Righteous last night on tap at a Stone tap takeover release party. AMAZING. It definitely boost that 4.3 i gave it to a 4.5. The aroma was awesome and made a great beer even greater.

Bottle @ home. Deep black appearance with a big tan colored head. Huge charred, burnt rubber, hoppy nose thats pretty unpleasant to me. Deep roasty, burnt dark malts over a piney hoppy flavor. Burnt hoppy finish.

Aroma is luscious, fruity, floral hops. Slightly citrusy notes combine with the roasted chocolate flavors of the malt. Smells delicous. Pours a dark brown with a big off white head. Taste is roasted malt immediately on the front, slightly chocolate. Follows up with a huge hop punch. Really coats your mouth with flavor. Lingering bitterness. Surprising amount of hop character for as powerful as the malt still is. Best black IPA Ive tasted.

Sampled randomly on tap at the Dieu du Ciel brewpub in Montreal.  Poured a jet black with a dense tan head, leaving behind some very decorative lacing.  Aroma is a penetrating resinous and piny character, very inviting.  Flavor is a nicely balanced, sweetness from the malts curbing the strong hop character enough to make this fairly easy drinking for the style.  Slightly syrupy on the palate, though this is offset by the mildly prickly carbonation.  Finishes very hoppy, coats the palate with enough hop resins to leave a lingering aroma several minutes after drinking.  Well done!

650ml bomber bottle. best by 06/29/10.

Pours a dense dark brown/black with hints of ruby when held to light and a foamy, long lasting tan head. It is a bit of an ambiguous color, it looks like a stout.

It smells sweet and hoppy, but it isnt that fragrant.

The taste is bitter and hoppy, with some slight coffee character. It is slightly metallic as well. The hops are piney and mix with the metallicness to create a flavor im not too keen on.

The so called black IPAs seem to be more gimmicks than anything, it seems like no brewers have taken the time to make the perfect recipe for it.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-02-2010 00:46:54

Bottle. Damm good brew. Goes to glass as medium bodied and deep black. There is a minimal head to stare at while you are nosing the deep caramel, malt and faint hops. a nice subtle sweetness and creamy mouth bring the hops into the picture. Very, very well balnced.. rich and complex. A Fantastic brew.
This one got me trashed for some reason. It was surprisingly smooth and very unique. I loved it.

Pours dark as a stout with a slightly off-white creamy, rocky head. Several different hops in the nose. Lots of hops in the flavor with the charred and roasted flavors finally in the finish. Lemon and grapefruit start, then the roast, followed with a familiar hop pummeling.

Very solid brew.  Pours a very dark brown with an off-white head.  Aroma is full of pine and caramel.  Medium mouthfeel with slight carbonation and tastes of burnt roasted coffee and bitter citrus.  Long bitter finish.  Would drink again.

Pours nice dark black, nice fluffy white head.  Aroma has big notes of pine, and a touch of citrus intermingling with chocolate, roast, and some coffee.  Taste is fantastic pine and chocolate intertwined with some caramel, finishing bitter and roasted.  Black IPA done well, where the right tastes matched up from the hops and the malt at the right time.

Bottle @ Hotelroom, Denver. Pours dark brown, allsmost black, with a huge tan head. Aroma of sweet caramel, chocolate,pine, resin and some citrusslike notes. Taste is coffee, expresso, chicolate at first, then overtaken by the bitter hops flavors, pine, resin. Medium body, soft carbonation, lasting bitter finish. Nice 260211

Growler from Stone BC. Dark brown pour with a stiff, persistent tan head. Resinous, chocolate nose - surprising that anything comes through the head. Medium body with light carbonation and chocolate, resin, espresso and citrus. Very smooth and drinkable, one of favorite Stone brews, second only to Lukcy Basardt at this point (which Im praying also becomes a regular in the Stone lineup). Ill be back!

22 oz bomber.  Pours dark brown, almost the color of a porter but a bit more translucent.  Thin, tan head.  Interesting to drink a beer this dark and have it be this hoppy.  I expected the maltiness to balance out the hoppyness but the hops come through a lot more, although this isnt a bad thing.  The usual citrus, pine, floral notes of an IPA dont come through near as much in this beer, but the bitterness is definitely there. I thought it would be a little sweeter, given the alcohol content.   Subtle hints of dry chocolate, licorice, cough syrup and resin are present also.  Not the most amazing beer Ive ever had but one of the more interesting and creative ones.  Thumbs up for sure.

On tap at the Meddlesome Moth, Dallas. It pours jet black with a thick tan head. The nose is rich-roast coffee, toffee, brown sugar, marshmallow and pine. The taste is of burnt sugar, toast, bread, coffee, molasses, soy, pine and hay. It has a medium to thick body and the finish is burnt, smokey and mighty bitter. I find it perhaps a bit too savoury, but enjoyable none the less.

(bottle)   My first beer in this style and it looks like I started out on top.  Love the balance of bitter IPA hoppyness and the rich full & creamy malt.  This pours a dark mahogany with a thick long-lasting head.   I often feel Stone beers are overrated, but this selection deserves accolades.
Pours a midnight black, with very little light brown head.  Stong cascade hops aromas.  Strong initial hops attach which mellows to a nice warm finish.  Very good beer.

Pours practically opaque with a nice head. Aroma is complex but is dominated by earthy hops. Faint notes of coffee/licorice. Taste is mostly bitter without a big pucker factor due to the sweetness from the malts. Very slight alcohol on the finish. Has a nice mouthfeel and is very smooth drinking. As an IPA fan, I was delighted by this particular brew. Will likely pick up a bottle next time I go shopping.

Pours a jet black with a tan head.  Nose is complex with bold citrus hop, grass.  Full mouthfeel, smooth, with a zing at the end.  Toast malt, bittersweet chocolate, almond moves to a balanced resiny and lemon hop.  Finishes with brown sugar and licorice.  Fantastic.

Stones newest year-round brew is also their best. This beer is everything a Black IPA should be - smooth, medium-bodied, dry, and tremendously hoppy. It looks like a porter and tastes like an IPA, but smoothed around the edges by the dark malt and, presumably, spot-on water chemistry. A truly world class beer.

Bottle. Pours black almost opaque, some tan head. Hoppy aroma with herbal notes, green pepper, a bit vegetal. Malt is more noticeable on the palate with some smoke and roasty malt. Full bodied and very flavorful, not a huge fan of the vegetal aroma though.

Draft from Coalhouse Pizza, Stamford, CT. Served in a pitcher and sipped in mason jars. This is a dark brown brew with a brown head with wonderful lacing. Aroma? To be honest, I have a cold, so I couldnt smell much, but this beer had a sweet tobacco, dark fruit, caramel, and even a cherry hint. Despite its ABV and color, this wasnt too strong of a beer, and it went well with my chicken wings. Hoppy, but not irritating, like how some Stone brews are a little too intense. I really like this .

The hoppy aroma is so intense, youre eyes will water. Just behind it is a malt that smells similar to a strong rye bread. The mixture of the two sensations is unusual and amazing. The head is off-white and fades after a time. The brew is a dark caramel, letting only the slightest light pass through. The taste is unapologetic in its extreme hoppyness. The malts rye quality is right there to back it up. Silky and milky on the palate, the bitterness of the hops continues into the aftertaste, but does not take anything away from your enjoyment.
One of my favorite Black IPA/Cascade Porters. The color and aroma were great. I think Stone gave the beer great malt and hop qualities.

Bottle.  Pours dark with hints of red and a medium off white head.  Aroma and flavor are grapefruit, pine, caramel, some toffee.  Well-balanced, a bit of sweetness, long bitter finish.  Not well versed in black IPAs, but this is quite good.

Rating #300. 650 mL bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, served in an English pint glass. Pours clear reddish black with a moderate, dense tan head. The head mostly remains, leaving behind a small amount of fine lace. The nose has huge hoppy notes of citrus and pine, along with grain, biscuit malts, roasted malts, flowers and a touch of chocolate. The flavour is intensely bitter throughout, with a slight roasty sweetness. There are notes of citrus, flowers and chocolate carried over from the aroma, along with a moderate peppery spiciness. On the palate, it is full in body with a smooth, milky texture and average carbonation. Overall, this is an excellent black IPA. It is smooth and subtle, very harmonious. High-alpha hops are paired elegantly with complex roasted malts. Another delight from Stone. 2011-02-06

This is a go to beer for me. When the 11th anniversary came out I must have drank 20 bottles. It was my first time with a black ipa and frankly I never looked back. Though I feel the 11th was better than the sublimely I was still stoked to have it available year round.

It bours black with a root beer hue. The head is an inviting tan. Smell is pure hops and I love it. The subtle toasted malt are present as well. This beer is the definition of an iba. The color is black bit it drinks like an ipa. Super hoppy and delicious. Nothing bad to say about this other than the smaller batch of the 11th was better. I still have 4 bottles of the 11th and I drank one the other day. The profile is completely different as youd expect. The piney hop flavors are gone and the malt flavors are huge, its almost choclatey. It is a completely different beer but still delicious!

Aroma is of thick smokey malt with a spicy hop smell on the back end. The appearance is thick and very dark brown with a very small head. Taste is smokey and full of hops on the back end. It is a very well balanced beer . The first taste that I get is the malt and that is followed by a surge of bittering hops. I love this beer, I havent found another Cascadian dark ale that I like as much. Please if you have any recommendations, send them my way

Pours like a stout with dark black color and thick rich head. Aroma smacks you upside the head with piney hop flowers. Fresh spicy hop flavor with some chewy roasted malt. Nice mixture of dunkel meets Hop Pocket.

Definite hop-bomb on the nose -- smells a lot like what you might imagine a bottle of IPA extract would smell like, if such a thing did exist.  Poured into an old jelly glass, it was coal black, although a tinge of a ruby/mahogany-like tint may show through if you hit the other side with a 500 watt halogen shop light, or maybe the tip of a plasma cutter.  A relatively thick tan-khaki head forms, slowly dissipating to a thin layer that laces all the way down.  I imagine a scoop of the initial froth would make a decent medium-strength adhesive.  Initial taste is reminiscent of that time when I was 6 or 7 years old and I accepted a dare to stop a spinning bicycle tire with my tongue.  It made the perfectly mediocre Honduran cigar I had lit at the time taste like I was sucking on an unlit toilet paper tube.  After the alcohol hit and the hop assault rendered that particular part of my palate comatose, I noticed the piney, grapefruity-citrus notes, and a malty presence that is hard to define, much like trying to discuss the subtlety of the triangle players performance during the last section of a performance of the 1812 Overture.  With real cannons.  Mouthfeel is truly sublime -- a silky, velvety envelopment awaits you, once the first few kilotons of hop yield completely overwhelm that aspect of your senses.  I have no trouble admitting that my palate needs further development before I can wax poetic about this beers awesomeness.  My Uncle Marvin (Yes, Him -- Marvin Edgeworth) might be disappointed in me since he called Arrogant Bastard "...a moderately hoppy beer", but at this point I can only say that this one is a "once or twice a year" beer for me.  Stunningly complex.  Nuclear hoppiness.  At this point in my beer education, its just a bit much. But I like it, even though Im not sure why...

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2013 Ya know...sometimes itâs hard to say much about a Stone beer, because really.....what havenât they already said. Now if there were perhaps some criticism to be made, that certainly would be beyond them...but when nothing but praise is there for me to proclaim....that torch has been carried - that flag has been raised....and on it are words by self-righteous people with a much better vocabulary than I.

sweet citrus and slight grassy hop aroma I associate with the arrogant bastard ales and a sweet bubblegum and maybe peach like aroma as well, very complex and amazing with a little bit of malt, appearance is black with an off white finger width head, oh my fuckng god, the first taste is amazing i get some coffee flavors and very creamy mouthfeel like an imperial stout, but I get citrusy hop flavors and a slight hop bitterness finish, absolutely amazing beer
Yeah, its hoppy.  But damn, it is balanced out so well, the hoppy-ness shines rather than blinds. Flat out fantastic.
Bottle. Deep, Dark Color. Aroma is hoppy like an IPA. Taste, is also like a regular IPA. Hoppy taste with a malty, caramel toast finish. Nice.

Fra flaske, dufter virkelig dejlig af mørke frugter og kaffe. fremstår flot sort med flot lysebrunt skum. smager dejligt af mørk frugt og stærk kaffe. dejlig fylde af kaffe i alt en super dejlig sort IPA

Bottle from Hopscotch. Thanks bro!! It pours pitch black with a steady creamy light tan head. The aroma is citrus, peach, mango, caramel and light chocolate. Heavy hoppy flavour with a good caramel backbone. Citrus, grape fruit, mango and peaches. Light roasty. Creamy texture. Good balance. Long fruity and light roasty finish. Great!
Great blAck ipa. This is cOmplEX yet easy to drink dark back coilor but tasters nmore. HopPy ythen maltyu

Review from notes, sampled 1/2/2008
Pours a dark black that shows some red highlights when held up to the light. Two finger head that dissipates, but never goes away, laces the glass all the way down. Aroma is hops citrusy, piney, grapefruity hops with a faint biscuit/caramel malt in the background. Taste is more of the same bitter hops. Another great offering from Stone.

Big pine resin candy nose.  Color is black with deep amber hues, thick tan head.  Caramel sweetness, very faint roasty malt background, big hop bitterness and flavor, balance is towards hops for sure.  Alcohol is warming and very pleasant.  Med to high carbonation, full rich body, finish is warming and hoppy.  Might be too literal of an interpretation of a Black IPA, not getting enough roasty malt flavors or aroma, great beer, just expected a little more "traditional" characteristics of style.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2011 I loved this one as Stone?s 11th Anniversary release and was glad to see it come back in this second incarnation.  Pours almost jet black with two wonderful fingers of khaki colored head-leaves significant lacing. Pine and grapefruit hop aroma as well as flavor. Near perfect use of hops in my opinion-not too much of any one flavor. Coats my entire mouth and just the right carbonation. The almost 9% abv is hidden well-could get in trouble quick slammin it back. One I?ve gotten more times than I can count-so glad its here to stay in my area. I love this beer!

Wow - just about drunk it all before I could concentrate on rating it. Bottle, jet black light tan head retained throughout. The aroma is one I first recall from my beer eureka moment and is the combination of my two favourites, chinook and amarillo. Its a big full choc/orange Grand Marnier hit that would go equally well with and aged sirloin or chocolate dessert. Sublime indeed

650ml Bomber. Pours opaque and reflective black with intense cream tan head, retained well throughout. Zesty, citrusy, grapefruit and grass aromas, nutty, bready, caramel, dark malt and cocoa only faint below the intense hop aromas. Medium body, fruity citrus hop flavours balance with a complex malt body of roast, cocoa, bread/grain, caramel and burnt toffee toward the finish with a touch of anise. Toffee sweetness and roasty malts linger on until the next sip. Perfectly balanced, complex brew. Self Righteous indeed.

Bottle. Pours nearly black with a big beige head. Aroma is chocolate, burnt wood, booze, and smoked meat. Flavor is ash, wood, burnt hops, tar, and walnuts. Medium body, dry, with a little heat. Like a toned down Palo Santo Marron.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2012 4oz sample @ Rattle N Hum, New York

Black coloured mix of a stout and an IPA. Salty taste has heavy hints of liquorice and salmiakki. Extremely hoppy and nice palate. Excellent beer. 8-4-9-5-16 = 4.2

Re-rated on 10.9.2011. 660ml bottle from Mybrewerytap

Pours black with a medium bubbly head. Aroma has notes of licorice, dark chocolate, coffee, roasted malts and fruity hops. Taste is quite salty and smooth with notes of licorice, salmiakki, chocolate and coffee. Hints of roasted malts as well. Slightly bitter and extremely fruity finish. Excellent, well balanced black IPA that has the best of the both worlds. 


3.8.2012: 3rd time having this beer and it is still as wonderful as before, even though the bottle isnt very fresh (BBE passed on January 2012). Simply an amazing Black IPA, and one of my favorite beers ever.

Bomber and on tap. This bottle is WAY FRESH and it shows!  Pours a dark, dark brown - pretty much black, with a billowy tannish head that stays. Fantastic, thick lacing. Aroma is big grapefruit, piney, citrusy hops, chocolate, malt, roasty malt. Taste is chocolate, malt, grapefruit, piney hops, really fresh and ending with a long lasting tingly bitterness.  The mouthfeel is very full-bodied and well rounded, with medium to medium low carbonation.  In a word, Delicious.

Pours a nearly black color with a thin whitish head. Aroma if full of citrus hops and some good malt character. Taste is full of signature Stone hoppy grapfruit peel and a good clean malt backbone. Nice brew.

Thick and viscous tan foam head lacing its way down the glass.  Aroma is ripped hops, resinous pine, underlying citrus, and thick, sweet malt.  Taste is scorched earth bitter hops, dark and chewy malt, and trailing alcohol.  I remember the 11th anniversary party where this beer was released and thinking, "damn, another super bitter beer.  bummer."  The beer smells and looks good but the ultra-bitter hops are overkill IMHO.
Pitch black body with thick tanned head. Strong hop aroma and taste with a  chocolate and coffee finish. Simply stunning beer.

Pours an almost jet black with a tan head.The aroma is of strong hops and roasted malts.The flavor is of sweet malt up front with bitter hops at the end.Got a nice bitter finish.Overall one of thew best from Stone.

Pours jet black with a pleasant tan head. Smells both roast malty and hoppy. Tastes malty at first, and then bitter from hops and then goes malty sweet again. Fuller in body than most other IPAs but not as full as a stout with what can only be described as a creamy texture and little mouth carbonation, Stone Sublimely Self-Righteous finishes dry from hops and sweet from malts. This is outstanding.
Bottle (in NZ). Drunk late on a night in Te Kaha (look it up), was like drinking orange chocolate nectar. Nothing grey about this!

Tap, Neighbourhood pub, san diego. I think I had six of these. Pungent, powerful citurs hop aroma that surrounded the whole table. Pours a dark brown-black, medium head. Kind of sweet, but moves to dry towards the end. Silky smooth, wonderful tasty finish. One of my new faves.
22 oz bottle: Pours a dark brown, almost black, with a thin tan head. Aroma is citrus hop and doughy with a grassy malt. Taste is complex, but finishes a bit bitter. Smooth, oily texture.
Pours black with pillowy ta head.  Aroma is rosty pine and florals.  Taste is chocolate bitterness with the pine hitting on the finish.  Very nice mouthfeel, somewhat silky.
Bottle. Pours a clear and dark brown/black beer with a beige head. The aroma is malt and hops with citrus. The flavor is following the nose. The palate is bitterness. Overall a really good beer.

On Tap at Trion in New Haven, IN. Pours a dark, almost black, with a light brown head, looks like a stout, but clearly an ale. Caramel and slight hop aroma. Taste is a nice dark roasted malt flavor, balanced nicely with hop subtleties.

(22 oz. bottle from Bootleggers) Pours dark brown with some reddish amber-brown highlights. Large tan head stays very well. Mouthfeel is smooth, medium-bodied, very lightly chalky, lightly chewy. Big, droopy rings of lacing. Aroma of big fresh grapefruit and Christmas tree, lots of resin. Flavor big and hoppy but not biting pine and grapefruit over chocolate and caramel with hints of black roastiness. Sweet, roasty and hoppy. Resiny, bitter but pleasant aftertaste.  ABV well-covered. Best example of this style Ive had.

There is many things going for the aroma. The smell of pine and hay are noticable. Has a roasted smell with a little black licorice follow up. Has a good head with a black coffee color. Has the best lacing i have seen so far. It has medium carbonation with a decent finish. It starts with a pleasant sweet flavor and ends with a bitter chocolate flavor. Overall the longer it stays in my mouth the worse it gets. For the price i would buy it again. I think stone brewery is a great brewery.

Bottle. Poured a dark brown with a creamy tan head that settled to a ring and left god lace. Aroma of grapefruit hop and roasted malt backing. The initial flavor found licorice and alcohol but this settled out as it warmed to a nice hop and roasted malt mix. Medium body, mild bitterness, and a light roasted malt aftertaste.
Bottle @ Odense tasting. Dark brown body with a large offwhite head. Aroma is hops, grass, fruit, pine. Flavor is hops, roasted malt, fruit, pine, citrus.

pours very dark opaque brown. aroma of chocolate and hops. very well balanced, the nose is a slight sweetness with chocolate notes, finish is hoppy with a medium bitterness. overall great beer, cant wait to try it again.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2011 Hoppy smell that gains more of a chocolate malt aroma as it warms. Taste is grassy and floral hops with a slightly sweet chocolate flavor. Quite a good beer. I need to have it fresh though.

22 oz bottle. Not really sure what a "Black IPA" is, but thought I would give it a try. Pours a mostly opaque black with a small light tan head. Smells of malt, hints of citrus, hops, and a bit of sweetness. Bizarre smell compared to the sight. The taste is just as unique, as it mixes the complexities of an IPA, stout, and possibly even a brown ale all in one, with lots of sweet malt, but also the balance of citrus and hops. Decent body to it also, with a pleasant aftertaste and some sticky mouthfeel to it. Overall, very different, but quite impressive.

This is my first black IPA and I must say Im impressed, both negatively and positively. Most everything seems to be done very well in the marriage of dark malts and citrus hops. Very hoppy aroma but a very malty flavor of dark malts. What I dont like is the odd combination of flavors in this beer. I prefer more traditional hops for this dark beer (more herbal or flowery). The hops overwhelm the palate about halfway through the glass so youre basically drinking an AIPA anyway.

This beer represents many things I love about beer. Velvety texture with fine carbonation, excellent balance and complexity. Nose starts with brown sugar, molasses, and a little resiny hop. Flavor is similar, malts are not heavy or sweet but are present with a fullness of sugar, molasses and biscuit, with a nice full bitterness that provides the perfect balance. There are hints of dark figgy fruits. One of those beers that you get sad when the bomber is empty. Very dark brown, hints at red, thick creamy head.
Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, citrus, grass, pine, peach hop. Flavour is roasted malt, chocolate, sweet notes, citrus, peach and pine hop.
Bottle @ Odense Tasting, December 2010. Pours black with a small creamy off white head and lacings. Roast, soy, caramel and coffee. A bit of ashes. Full bodied. Nice . .

Échantillon, lors du Mondial de la bière, savourée le 3 juin 2010; il : brune foncée, opaque, petite couche de mousse, pas de dentelle; nez : houblon résineux, pamplemousse, orange, malt, alcool; bouche : houblon résineux, astringence, sècheresse, pamplemousse, léger orange, alcool, finale très sèche en houblon résineux avec présence dalcool, corsée, peu carbonatée, bonne astringence, plutôt amère, une touche sucrée; en résumé : bien bon

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2012 Bottle from Beers of Europe & BrewDog Glasgow. Strong hoppy aroma. Very dark brown colour with good tan head. Flavour smokey barbecue roasted hops with spicy bitter aftertaste. Strong but still great. Very nice bottle.

22 oz. bomber, $6 @ Binnys. Again, I fill out my list of beer styles with this exemplar of a new style. Sweetish porter smell in the glass, which shows a thick, puffy head over a black body. Smell suggests some bourbon, even though none was involved. But the taste, ahh Full boatload of those amazingly bitter USs hops (the web site mentions Simcoe and Amarillo, and that I can find easily). Black malts show most prominently on my lips as a bitter buzz, then some at the back of my throat, combining the qualities of coffee roast stout and black lager. No oily smoothness like an imperial stout. So the alcohol goes down imperceptibly. The roasty malts almost make one forget the huge hop load here. So its stout and IPA, two great tastes that taste great together!

Very dark red -black with 1 finger medium chocolate brown head. Smells of Hops, dark roasted sweet malts, dark fruits, prunes, raisins. Taste if bitter chocolate and Big earthy hops, the dark fruits &  malts lend some sweet notes, some yeasts add to a good complexity, alcohol more present as it warms. Full body with good zesty carbonation start to finish, good hop bite and dry finish. A good bold brew (not for the pale ale crowd). Big hops, full body, bold dark fruits all get you attention!

Tap @ Parkway. Dark red-brown pour with a light tan head leaving moderate lace. Spruce and cut-grass hop nose leading into an Arrogant Bastard-like body. Solid, medium-heavy body with whisky, chocolate and coffee notes. Bitter and umami, with a touch of sweetness in the beginning and middle. Half a pint is adequate, but thats not a bad thing.
On tap at Maduro in Madison, poured into a tulip glass, pours a dark black with a thick creamy head, aroma of hops with nice malt tones, the flavor is very hoppy and is well balanced, very enjoyable.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2012 G: Poured into an imperial pint glass. Enjoyed on March 24, 2009.

A: Pours a dark molasses from the bottle with a large, two-finger tan head. The brew was barely transparent as it was being poured, and is opaque in the glass. Plenty of carbonation apparent, and the lacing is tremendous.

S: Very rich malt is the initial scent. Raisins and dates are apparent, but molasses, dark malt, and a tiny bit of brown sugar are the most prevalent here. Excellent. Hops are still there as well.

T: Deliciously rich! Malt and molasses are immediately apparent, as are all of the dark fruit undertones. Some hop bitterness remains. I dont know what this was like when initially released, but it is an absolute delight now, at what I assume is around two years of age?

M: Incredibly smooth with moderate carbonation, creamy mouthfeel, medium to full body, and just the right alcohol pinch.

D: Pretty high abv and a lot to handle. I think a single bomber of this is definitely enough, although it probably wont last in my glass for too long.

This is a review from an aged bottle of Stone 11th Anniversary.

Poured from a bomber into a glass. Appearance is a dense black with an thick tan head. Aroma is all hops. Taste is where this beer surprises me. Its nowhere near as strong as I expected it to be. Taste is like a subdued hoppy IPA. Very pleasant beer. Another shocker, I taste peanut butter in the finish. I love this beer.

Holy God, this is what beer is all about.   This is hands down the best beer I have ever tasted to date.  Notes of pine trees in the nose, followed by the sheer overwhelming complexity of a beer so divine that I dont even have the words to describe it.  Excellent.  Divine.  This is the beer that God would brew if he was in the industry.  Drink all of this that you can.

Pours a dark black with slight reddish hues.  Aroma of floral, spruce and molasses.  Flavor is bitter floral, anise, dried fruit with a hint of brown sugar.  A dry, bitter finish with a slight raisin and nuts.  Overall a heavier, bitter beer with good complexity and a nice balance.
how sublime is this beer? its sublime.

bomber shared with kish84 and jb84. pours dark brown with a tan head. big hoppy nose with backing malt. the flavour is hop foward with supporting pale malt and just a touch of roastiness. solid black ipa.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2011 Bomber from Discount Waukesha - discounted to $3 as the "enjoy by" date is last week?  Pours a cola brown with foamy head, nice lacing on the glass.  Smells sweet chocolate malty with hops - I wish I knew what that aromatic hop is because it is terrifically promising!  One of the best smelling brews ever ...  Taste is sweet chocolate/coffee.  Malty.  Slight licorice and sour mash.  More like chewing salty cocoa beans.  Faint alcohol burn.  Light hop burp on the end.  Just a stellar brew from Stone -- certainly one of my favorite ever with the hoppiness & choco/coffee malt.  10/5/8/4/18.  ReRate 2011.5.7 - still stellar as ever!

This is some opaque crap; DARK chocolate brown with thick fluffy tan head with good retention. It smells like a stout hiding an IPA in its coat;  smoky, chocolatey aromas with some resonous, piny hops, more will probably appear with warming. Its sweet with nice dark chocolate flavor blending well with the incredible dry, hoppy finish. Its full bodied and complex. Tastes like the best of both Imp.Stout and IIPA worlds. SMILES!

Bottle: Pours a Dark Brown with creamy beige head here. Well - Its an awesome brew to be sure. Hoppiness is huge here , but it is balanced fairly well with the creamy malts and a bit of caramel as well. ABV is pronounced imo, but with that said it works for me. Excellent!
