22oz bomber. Pours really dark with a frothy tan head. Piney hop aroma some undertones of dark fruit. Sweet raisin malt start with a big hop finish. A nice hop character that seem so impart some serious licorice bitterness.  Nice.
I was really worried about not liking this.  But I find it much less deficient than most attempts at a IIPA or impy stout.  The people at Stone know what they are doing.
Mellow as hell with a hugely tight drying finish. Heaps of hoppy goodness and a heady burn. Bittersweet and tingly.

Notes from Sunday, July 4, 2010

Ar: Big piney hop note so emblematic of an IPA, but also a backbone of roasted coffee.
Ap: Pours a deep black with streaks of red.  Light 1" cinnamon head leaves good lace.
F: Lovely beer.  Great piney hops along with some citrus (lemon), and a touch of bitter chocolate.  Light alcohol on the finish.
P: I would like this to be a bit thicker.
O: First black IPA.  Very interesting style.
This is the best beer I have had yet.  Man this was a good beer!  Dark/Malty like a porter and fresh like a great IPA.  The Aroma was like an IPA, but there was so much more in this one!

This is one big beer.  When I poured this, I thought stout, but it was too light.  The aroma had nice caramel notes and I thought porter.  But, the hops are over the top.   Im not sure Ive ever had a Black IPA before, but Im sure Ill have more.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: 22 oz bottle served in a tulip.  Pour is cola with two fingers of fluffy beige head on top; this brew has decent head retention and a bit of lacing as well.  Nose is roasted malt, floral hops, booze, and a bit of raisin.  Taste is on par with a bitter, but sweet caramel finish.  This is a tasty brew, but it gets better the closer to room temperature that it gets.

Bomber pours dark black/brown with medium tan head. Aroma is pine, citrus, and dark caramel. Taste is distinctive pine citrus which flows into a nice dark malt coffee chocolate bitterness. The excellence over other Black IPAs is the simplicity of each distinct flavor and how the flow into each other the pine citrus into dark malt coffee perfect, I feel like many Black IPAs have such a confusing mash of different flavors coming all at once, this one is definitely Sublime over the rest.

Pours a four finger light tan head that fades slowly to a thin layer leaving a very good lace. Black color, no highlights. Light-medium carbonation and heavy bodied.  Slight piney hop nose. Flavor is slightly more pine hops than caramel malt and with lingering piney aftertaste. $5.99 for a 22oz bottle from Liquorama Upland, CA.

Bottle.  Pours black, cant see through it, with a nice light brown head with nice lacing.  Strong hoppy aroma of pine and citrus mixed with chocolate coffee.  Taste starts off hoppy and finishes with chocolate and coffee.  Long nicely bitter coffee finish.

(Bottle, Stockholm Beer Festival, 8 Oct 2010) Black colour with creamy, off-white head. Roasted, malty, hoppy nose with notes of black coffee, ashes, pine needles, chocolate and hints of anise. Roasted, malty, hoppy taste with strong black coffee, cocoa, ashes and generous amounts of pine needles in a dry and bitter finish. Almost full body, rather dry and bitter. Despite the powerful taste its very well balanced and tasty. Lovely beer!

Bottle 50cl from the mondial de la bière. A dark beer with a very nice head. Smell is intense on hops. Aroma is amazing, with a creamy and powerful roasted and malty body associated with intense hops and resin aroma. What a beer, everything is there, very nice, specially the creamy and chocolate side associated with a fresh hopy flavor and licorice notes with dark fruits, well done.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Black colour, tan head. Nose of caramel malts, lots of hops, pine, floral. Flavour is good malted, little sweetness, lots of hops, little roastiness, grapefruit. Bitter and fairly dry finish. Excellent stuff.

@Mondial de la Bière 2010, Strasbourg - dark black coloured and with a persistent dark beige foam; a solid fruity hoppiness, grapefruit and chocolate in the background; full-bodied and very bitter, fairly carbonated, very dry and very bitter chocolatey finish with notes of ashes and tons of hops

Key Food Brooklyn bomber ($7): Pours a nearly black color and a massively awesome tan head that makes me happy. Aroma is massive. You can smell it from like three feet away... this is a good thing. Hops and some chocolate is in there, but it isnt really what flavors are there, it is more about the intensity. Taste has some milk chocolate that by the aftertaste turns into bitter dark chocolate. Hops are intense, but not overly so and balance very well with the porter flavors. The mouthfeel is creamy and pleesant and makes the intense flavors very manageable. Bitter, but appetizing. Overall quite nice.

I thought that this brew was extremely interesting style. So I had to try the stone take on it. Again Stone tends to take their hops seriously I figured a black IPA form them would be one to try.

Bottle pored into a stone IMP pint glass produced a gracious two finger off white to brown head on top of a dark brown body. The head turned into a nice lace that followed the body of the brew down the glass.

There is a huge hop nose on this brew you just cant get past it. This wasnt to much of a shock coming from stone. Big old grapefruit with a tad bit of roast in the end. The flavor was interesting to say the least. You get a good bitter hop flavor with a slight roasted bitter coming thru in the end. That basically sums it up. 

I finished the bomber with no problem, and enjoyed every drop. I would buy it again for a hybrid style, I think it is worth the try.

pours dark brown almost black with red highlights huge tan head, nose is huge, herbaceous, citrus, beautiful. almost some marijuana in there, so herbaceous, taste is hugely hoppy, almsot medicinal with sticky mouthfeel,  resinously hoppy taste. wow. this is more intense than i would have imagined. really good, but almost over the top. wow.
Great one.  That Stone hops always there, roasted malty sweet, but the hops dont let you forget this is a Stone.  Very tasty.

I have had this beer a number of times now and love it more with each tasting.  Stone hop profile all the way: pine, slight citrus and hop funk mixed perfectly with chocolate and roasted coffee notes.  Taste is the same with the chocolate and coffee notes in the middle and hops on all sides with a touch of a dark chocolate bitter finish.  In my opinion, a truly style-defying ale.

Nice that Stone recognized they brewed a good limited edition beer and brought it back again into production.   Strong roasted malt and hoppy aroma.   Cascading head much like a nitro beer, brown body.   Moderate bitterness, flavors of licorice and citrus hops.  I assumed this was an American Strong Ale.   Alcohol level will give you a nice buzz, drinkability is there as well.   Perfect beer for the Fall weather.

Appearance was black as coal with a thin head.

Intense citrus and pine aromas with ild roasted malt

A taste like nothing I have ever tried. It is basically a roasted IPA.

Clean and hoppy on the palate with malt sensations similar to a porter.

Pours black with a thick beige head.  Aroma is hop-heavy, with floral and bitter hops both there in bunches.  Some sugary malt notes as well.  Flavor is also hop-centric, but with other more subtle notes like fruits and chocolate coffee.  Feel is silky smooth.  This is an interesting beer, and is unlike very many other beers I have had.  Glad to have tried it, though its certainly no session beer.  One bottle is fine for now.

10 oz. draught. Nice black color. Light vanilla, roasted malts, hops and citrus nose. The flavor is smooth, nothing over the top. Roasted malts, coffee, caramel but yet there is a great presence of hops and citrus that cuts through everything. Very enjoyable.
Nice dark earthy brew.  Pours dark and has a carmel colored thick head.  Semi sweet chocolate under-tones, very enjoyable

Draft.  Great citrus aroma, smooth, slightly burnt caramel, piney, very nice.  Flavor is similar but with way more citrus, brighter pine, light ambrosia, very bitter, seemingly some green apple.  Sticky bodied, sugary but drinkable.

~Strong earthy, grassy and spicy hop aroma, some chocolate in background. 
~Pours dark brown with thick lasting brown head.
~Strong earthy, grassy, spice hop flavor, bitter, in far background roasty chocolate malt.
~Med full body, med CO2, bitter earthy lasting finish.
~Great brew if you are a hop fanatic. I loved the choice of hops. I would have loved it if it was a bit more malty. Maybe if aged the bitterness will be lowered and malts can shine through a bit more.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2011 Poured from a 22 ounce bomber into a Samuel Adams Perfect Pint glass. Enjoy by 11 09 10 etched in glass.

Appearance: Pours a very dark brown, almost coffee black with ruby highlights and a 2 finger foamy tan head. Looks like a stout. Excellent lacing. Beautiful looking beer.

Smell: Piney hops with a hint of pineapple to go along with a background of roasted malt.

Taste: Extremely hoppy throughout but there are a few flavors poking through which make this quite complex. Citrus up front followed by a little roasted malt in the middle then a blast of bitter grapefruit at the finish. Aftertaste is lemon zest.

Mouthfeel: Medium-to-full-bodied with a good amount of carbonation. Feels creamy and prickly at the same time. Hops are pretty sticky.

Drinkability: High drinkability. I wouldnt recommend pounding bomber after bomber but this is a beer you wont get tired of too quickly.

Overall: Excellent beer overall. This is my first experience with an American Black Ale (Black IPA) and I am not disappointed. Another great offering by Stone. I would highly recommend this. Ill be buying more of these.

I better rate this beer half-way through the bottle less my intoxication empare my judgment (and my spelling).  Loved the aroma, reminded me of juniper and Im a big gin guy.  Well balanced, caramel, distinctly bitter.  Hard to believe it is a wine strength ale.
Bottle from Boston. Nose is grassy hops. Pours dark brown with low tan head. Flavour of big hit of grassy hops with dark fruit and chocolate malts. Lingering hop finish. A big complex beer.

650 ml bottle from brewery (thanks MK).  Pours a dark, slighly reddish brown with moderate-sized tan head.  Aroma is an interesting combination of roast and sweet citrusy hops.  Flavour has lots of character with strong citrusy hops, some dark fruit, roastiness and a hint of cocoa.  Fairly bitter finish; medium+ body.  Very nice.

Sample from Bottle at SBWF.
Nice hoppy aroma. Taste of citrusy hops and licorice. Lack of balance as usual for Black IPAs, I have a dificult time to really appriciate this style despite haveing rated all of the style top-3

See Harsebraus rating.  Its Shake-n-Bake, and I helped.

...

Honest intro - probably too schnocked to rate...(got the hiccups)...but here goes... Aroma: this baby has the dark fruits cruising through the nostrils with traces of cocoa with a definite hop. But a lot of prune and raisin. (btw Harsebrau is helping with this..also schnocked.) Poured a dark brown to black. Touch of off tan/white head. Were drinking this in dimpled mugs. It has a flavor of bitter and malty smooth but sharply bitter. It has been burnt by something. I dont what...but burnt. And that is ok.

Honest intro - probably too snchocked to rate...but here goes...
Aroma: this baby has the dark fruits cruising through the nostrils with traces of cocoa with a definite hop.  But a lot of prune and raisin.  (btw Grizzle is helping with this..also snchocked.) Poured a dark brown to black.  Touch of off tan/white head.  Were drinking this in dimpled mugs.  It has a flavor of bitter and malty smooth but sharply bitter.  It has been burnt by something.  I dont what...but burnt. And that is ok.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 1pt. 6oz bottle into a tulip glass. The label has a nice description and history of the beer as this is a remake of there 11th anniversary ale. The ADV is listed as 8.7% and there is no freshness date. 

Appearance: The body has an opaque dark black color with a thick light tan head on top. The head is long lasting and makes for tons of cool lacing on the glass. 

Smell: The aroma has solid roasted and toasted maltiness with caramel like sweetness backed up by equally solid citrusy hops. 

Taste/Palate: Its deep maltiness sets up a firm base for the hops to work there bitter magic. From the base malt I get firm toasted and roasted character with loads of caramel like sweetness that weaves in and out of the dominate hops. The hops bring a big hit of citrus and pine like bitterness. Notes of grapefruit, lime, bitter orange and pine resin hang onto the tongue long into the slow fading finish. The big full body brings a heavy slow sipping and sticky texture with just enough carbonation to keep things from getting cloying. 

Notes: This is another outstanding beer from Stone.

Bottled. Pours a deep burgundy with a pretty off white head and good lacing. The maltiness in the aroma sucker punches you when you get this wonderful hop flavor, piney, herbal, peaches, and mint. Lovely long bitter finish.
Pours dark with a thick, multi-leveled foam that sticks to the side of the glass.  The aroma is piney with a hint of chocolate.  The flavor is rich and dry.
Sample @ SBWF. Nice citrusy aroam, but the taste is just too aggressive without any finesse. Uninteresting.

Black body, with an airy chocolate head--looking like any respectable stout. However, the nose belies the characteristic roasted appearance of a stout--this brew stings the olfactory senses with a sharpness of hop needles, pine and floral. Then, an easy-debittered chocolate settles into the medley. Pleasantly hoppy flavor with a nice bitter floral strain that melds with a stream of lightly roasted chocolate, mostly absent any acrid roast notes. Sour bitter roast and hop twang on the finish. An aggressive brew in all respects. More roasty than many black Ipas, but works well overall.

Pours near-black with a little bit of brown head and decent lacing. Nose is potent hops with a roasted malt in the background. Flavor is about what youd expect from a Stone black IPA: sharp bittering hops on the front and back with a big roasted oat or barley malt balancing it out. Backside is bittersweet and really emphasises the blackened character. Finish is a little sticky and hoppy. More hop heaven from Stone.

Enjoyed from a 22oz bomber in an elongated tulip glass.  The beer pours a jet black color, with a smallish light tan head.  The aroma shows signs of overaging, to the fault of the drinker.  Earthy/herbal hop notes come through, but seem far more muted than they would have been in their original incarnation.  Toasted malts also come through.  The palate is lightly hoppy in the approach and mid-palate, reminiscent of an English pale ale; pleasant, but again evidence of being over-aged.  Subtle alcohol comes through, adding depth.  Overall, a good beer that would like have been excellent, if consumed when intended by the brewery.
Black with very small light tan head. Hoppy pine aroma, like Arrogant Bastard. Yep thats a lot of hoppiness, if thats your thing. The bitterness in the finish is just too much for me to enjoy.
From bottle, dark pour with foam head good lacing.  Aroma is hop delectable with full body palate feel.  The bitter sweet sensation gives this ale great flavor and drinkability.  I Love stone beers!

Black in color with a touch of red when held up to the light.  Creamy caramel colored head.  Clean pine hops aroma, almost soapy like Irish Spring.  Awesome flavor balance of bitter roasted malt and bitter hops.  Thats what makes this brew awesome!  Overall, wow... just... wow... I think I have to sit down.

This is a fine example of a BIPA, very nice grapefruit/ pine hop aroma, dark brown color, and wonderful hop bitterness balanced by nice sweet rosty dark malt tones. This is one to try if you havent already.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2012 Draft and Bottle. Dark black color with a nice cream head, a bit off white, about two fingers. Nose is big on hops with caramel and roasted malt. The hops dominate, though. Taste is a bit of roast and carmel, maybe a few dark fruit notes, but overall dominated by hops. Love this stuff.

Awesome appearance; dark black body with a thick foamy head. Nice lacing too. Great hoppy aroma and taste, almost like an IPA, but a little fruitier. Kind of creamy on the palate. This is sort of a combination of my two favorite styles; imperial stout and IPA. Excellent beer.
Very dark brown with small tan head. Malt & citrus mix in aroma and taste. Very complex. Lasting burnt caramel in the finish.

22 oz bottle. Dark slightly thick black color with a brown head that laces the glass. Aroma is full of IPA hops along with mild coffee and dark chocolate. The taste masks the high ABV completely but this beer will definitely warm your insides. Its hard to describe just how this beer tastes... Sweet hoppy bitterness at the start and a dry chocolate porter finish. Amazing complex beer that I am very glad to have been able to drink!

Am I dead? Im in heaven right? And I thought I was an Atheist! Stone Brewery trapped Heaven in a bottle! WOW! A floral, hoppy, citrus, charred malt, chocolate-coffee, lightly yeasty, Riesling nose; wait a moment while I change my pants. The flavor begins like a porter with a charred malt intensity but it is accompanied with the hoppy citrus resin of an IPA!!!! An enjoyable lingering coffee-resin finish. OMG!!!! A nice head, didnt last too long, but still nice. Dark brown, nearly black color. The texture is creamy like a stout, WOW!!!  Dont pass this up!! Only cost me 7.99 for a 1 pt. 6 fl. oz. bottle. AMAZING!!! I wouldnt mind a little more bitterness, but still.....   WOW!!!!  THIS IS WHAT WE LIVE FOR; BUY THIS BEER!!!! MY BURPS TASTE LIKE THE SMELL OF JASMINE FLOWERS!!!! Imagine a Sierra Nevada Torpedo crosses with a Great Lakes Edmund Fitzgerald!
This is the perfect beer. Not bear; beer. Ive never gotten a better head, including from my wife. YOU KNOW WHAT IM SAYING?
Tap at the Rake. Stunningly good - lots of roast malt and hops, flavours of liquorice, very bitter yet creamy and rich.

Keg at the Rake, London on 7th September 2010. Black with thin grey head. Richly pungent aroma with oats and herbs. Main kick is bitter, burnt malt and grapefruit notes. Cerial, oat and grass in a finish that turns ever drier. Thick fullmouth texture. Top class.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2016 a dark, dry hopped beer...yummy. fairly unique brew, and even though dry hopped, not overly hopped, especially by Stones standards, as another rater noted. frsh re-releases after the 11th anniversary have gotten even better. the last two times i had this nice freshly hoppy dark brew, its been awesome!"
The encore 2016 seems a little weak in comparison.  Still very good, but not 100th percentile great.

From the Bottle at the White Horse, Parsons Green 06/08/2010 (As Self-Righteous Ex 12th Anniversary)
Big hop aroma. White head. Dark coloured strong in alcohol and hoppy with a hint of dryness in a malt finish.

Come on, is this really an official style now? Whatever. When youre in the mood for an IPA but would rather be seen drinking a dark beer... Fruity-hop-caramel aroma and flavor, subdued roasty notes. Lastingly bitter. Unpleasant resin-caramel-bittersweet aftertaste. Not highly drinkable. Fun to try. Otherwise I dont see it having a regular place in my life.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2015 First Black IPA Ive had so I have nothing to compare it too in the style. Regardless it was pretty tasty.  It took a bit of getting use to it being bitter on two different levels. Serving: Tap

22oz bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours very dark brown with a beige head.  Aroma of hops with a nice smokiness.  Flavor of smoky, roasted malts with an underlying hoppiness.  Average texture and full body.   Definitely a good beer.
Brown to black pour with a creamy brown head.sweet low hop aroma. warming taste big on hops.
An amazing beer if you can find this on tap! huge hops and enough nuttyness to the flavor of the beer that it could be an excellent session beer!! Beware though as this is very bitter

From a bomber into a pint glass.  Pours dark, dark, dark, with a TON of MASSIVE head!  This suckers got staying power!  Aroma of hoppy goodness.  Mouthfeel is awesome, just awesome.  Thick and substantial but not overly so, with just the right amount of carbonation to keep up with this substantial brew.  Taste is very hoppy  and bitter.  A good amount of chocolate malt balances out the hoppyness.  Its the best thing about this beer... the balance beetween the dark malt and the hops.  This is by far the best black IPA Ive had.  Im a fan of the style now.

Pours black, lingering thin head. Great aroma, vegetables, grassy. This is an amazing beer, the hoppiness of an ipa with a creamy stoutlike mouthfeel. Grassy notes, hop resin, very bitter, dry finish, well balanced. Amazingly well crafted, and opens up my mind to a new style.

Yeah...Bomber via Bonster.  Thanks for letting me catch up with the rest with this one...albeit a week later.  You guys were pretty drunk.  Full pour yields a lovely slate black with intense frothy head.  first taste is a very hoppy ale quickly followed by a pleasantly hopped porter.  Punch me in the face, call me a Democrat and  Im not sure that  I would care.
When I saw that they were selling these beers in my area, I made sure I got one of each.  First time I dropped over $100 on beer alone.  This beer was pretty good.

Pours black with creamy tan head.  Aroma of pine hops, strong roasted malts, hint of chocolate and citrus.  I could smell this all day.  Similar taste, great roasted/bitter malt finish.  Somehow the hops are able to shine through and balance this out and maintain the characteristics of a black ipa.  So far this is  the best Ive had for this style.

Finally,a beer from this brewer I actually like. Unusual style but well done.
Aroma is mild hops and slightly bitter sweet chocolate/mocha. Tastes the same Ok lacing but very deep dark like an Impy stout. Not complex but highly quaffable at almost 9%. Easy price too. I think $7 a bomber.

Brickskeller in DC.

Good strong, dark colored American Ale with slightly hoppy finish.  A bit too thick bodied for my tastes but still very good all around.

22 oz bottle from some beer store in Texas (thanks Jason!)  Black pour with a fluffy three finger tan head.  Awesome aroma, mix of sweet & citrusy hops with a very nice malty balance.  Dry, slightly bitter hoppy flavor with a finish that has notes of...chocolate?  Very interesting beer.

Poured nearly black with a very thin off-white head.  Aroma is very hoppy with some light citrus.  Some chocolate malts.  Taste is very smooth with a good amount of hops.  Some slight vanilla and chocolate flavors do a great job of balancing out the bitterness.  Black IPA is a style that should be more popular!

Bomber from Belmont in Dayton, OH.  Poured a very very dark brown, almost black color.  Nice looking ale.  Aroma of bread, nuts, ect.  Very bold taste for an ale.  Extremely smooth beer, taste boarding on that of a porter.  Highly recommended.

[650ml bottle, Utobeer, London] Pours thick black, with a fast dispersing tan head. Aromas of all kinds of things  malt, caramel, alcohol, treacle, liquorice. The taste is dark, rich, and with an alcohol burn at first, which gives way to molasses and liquorice with some fruit  an almost rum-like quality  before more alcohol and brown sugar at the very end. This is something else, really very good indeed [21082010]
Adding notes from last few months, have not been able to comment perfectly on each beer. I blame the beer.  Would try this again.

22oz bottle.  Pours deep brown with a thick light brown head with excellent lacing and huge head retention.  Strong malt aroma with hints of pine and very slight licorice and juniper undertones.  Hops are hard to identify from aroma alone, but clearly a complex beer.  Initial taste had a definite chocolate/brown sugar sweetness, but the hops bite quickly and hard.  This beer doesnt finish quickly.  Flavors continue to develop well after the first swallow, and continue to produce different combinations the deeper you go into the bottle - pumpkin, cherry, plum, cinnamon.  Im very impressed with this beer - its very hard to pin it to a specific style, and its very unique.  Has similarities to Sierra 30, but only slightly.

Let me prefaces by saying... WOW! Very nice beer indeed. Im a big fan of the style. Ans Stone pulls it off like a champ.

OK.. so 

A. Pours out black with a nice light tan head. Nice lacing. Not much light comes through the black. Maybe a bit, with a tad dark brown and ruby highlights... but faint. 

S. Roasted malt, Hops, and a hint of cherry. Very compelling. 

T. Fist comes the roasted malt, followed immediately by fresh hops, then finishing with a black cherry followed by bitterness that sticks for a bit. Very nice. 

M. Medium body, Creamy, Slightly sticky, with a well balanced carbonation. 

D. Quite impressive. Very complex for the style. Almost a contradiction in a way... but in a really good way. Overall ver impressive. Not much to complain about really. Possibly.. well no... on second thought.. nothing really to complain about on my end. I love it. 

Will buy again. Often
This is good stuff. If youre lucky enough to find one, read the bottle; it says it better than I can; dark malty rich IPA hopped ale

Dark brown pour with light beige head. Good lacing on glass. Smells of carmel, raisins, pine, nice earthiness. Taste is strong and smooth and lingers for awhile. Bitterness and alcohol are balanced well. Awesome IPA

Dark brown/black color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of toasted chocolate malt, pine hops, & citrus; Flavor of slight roasted sweet malt, chocolate, caramel, pine hops, and citrus (notably grapefruit); Finish is bitter; Nicely balanced & complex; Overall, excellent IPA - I enjoyed it.

Bottle.  Pours extremely dark garnet, with light barely peeking through, topped by a medium tan head.  Aromas of sweet pine sap and orange rind, milk chocolate, brown sugar and caramel, and a hint of vanilla.  Alcohol-soaked plums become present as this warms.  Flavor is roasty sour cocoa and bitter fresh pine, bitter cocoa and bakers chocolate, grassy hops, with some sweet caramel and vanilla to round things out.  Bitter cocoa and espresso aftertaste.  Bitter, warming, and a touch creamy, with medium carbonation.  Really good; bitter and complex.

Visually this beer could pass for a stout with a nice thick tan head and an almost black coloring.  In the aroma are rich malts, funk, and very nice hops.  Pine and citrus notes.  A delightfully smooth feel.  Flavors are all over the place.  Anise, tart citrus, bread, pine, spice, rich malt, dark chocolate, toast, and I could go on.  "Sublime" is a good word to describe what goes on here.  Its one of those beers that make you say "Thats what Im talking about!"  Perhaps my favorite IPA of all time.

Bottle from summer secret santa, thanks santa! Opens with a nice pop, pours black with red highlights and a thick, light brown head that slowly fades to a ring, leaving plenty of sticky lacing. Aroma mostly dominated by citric hops, but with some grain, some vague coffee and roasted notes, a hint of liquorice, raisins or prunes. The hops add a bit of floral fruitiness to the flavour of it, instead of pure citrus like the nose gave away. Starts off fruity, goes basically straight into the hop juiciness. Definitely some burnt and roasted malts in here, a mixture of burnt espresso like bitterness and hoppy bitterness in the finish. Well balanced with the sweetness of the malts, which doesnt come through as grainy as in the aroma. More pure roasted and burnt malts, but perhaps a baked or toasted bread/cookie sort of thing going on. A bit of alcohol burn when it warms. Ample carbonation, but not agressive, making the body nice and full, with a creamy mouthfeel. Reading my review this far, theres nothing I really pin down as bad or unpleasant apart from the alcohol when it warms. Still, its not really striking me as an outstanding brew. Its complex, melds together well, good balance, good mouthfeel, but still not really striking me as fantastic. I think its because I like more floral, fruity and juicy IPAs, and this black IPA business might not be entirely my thing. Still, its a very good brew.

Pours black but tastes and smells like an IPA. Leaves moderate lacing and has a thick foam head that lasts.  Has a good amount of bitterness but doesnt overpower the malt.  Body isnt too heavy and is quite smooth.
Black color with a thick dark tan head and plenty of lacing.  Coffee and floral nose.  Rich taste with notes or coffee, chocolate, caramel, wood and pine.  Spicy, almost salty finish.

Bottle. Reminds me of a less sweet barley wine. Poured black with a small head. Aroma of citrus, baked malts, with a slight roast. Nice palate, thin, moderate carbonation. With a lot of hop, resinous bitterness. Baked, cookie-like sweetness. A bit of roast, chalk, hop citrus.

22oz bottle.  Pours near-black with fairly thick tan head.  Aroma is not nearly as hoppy as I would have expected, really more sweet; mocha, a bit of alcohol.  Silky smooth in the mouth.  Finishes with a kick of bitterness that doesnt linger.  Quite amazing, really.

a very interesting brew.  Pours deep brown with moderate carbonation.  Aroma is that of an ipa but the hops dont dominate as much as a traditional ipa (also some maltiness and toastiness on the nose).  Taste is quite good (like a chocolate chip cookie being washed down with an ipa.  Quite a good balance in this brew which, in combination with the smooth mouthfee, makes it an enjoyable and easy to drink brew.  Overall I wasnt blown away by it but it was quite good.

Bottle as shown. Pours a very dark amber with a medium creamy light tan head that diminishes quickly leaving sticky lacing along the glass. The aroma is a strong hops with raisin and fruit. Medium mouthfeel with a strong hop bite upfront with rich malt and a nice lingering bitter finish. Alcohol present but not overpowering, a very complex brew from Stone.

1 pt 6 oz bottle. Pours a deep dark brown almost black with a thick chocolate colored head that lingers. Aroma is caramel and chocolate notes with a doughy tinge. Taste is sweet and rich. Palate is full bodied and creamy. Average carbonation and sweet and elegant finish. Lots of chocolate and a hint of coffee. Overall WOW. Very nice. Great look and taste. It is a great ale. Much darker and complex than I would have expected, but then again Stone is good at what they do.
Drank from a silver chalice. Very smooth IPA. The flavor has a nice hop presence that mixes with a bit of a cola flavoring. A little red meat flavor, also.

This was my introduction to the black IPA. Pours black without a head from a 22oz bottle. Aroma: caramel, toast. Taste: medium sweetness. Palate: thicker than an average IPA with what I would estimate to be average carbonation. Very enjoyable, among the best that Ive tried from Stone.
Doesnt get much better.  Dark, complex aroma and taste.  Just the right amount of hops and dark malts.  The name says it all.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2011 This is a load of hops.  Dark amber almost black, with modest head but nice lacing.  Not as oily as other, but plenty of fruits and resins. Fragrance of hops and coffee, the hops start big and get bigger.  This is a really great beer.
Bottles at Grazianos Pizza
UPDATED: AUG 9, 2013 Excellent brew. Recommended by a friend, and he just earned bonus points with me. Pours very dark, and is the perfect hop level for my taste.

Bottle...  Poured black with a khaki head.  Aroma of citrus, baked malts, with a slight roast.  Nice palate, thin, moderate carbonation.   With a lot of hop, resinous bitterness.  Baked, cookie-like sweetness.  A bit of roast, chalk, hop citrus.

Bottled. Thx Rasmus.
Almost b lack with a small, bubbly, beige head.
Loads of grassy hoppiness.
Roasted with chocolate and high bitterness.

(22oz bottle) Opaque black brown body with an initially big tan head that quickly subsides into a small creamy head that leaves nice lacing on the glass. The smell of plums and peaches was strong when I opened the bottle, but not as noticeable in the glass, for some reason. The aroma is a nice roasted chocolate malt. Body is thick and creamy/oily, but simultaneously light on the tongue. The flavor has a strong and smooth bitterness, some fruit, and a milky quality - but not in a bad way. The flavor is not too complex - its simple and delicious.

Bomber poured into Sam Adams glass. Aroma is strong in citrus--grapefruit, lemon, tangerine; also, Granny Smith apples, pine, molasses, brown sugar--freaking awesome. Pours deep, deep ruby red--nearly black, with a thick beige head with long retention that leaves nice creamy decorative lacework. Taste starts out a little sweet, but remains mostly bitter for the rest of the drink. Has strong notes of raisin, burnt toast. Full-bodied with medium carbonation. Compared to the other black IPAs Ive had, this one is far more IPA than porter or stout; all the ones Ive had so far seem to be close to half and half. This one is far more bitter. Not quite as good as say, Deschutes Hop in the Dark, but its a nice brew.
Bottle. Black beer with a brown head. Hoppy aroma, grassy, malty and milky, roasted, some licorice. Hoppy flavor, grassy, some metal. Bitter finish

Poured Dark with a largish head that lasted for awhile. Malt and hops aroma, lots of roastiness here,  taste was a perfect marriage of the two, creamy stoutish taste & hops kick to finish.  Very very good.

Shared by MrPickles - Pours dark with a ruby tint and a nice khaki head. Nose is big and bright citrusy hops, sweet with a decent malt backbone and some tropical frutiness. Taste is really smooth malt, with a blast of dark chocolate. Tons of grassy, bitter hops on the finish linger for awhile and dry everything out. Hmm. Black IPA isnt my favorite style, but Ive had some that are awesome. This one started out great on the nose, but the bittering and finishing hops just arent my cup of tea and dried things out way too much. Decent though.
black with beige head.   citrus/grapefruit hop aroma.   full body and the flavor is strong hops at first and then slightly sweet and chocolaty

Basically one of the best stout/IPA combination Ive ever had.  The pour expresses a big tannish head that stays big for 4-5 sips and then lingers.  There was something about the head of this beer that just brought out its quality.  Picture a mix of their Russian Imperial Stout and Ruination, but better.  Probably in my top two of favorite Stone beers.  These guys definitely know how to work with hops and malts.  The label correlates with the beer.  Just rad.

22 oz. bottle- Pours almost black with brownish red highlights, nice frothy tan head, aroma is citrusy grapefruit, bitter hops and roasted malts. The flavor is hop forward, very bitter yet deep chocolate undertones, full body creamy mouthfeel, the beer lingers around in your mouth for a while after the swallow, especially on the roof of your mouth. This might be one of Stone Brewings best beer, just one I can think of is superior- the masterpiece that is Imperial Russian Stout. Although I have to say the label on this is possibly the coolest looking label Ive seen.

Bomber->tulip: Pours a large, rocky head atop a black body.  Aroma of wheat, floral hops, and molasses.  Mouthfeel is heavy and alcoholic, finishing mildly sweet and astringent.  Mildly sweet, and a pleasant, but heavy beer.  Id consider this to be a cool weather beer, be it in the winter or in a very air conditioned setting.

A flavorful black IPA that is light on the tongue and creamy-rich at the same  time. From a bomber & on tap at Neighborhood San Diego. The pour is 99% solid black, with a Coke-a-Cola mouse of a head and spotty lacing. Friendly aromas of dark caramel, wet hay, and truffles. Theres a toasted sugar sweetness to the taste, but melded with a West Coast style IPA citrus and floral character. The dry  finish lingers, but refreshes at the same time. A wonderful example of the style.
Absolutely incredible. Tons of hops but with a creamy chocolate mix and just a hint of caramel.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2014 Pours black with brown hues around the edges.  Excellent fluffy brown-tan head that persists.  Aroma is straight west coast hops - pine, resin, mild floral.  Flavor is excellent - brief roasted malts, coffee, toffee, followed by that great bitterness.  Both aspects are extremely smooth and meld together like a piece of art.  I could drink this one all day long.  Medium body, great mouth feel.  Extensive hop and malt bitterness on the finish.  Lacing up and down the glass.  About as good as it gets! Re-rate: very good IBA, not quite as balanced as original rate.  Reality rate -0.4

Man, this was like walking into a punch. There is a lot of hop character to this, its bitter in a good way, and the roasty coffee/chocolate just finished me off. Aftertaste was earthy and dirty, which some may enjoy more than I did. Would definitely give this another go. Its not well-suited for a very warm summer night --my mistake.

bottle on numerous occasions and a tap sample or two.  Deep brown hue with a small fizzy beige head.  This beer looks different on tap-the head is a bit bigger.  Nose is hops, dark malts, chocolate and coca but when you mix this all together, it tends to smell like a copper penney that has been held in your hand for a while.  That is what came to me first.  on tap when fresh, its a bit more hop punchy, but not much.  Flavors tend to go towards that copper penny as well, especially in a bottle with a few months of age.  on tap, the beer is a bit more hot-alcohol shows a bit more than in the bottle.  long metallic hop and chocolate finish.  a cool brew that is one of the stone beers i still buy, but with a few changes, this could be a world class IBA.
Has the trademark smell of a good Imperial IPA, looks just like Coke on the pour.  Fantastic toasty chocolate/caramel taste with a hoppy finish, Stone gets it right again, the arrogant bastards!

Pours a pitch-black color with a thick pillowy head which leaves an amazing lace down the glass.

Aroma is first hops followed by a nice coffee and a bit of smoke. Quite nice.

Taste is best described as a smoky coffee IPA. Theres some spices floating around there as well along with some dark fruits. 

Palate is creamy yet crisp, much like a good stout with a bit of a bite to it from the hops.

Overall, this is quite good. I dont know that I could have more than one without it getting cloying. I must admit that I dont think Ive ever had another Black IPA, so I dont know how well Im rating this to the style. But I highly recommend this!
Light aroma, mostly hops. Full of body. Lots of hops upfront with a very sweet and malty finish.

Aroma:Strong grapefruit hops aroma,light chocolate.....
Appearance:Dark,good beige head....
Flavor:Mixed of coffee,grapefruit and chocolate......

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2012 Draught. Shiny black with a thin, fine, tan, milkshake head. Big stone aroma of west coast citrus hops, licorice, pine, menthol. Sweet start in the mouth, with cherry and other fruits, then dark chocolate, then earthy, dirty hops with citrus, pine, licorice, coffee. Complex as hell. Sweetness and bitterness bith big. Raw and dirty finish. Good stuff-rather original.

Bomber from Greens on Ponce.  Was really looking forward to this one, my first black IPA and I had heard good things.  Poured black without any head, good sticky collar though.  Aroma was of big piney hops, citrus fruits, resin and some chocolate malt although the hops were way out front.  Taste is fantastically hoppy throughout.  Simcoe and Amarillo work so well together, this is a perfect example.  Bitterness is fitting and lingers in the finish.  Some roasty flavors were there but not pronounced, this was simply a hoppy, well balanced black ale.  Very good.
Picked up at brewery Dark chocolate notes with smooth taste.  Need to try this for your plreasure

22 oz. bottle.  Poured black with thin head.  Some splotches of lacing.  Piney, floral nose.  Complex flavor with grapefruit and resinous pine up front followed by some hints of chocolate.  Mild bitter finish.  Medium bodied with silky mouthfeel.  Great stuff.

Deep brownish black pour with wispy head leaving nice lacing on the glass.  Complex aromas cover a beautifully floral hop bouquet as well as a deeper more sinister underlying toasted richness.  The flavor runs the entire spectrum beautifully and illustrates both power and balance.  With a pined, citrus flower hops bittering along the sides of the palate with an entrenched malt backbone displaying an almost nutty caramel and berry backbone.  A wide ranging experience which was masterfully balanced.  Excellent

Citrusy / piney hop flavors and bitterness come through nicely and more than balance out the roasted malt backbone.  Tan head is large, long lasting, and knows how to lace a glass.  Im liking this beer.

Dark black with a light tan and foamy head.  Aroma mostly of fresh hops, but the chocolate or roasted malts show up just underneath.  Its those chocolate/dark roasted malts that come through in the taste, giving a coffee and chocolate flavor, which hides some of the hop taste all the way to the finish.  Im becoming a fan of the black IPA.

Pours out dark black-brown with a light colored head.  Aromas are notably hop heavy with an earthy aroma with strong notes of evergreen and lush forest.  Flavors are more malt oriented, working well to create a delicious bitter-sweet balance of citrus/earth and caramel/toast.  One of my favorite Stone creations.
Beer Thoughts: If you could only have beer from on brewery which would you choose? Stone.

Dark coffee pour, black in the glass. Barmy, mocha colored cauliflower foam leaves lace rings in the glass. Divine piney and fruit cocktail hop perfume; some "hopsack" aroma as well. Flavor is malty, caramelly, chocolate-covered coffee beans, those Christmas tree hops again, a little bit oily and smoky. Simcoe for sure, maybe Amarillo? Voluptuous mouthfeel, full and silky. Resiny, burnt grapefruit finish- gotta be Chinook- and lingering "spicy" cigar smoke aftertaste. Holy hell ! This beer grabbed my attention straight out of the bottle and kept me riveted throughout. Amazing.

Fairly interesting beer.  My first black IPA.  Pours black with an almond head.  Aroma is malt with major hops.  Taste is very malty with an aftertaste of a blast of the Stone hop taste and a very interesting malty bitterness.  Nice beer.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2013 22 oz bottle from Jungle Jims, Fairfield, OH.  Pours black with moderate head.  There is a lot going on here.  Aroma is chocolate, floral, piney, hint of grapefruit and some sweetness.  Bitterness up front, resinous, grapefruit and grapefruit peel, chocolate, bit of smoke.  Grapefruit lingers into finish.  Medium full body, carbonation is complementary, coats tongue slightly.  Overall, quite good - the flavors and aromas play nice with each other.  The hops overpower just a hair too much though, to the point that by the end of the glass, their cumulative effect pretty much blocked out most of the chocolate flavors (but definitely buying another).

Poured a deep, dark brown with a foamy half-finger head that left lacing down the glass. Aroma is complex: coffee, charcoal, bitter hops.  Taste is coffee, charcoal and a little bit of orange rind.  Well done!

(22 ounce bomber - shaker glass)  Pours a opaque black color with tan head that dissapates to less than a half finger length.  The smell of this beer knocked me on my ass!  Very hoppy aroma, consists of citrus, resin and floral hops.  But also has notes of chocolate, espresso coffee and even dark fruits such as figs, dates, raisin and licorice.  Taste is of a pleastant heavy bitterness and has a light sweetness.  Soft carbonation, full body and great bitter finish.

Obviously pours black.  Aroma of citrus hops and citrus hops.  Its almost absurd.  Flavor is largely is mostly grassy bittering hops and sweet crystal malts.  While being a bit rather bitter, it balances its character with the malts well and finishes with just a bit of bitter.  Overall an overwhelming solid beer.  Good job, peoples.
grass, citrus, black, frothy, very bitter, medium body, creamy, average carbonation, long finish,

Taster at mondial de la biere Montréal 2010. The color is a dark brown with a thin dark beige head. The aroma is of roasted hops and herbs. The taste also of roasted hops some malt,citrus fruits a bit of a veggy taste. A good long after taste.

Although I have already rated this beer, I did so from memory and basic field notes. So, in the name of fairness and total legitimacy, Ive decided to rate this great beer again with it right in front of me - the only side note being: that this, I assume is a new batch, as I first tasted the beer a year ago, and the place I get it from has only just restocked it, along with the new 2010 Old Guardian Barley Wine. So here goes: What an aroma! This beer has a nose that is just sensational. So much to take in - be in no doubt, this may look like a stout, pouring black with red hues at the edge of the glass, but its big IIPA hops to the fore! Along with highly resinous, earthy smelling hops theres some grapefruit, loads of caramel and toffee, treacle, pepper - almost a note of celery... Theres also a good bit of sweetness in the background reminiscent of candy-floss or boiled sweets. Flavour is pretty darn mental. First up the hops definitely do the talking with loads of resinous flavours, bordering on rubber/leather, then theres is an element of smoke and mineral, a truly roasted, pretty much charcoal bitterness. There are also ark fruit flavours such as bitter plum and blackberry, though without much citric tartness, having said that though, there is still a flavour reminiscent of grapefruit. There are some sweeter notes, once again more candied than anything else, I want to avoid using words like "chocolate" and "coffee" as that would be too easy under the circumstances, as it may look black, but this is no stout. The finish is big BIG bitterness ( you could almost mistake the bitterness for espresso, but its most definitely alpha acids bringing the hit) More charcoal and wet stones/slate in the finish also, with the tiniest hint of fruit. Finish has considerable length, almost like a great mature cheddar. I have to admit, Ive hardly even scratched the surface as far as the complexity of this beer is concerned. But rest assured it has many levels to investigate, and shall reward any experimenter handsomely if you spend the necessary time with it. Truly wicked beer!

Draught at the Burger Bar, LV. A truly massive beer, rightly deserving of its flowing commercial description. Stunning black IPA, so smooth and fresh tasting. Long hoppy finish that lasts and lasts, lingering over the throat. My first experience of draught Stone and what a way to start.....

SAmpled at Mondial:

Deep rich brown with massive tan cap.

Aromas are like an IPA-Stout mutant: Rich Cocoa-coffee roast over grapefruit-pine,,,gets more pungent as it warms.

Rich malt body, silken mouth feel.

Big chewy roasty malts are balanced with citrus peel an resinous pinet hopping, goes wickedly dry in the finish with a touch of anise.

Great big beer.

It looks like a stout, black with an of-white head, but wait, there is more to this than meets the eye. The aroma is imperial ipa all the way mixed with dark coffee. Pine, spruce, and coffee/chocolate smell. The taste is of the aforementioned aromas and very bitter hops, with a stronger taste of dark coffee. The ipa taste dominates the coffee one, but in a way that both are merged to create something truly unique. Stone rules.
Sampled on tap at SIB, pours dark brown / black. Aroma of wood, roasted malt, burnt flavours, caramel and oak. Flavour is much the same. Awesome beer.

Dark, dark pour with a smallish head and some decent lacing.  Smells like a chocolate rain forest.   The foretaste is predominantly sweet chocolate with a biting roastedness finishing with a bitter pinelike hoppiness.  A bit harsh in all regards, the mouthfeel lacking a certain creaminess that could have pushed the whole rating sphere higher.  Certainly worth seeking out.

22oz bottle, dark, nearly black with a tan head and a bit of lacing. The fresh tang of piney hops of an IPA and the dark malt background of a porter give this beer an identity crisis. However, this example is a combination of the best traits of both, Excellent beer.

On tap at Pipers. Dark brown, thin white head with ample lacing. Soapy hop nose, significant orange and grapefruit notes. Flavor has a lot of caramel sweetness and citrus like the nose, neither side really mixing well. Bitter finish, lightly stinging grapefruit, musky earth tones throughout and hints of dog food. Chewy and well carbonated, but overall feels like Jackson Pollock painted on my tongue.

I picked this up while at the Stone World Bistro and consumed with a friend in Portland, OR.  This was consumed while also drinking AleSmith Speedway Stout and Port Older Viscosity...so it was a great beer night but Im up early reviewing this because I cant fall back to sleep...too hungover!  Appearance of this is black with a white creamy head.  Seeing that, my mind told me this would taste more like a stout.  Aroma is very pronounced (but not massive) in hops with a slight malt character, kind of lemony, grapefruit notes, very unique.  Taste is bitter with a great hop / malt balance.  My mind deceived me upon first taste and I was surprised but happy...very good stuff.

22oz bottle pours dark brown with a big tan creamy head that stays well with lots of lace. Aromas of pine slight grapefruit and some chocolate and burnt notes. Flavor is mostly caramel and pine but there are grapefruit notes, much roast, and slight chocolate hints. Interestingly complex and honestly quite delightful in the mouth. Feels full in body but very easy to drink. Another fine brew that is worthy of an anniversary celebration! Stone never disappoints!! Great!

Whoaaaa! This beer IS righteously titled. Normally I dont go too much for hoppy dark beers, but this one is GREAT!! Poured with a smallish tan head and a little lace. Color is a very dark almost black brown. Aroma is very hoppy, roasty, cocoa, malt, toffee, iron. Flavors similar to nose. Hop is not fruity, thank goodness. Great body and carbonation fit the style perfectly. Finish (with good burps!) is like flavor, mostly bitter with a hint of malt sweetness to smooth it out and is of medium length. Session for sure, even though its so rich. Excellent!

I didnt know what this beer style was until I poored it and all I could think was IPA.  Obviously a black IPA due to the color but closing my eyes IPA is driving style.  Beer has an intense hop aroma with a touch of roasted aroma.  Beer poors black with a very pale tan head.   Beer flavor is bitter like an IPA but backing malt character is substituted with a very slight chocolate roasty flavor.  Medium body with a slight drying astringency after swallow.  Overall a very cool beer.  Id definately get another.

This beer is fantastic.  Pours cleanly with a fruitiness on the palate.  As the beer warms the flavors evolve into chocolaty notes over a warm dark malt base.  I can see why the demand for this beer was so high.

on tap at Dieu du Ciel. pours a very dark brown with a tan head that leaves tons of lacing. aroma is loaded with hops, and a bit of bitter dark chocolate. taste is roasted malts, caramel, dark chocolate, and a huge hops finish. body is thick, mouthfeel is creamy. an incredible beer that i wish i was able to get more of on a consistent basis.
Black pour with a medium tan head. Aromas of hops and caramel. Hops up front in the taste with bittersweet cocoa in the background. Very unique and delicious.

Tap at the Austin Flying Saucer. Pretty much black, with a nice medium-sized tan head. The aroma is full of piney hops, accompanied by some nice toasty malt. A nice strong bitter flavor then joins a sizable sweet malty backbone. Another really strong presentation from Stone, and a very drinkable one at that. Hope to be seeing a lot more of this one.

Pours a black color with a nice tan head. A very strong hop scent with some citrus which was surprising from a black beer. The taste is of an IPA and the aftertaste is a sour/sweet grapefruit type of after taste. A full bodied beer that is very good.

Blindfolded at midnight dark pour from bottle.  Nose is burnt rubberbands (yes, you read that right).  Taste is bitter chocolate, pine cones and sugar.  Warm, slightly bitter finish.  Typical strong offering from Stone.  Cheers!!

Exuberant three-finger yellow-beige cap covers the dark blackish brown coat. Aroma is a bit wild with herbal-woody hops and juniper citrus and underpinnings of fruit kola and cocoa. Taste is majestically bitter with countering dark-fruit. mocha solidity, really tasty. Good one Stone!

Serving: Draft at Tuscarora Mill. 
It pours almost black with a creamy, light tan head.  The nose is a mix of herbal hops and roasted malt.  The taste is very Stone and very hop forward.  Notes of herbal and earthy hops, a little mushroom, and earthy greeness, like wet parsley.  A slight off metallic note is there too.  Medium to rich body leading to a long, earthy bitter finish.  Pretty damn good.

Bottle poured into 22oz arrogant bastard glass

pours dark brown almost black with thick tan head.  Head dissipates pretty quickly and leaves interesting lacing.  Smells of piney citrusy hops and roasted coffee.  Taste is citrus and piney hops up front with roasted coffee and bready malt.  Mouthfeel is smooth and slighlty creamy.  Great beer and I am so happy they brought it back.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2010 22 oz bomber shared with Judah! Thanks Judah! Poured a deep dark brown with a tan foamy head. The nose was rich cocoa, big floral hops,  smoke, toffee, and burnt caramel. The taste was very hoppy with caramel and chocolate malt, fig, raisin, smoke lingering, and woody like pine. The mouthfeel was creamy, mildly thick, and decently balanced. A great Black IPA!

Dark creamy brown color with a sticky tan foamy head.  Sweet caramel molasses aroma with notes of malty bread.  Nice inticing flavor of malts, somewhat roasted, breadlike grassy notes. Alcohol is nicely subdued on the back of the palate. Very easygoing and drinkable. Of of the few strong ales that could be called a seesion beer.

Bomber of the newly released year-round version; dark brown pour with foamy tan head to the edges; crisp pineapple and piney hop aromas with a little chocolate roast; bitter chocolate, fruity hops and dirty grass; texture is rich and almost stout-ish to me; creamy hops and chocolate mixed together; a dope brew indeed  

Original Rating 9/15/07 (Score - 3.9): 22 oz. bottle; ah, nice to see the long-awaited black IPA on the shelf at bottleworks the other day; pours dark w/ foamy white white head; roasted aromas are much more porter like than an typical hoppy IPA, as are the flavors; drinks so smooth w/ a slight aftertaste of roasted malts; to me, this brew is a little more on the porter side of things than an IPA; very enjoyable though

Dark mahogany with good, creamy, tan head / Big weedy, grassy nose / Medium body, chewy, sharply hoppy with good malt balance, and long finish / Flavors of chocolate, dark roast barley, weed, and fresh hops / Outstanding.

First beer in the SD tour and what a start.  Deep dark brown/black with thin tan head.  Malty caramel nose but not very strong; that is taken care of in the flavor of burnt malts and coffee which leaves the palate rather cleanly.

Aroma: Very malted aroma but with a nicely balanced hop. Smells of roasted barley, chocolate, caramel, and pine. The ABV on this brew comes through in the scent as well .

Appearance: Thick dark tan head with a nice lacing. Has a very dark, almost black pour with a red tint.

Taste: Tastes woody, smokey, and roasted with a hint of chocolate. It has a nice sharp bitterness as well.  Grapefruit notes present.  

Palate: full body, lively carbonation, oily texture, long bitter finish
(bottle) very dark brown colour with small light tan head; aroma of figs, bit of longan; flavour bit skewed towards bitter with long strong bitter finish; very good with food, not as good on its own

Pours black into the glass with a tan head.  Aroma is a mix of coffee/chocolate malts and sticky icky hops.  Lots of pine and resin with some citrus notes.  Flavor is a great melding of the the sweet and bitter.  Medium bodied.  Great beer.  Interesting combination of the style.

Dark brown to black liquid with a creamy mocha head. I like a dark hoppy beer. Good, strong aroma. A mix of German malt and strong hops.  The hops blend with the german dark malt to produce a spicy, citric flavor that is both intriguing and assertive. The simcoe hops lurk in the mix, and I might prefer a bit more malt and some different hops to mix with the simcoe, but I admit that Im on board the simcoe bandwagon right now. Wonderfully creamy and lush.

Bottle. Tasting at Ekstedt´s place. Thanks to larsniclas. Dark brown colour with a beige head. Hoppy, malty, roasted, caramel, citrus, light spiciness. Bitter finish. Well brewed, but just a bit to bitter for me personally.
bomber.  Pours black with a light-brown head.  Nose is of roast malt, some citrus hops and chocolate.  Taste is of chocolate and roast malt.  Mouthfeel is medium-thin.

Bottle, 2010-06-05, Göteborg, thx to larsniclas
AR: north american hoppyiness, pineapple, IPA-ish
AP: dark
F: smokey, dry, bitter almond, some sweetnees
Bottle (bomber), thanks larsniclas. Dark brown, small beige head. Roasted chocolate aroma with piney and citric hops. Medium bodied, soft carbonation. Dry and very bitter.

Poured a deep black with a dark caramel head. Huge malted and hoppy aromas. This beer has character all up in it. Wow, big hoppy tastes with the same amount of smooth caramel malty flavors.  This has big mouthfeel and a great finish that lingers but doesnt linger past its welcome. Awesome beer.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2013 First ratingBottle, bomber, thanks to larsniclas!On June 5, 2010Very dark red to black color, tan head. Sticky, hoppy, citrus scent. Bitter, hoppy, sweet taste. Soft, smooth mouthfeel, high bitterness.8/3/7/4/15=3.7RerateDraught at Moeder Lambic, Brussels, for Zwanze Day 2011 as well as the Moeder vs Stone beer festival. Sampled on September 17, 2011Clear deep dark red color, close to black color. Lasting fluffy tan to light brown head. Sweet, malty, caramel, citrus, hoppy scent, very fresh. Sweet and caramel taste at first, some fresh hops. Rather fast turns to the bitter side as well as bringing in some roasted notes. Smooth yet to the moussy side mouthfeel. Fairly high bitterness, dry finish.8/4/7/3/14=3.6Rerate12 fl oz bottle at Bishops Arms Örebro on May 25, 2013.Very dark red to black color, big brown head. Hoppy, citrus, roasted scent. Sweet, bitter, hoppy, roasted, citrus taste. Raisin, bitter, hoppy, roasted aftertaste. Medium to fizzy mouthfeel, high bitterness. Noticeable alcohol.7/5/7/2/14=3.5

Draft in Arlington, VA.  Dark brown, almost black with thinnish beige bubbly head.  Aroma is very hoppy and floral with hints of roasted nuts and cherry.   Bittersweet taste with average carbonation and long finish of espresso.

Bottle. Pours a pure black with a beige substantial head. Aroma of hops is prominent, but with some roasted malt in the background. Taste is a great balance between hops and malt. Each is present and fully aware of the other. Hops linger on the tongue after swallowing. Rich beer with a great mouthfeel. Another great beer in the Stone stable.

Poured from 22 oz. bottle into Trappist glass.  I smelled hops as soon as I cracked the top off the bottle, it is very hoppy on the nose with a hint of alcohol in there as well.  The appearance is very nice, black with a tan two-finger head.  It has a great, full mouthfeel.  Overall a great beer from Stone Brewing Co.  4.3

22 oz bottle Premier Gourmet  Buffalo NY. Dark dingy brown in color, thick head with great retention . Big fruity hop aromas that remind of grapefruit, flowers, citrus, with a lighter malt side of toffee and caramel. Flavors are very hop driven. Starts with big floral/citrus hops giving the impressions of grapefruit and flowers, with a light malt backside of caramel but the hops overwhelm. Bitter, a little sweet, oily mouth feel, hop driven. Not for the faint of hops, I personally love hop driven beers so this was great to me. I am a bigger fan of balance though....

650 mL bottle.  Almost black, with a medium beige head.  Smells like an APA, but the first sip reveals a mouthful of smoke, which a second noseful continues to hide.  The smoke fades with familiarity and warmth, revealing the pineapple, chocolate and roast.  Solid body.  An intriguing brew.
Draft. Pours hazy brown. Flavor is big on hops, lots of pine with chocolate. Interesting brew.

Thanks to hudsonphotog for sharing this bottle.

The beer pours black with a cream-colored head. The aroma is piney hops with roasted malt. I also get a touch of citrus. The flavor is pine, chocolate and roasted malt. Medium, creamy mouthfeel and low carbonation.

On tap at the Gingerman Fort Worth.  Black pour with a brown head.  Aroma is fruit, pine hops, citrus, powdered chocolate, and caramel.  Taste is cinnamon, pine, chocolate, roasted, earthy dirt, coffee, and hops.

Reading the ratings it must be me, but this tastes like a DIPA to me.  Pours a black brown color with a caramel colored head.  Looks like an IS but has an aroma of a DIPA, grapefruit and pine.  There is a very subtle roastyness to it, but very distant.  Like I said, tastes like a DIPA.  Sweet up front, then hit with the harsh hopiness.  A resinous brew.  If you look for it, you can taste hints of the roasty malts.  But I have had DIPA that is more malt forward than this brew.  Excellent beer.  Would call this a Black DIPA before I would an American Strong Ale.  You will notice the maltiness kick up as it warms.
Stone has done it again!  Nice aftertaste with strong alcohol/caramel?  How does Stone repeatedly do it so well?

(Old BA rate - tap)
Deep brownish color with a thinner slightly off-white head. Decent retention. Pineapple/citruisy hop bitterness; some darker fruity sweetness; piney hops toward the end. Really nice. As suggested by the aroma, great hop presence, but was by no means overpowering. Hoppiness was tempered by the substantial malt presence. Medium MF, bit of a kick on the palate from the alcohol presence. Pretty solid drinkability given the weight and abv. Pretty pleasant sipper. Overall, a nice brew and definitely enjoyed the hops. Fairly tame next to some of Stones other offerings

pours out a clear brown producing a 2 finger thick head that was mocha coffee colored.  the body is black with no light penetration and the head was thick and frothy and fell at a slow rate.  the aromas are light but i can smell some pine, little hops, some malt, and light alcohol.  it is medium bodied and has a smooth mouthfeel.  the flavors are great and is really "drinkable".  it finishes smooth and has no real potent aftertaste.  very good beer.

Nice inky black but whitish head. Citrus aroma, with imperial ipa flavor - grapefruit, bitters, burnt wood, spice. This has that trademark Stone flavor, very full and bitter, powered by what I think are the Cascade hops. Quite good, but not that much different from Arrogant Bastard.

On-tap at Smokin Joes.

A- Body is a nearly opaque black hue. When held up to the dim light some brown comes through around the edges. Served with a 1/2 finger or so off-white head which fades to a thin collar-traces of lacing are left behind in the glass.

S- An assault of grapefruit and pine come through initially with a much weaker, but still present roasted malt backbone.

T- Like many stone brews the flavor upfront is big. It offers a lot of white grapefruit flavor with a substantial roasted malt backbone. The hops are definitely the highlight of the flavor-but the dark roasted malt backbone isnt hiding. The finish adds a good amount of refreshing pine-as the bitterness builds. The lingering hop bitterness is moderate in strength and does not become cloying- the roasted malt flavors linger for about the same amount of time but are slightly milder.

P- Medium to high tingly carbonation with a medium to heavy weight, full, oily body.

O- In summary-This is a very hoppy black IPA-I wouldnt say its balanced-but the malt is not hiding. And with anything IPA I expect it to be very hoppy. This brew is pretty aggressive and very good overall. ABV is completely hidden by the flavors this brew exceeds my expectations for this hybrid style.

Serving type: bottle
UPDATED: MAY 29, 2010 Poured near-black out of a 22 oz. bottle. Very tasty and slow-drinking. It accompanied me down the rabbit hole during the Lost series finale.

One of the better beers Ive ever tasted.
Poured very dark brown with a creamy white head.
Aroma of hops and molasses.
Very smooth initially with wonderful flavor, followed by a bitter finish.
Excellent.

On tap at Petrol Station.  Pours almost opaque brown with some ruby in there.  Creamy tan head. Aroma is pine and citrus with molasses and roasted malt.  One of the most delicious concoctions Ive tasted.  Its like a porter thats supremely smooth with a huge bitter finish.  I wouldnt consider this one "over the top" except for the overall tasting experience and medley of rich flavors.  Its wonderfully balanced and smooth.  One of my favorites indeed.

Wow Im the 1000th rater of this beer here! Great brew! Bomber, Pours a dark murky color with a nice off white head. Aroma of piney hops and roasted malts. Flavors is very hoppy with notes of pine, slight citrus and roasty malts. Very tasty brew, enjoyable

If I hadnt known better I would have called this a strong stout.- dark brown with a caramel head - very flavorful and complex.  The initial sweetness of a stout is upfront, but it gives way to a roasted, almost burnt flavor fighting with a distinct presence of bitter hops, with  alcohol  backbone hiding in the shadows.  Delicious.

incredible floral and citrus hop aroma with a hint of roasty malts..dark brown color with creamy tan head lacing apparent..complex taste..strong citrus and piney hops upfront,roasted smoky flavor throughout,sort of a chocolate/licorice quality,roasted almost burnt malts, and light spiciness..tingly and creamy and slick mouthfeel..drinkability it almost doesnt let you stop till its all gone a nice one that may become a regular beer for me

The pour was a mahogany brown with some red hues and a two inch puffy tan head.  The aroma is well-hopped but also nicely balance.  There is some good stability in a medium mouthfeel.  The taste is both sugary like molasses and hoppy.  But it is not too bitterly hopped.  It really seemed mild considering it is supposed to be a strong ale.

Let em start by saying Im Irish, and damned proud of it. I gre up with great European beers, even though I never had a tase for lighter beverages, I appreciated them. But Guinness and Warstainer Dunkel were always my drinks of choice. 
Then, one glorious day, I had my first Arrogant Bastard Ale. What was this?, I asked. An american brew with actual character, bitterness, distinction and real FLAVOR. I was hooked. Since that day I have enjoyed Stone products without reserve. Then this, the apex of the art of brewing, the pinnacle of malt perfection. Amazing. From the appearence, resembling Tyra banks in a glass, to the phenomenal bitterness that recalls a fresh, hurtful divorce, to the finale of aftertaste that is remeniscient of the afterglow of a first sexual experience, this f*&^er rocks. I am only sorry that its not readily available on tap. A downer for sure, but I am content, for that moment to indulge in one of the other remakable Stone products while watching the ignorant masses let the yellow runnings of lesser productions wash over their tongues like so much hobo urine over the abandoned city curbs in a derelict metropolis.

Served from bottle into a Spaten mug.  Pours dark dark brown almost black with a one-finger light tan head.  The aroma is mainly of a slight hoppy note.  The flavor on the other-hand is of weak hops with a subtle nutty flavor.  It was medium on the palate with low carbonation.  There was no apparent lacing.  Overall this is a very nice brew as with most Stones.  Definitely worth trying if you have not before...
Draught at Churchkey.  Nearly black, thick tan head, solid lacing.  Aroma of wet cardboard and summer fruits.  Taste is bitter cocoa, alcohol, pepper.  Strange.

Bottle from Kris Wines, London. Dense dark brown pour with a decent sized tan head.  Bags of piney hop in the snout with some tropical fruit notes. Silky smooth mouthfeel, slid down wonderfully well.  Flavour was a superb marriage of roasted malt and resin laden hop. Bitterness totally bob on. Bloody good stuff and definitely one to seek out again.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2010 As it pours, it reminds me a bit of cola.  But as the pour is finished, I hold it up to the light only to see a very small amount of light escaping through this black concotion.  An attractive tan and creamy head forms lasting for the whole glass.  Beautiful lacing is left behind just hanging on the glass.  Thick resinous hops fill the air as the beer is poured.  A wonderful mixture of sweet citrusy tropical fruits like mangoes and nectarines are very easy to notice.  There is a bit of an underlying roasted malt with chocolate character that is really quite terrific.  It has a somewhat viscous and oily mouthfeel to it and yet, its very smooth and creamy, almost silky on the tongue.  Wonderful mouthfeel!  Wow, the hops are just powerful in this!  As the flavors come it, I pick up a small note of the roasted barley balancing out the very bitter hops.  The hops show several different flavors of pine, earth, and some citrusy fruits as well.  The finish is long and bitter.  Very unique, but very good!

Pour is opaque black (cola like) with a dense and sticky khaki head...laced weblike down the inside of the glass...the smell is immediately dominated by grapefruit....tremendously citric...that pretty much dominates the nose...there is a faint subtle roasty sweetness that does come out as it warms, but this just smells like a really sweet DIPA...shock...taste has a lot of that grapefruit and pine hoppiness that starts up front and lingers all the way to the soapy finish...some caramel and molasses and chocolatey sweetness sort of turn on and off throughout...a nicely thick, chewy, and viscous mouthfeel too...overall nice, but just a tad sweet for me.

22 oz bottle, good to see these finally in Alaska. Pours dark mahogany with a thick foamy deep beige head. Aroma of citrus, pine, and floral hop scents. Flavor starts off like an IPA with lots of fruity hop bitterness, then the roasted malt slowly fades in and finishes with a hop/roasty bitterness. Medium body with average carbonation and a dry bitter finish. Excellent Strong ale with IIPA qualities. I remember when this one came out as the 11th anniversary, but I dont remember it being this great. Thanks for making this one a permanent beer Stone.

22oz bomber pours a dark brown and has a fantastic aroma.  Taste is incredible and has a hint of chocolate malt. This almost taste like a stout and I would have a hard time telling the difference. Lays on the palate and just makes you salivate. Of all the Stone brews I have tried this is the tops. So this is why my rating is so up there.

Bottle from Brattleboro Food Coop. Pitch black body with tan head. Nose of caramel, coffee, chocolates and plenty of malts. Nice taste of bitter chocolate and vanilla. Really nice. Very smooth texture and sharp, bitter finish. Hats off.

In 2007 as Stone 11th Anniversary Ale, from a 22oz bottle...

The look is pitch black. Has a large bubbly light brown head. Looks like a stout more than anything. Absolutely opaque. Contains a thick swath of lace as it is emptied.

The smell is of a citrusy IPA, with bitter, woody hops. No stout smell at all. There are magnificently complex hops here (grapefruit, pine, other citrus) with mild dry-English malt thrown in. Its perfect. A real bouquet. Hops are oily and rich. Its a traffic-stopper. Has a hint of dark chocolate.

So it looks like a stout, smells like an IPA. What next?

The taste is major bitter hops, but with a unique burnt coffee malt. Like an India Pale Porter/Stout. Oily bitter hops and dry bitter malt both fight it out. Hops come out strong, and malt takes the later rounds. Rich malt steps up as it warms, with hops as an accent more than anything. It evolves with the temp change.

Thick, smooth, oily feel. Dry roasted malt finish. Its motor oil. Overall its a big, thick, oily, dark, hoppy, nutty, roasted brew. Too big for all night long, but absolutely perfect for one bottles worth.

22oz bomber from Lonestar Beverages in Carrollton, TX.  Pours a clear, dark, cola-colored body topped with a soap bubbly, off-white head that leaves lots of sticky lacing as it recedes.  Aroma is very hoppy--pine, resin, bitter citrus and a hint of caramel on the backside.  Flavor a battle between those piney hops and a good dose of caramel/light toffee/slightly roasted malt sweetness.  Lingering bitter finish lasts until the next sip.   Medium mouthfeel with active, fine carbonation.  Im glad this one has finally come to Texas.

This is beer is fantastic!  It pours a dark ruby red color with an off-white head.  The nose is party hops and party big maltiness.  The body is fairly heavy, but is still smooth and extremely drinkable.  The flavors are richly malty, with some chocolate, toffee, light coffee and caramel, but they are toward the finish of the flavors.  Upfront, I got a ton of hops with pine, grapefruit, orange and resin.  This is definitely one deliciously dangerous beer!

Very intriguing.  Thats how I would describe it.   Self-Righteous poured a very dark, almost black amber with a relatively thick head.  Aroma was sweet with alcohol and citrus notes.  

Taste was complicated.  There was a distinct sweetness that reminded me of a dubbel or trippel, but the hops or dark malt or whatever was in it managed to keep a terrific bitterness that kept it from being too sweet.   Note: nowhere close to as bitter as Arrogant Bastard or any of the Stone IPAs.  Had a light smokey flavor that sticks with you.  Ive given high marks simply because it isnt like anything else Ive run into.
Deep brown in the glass with a thin tan head.  Fruity hop aromas.  Incredibly complex palate with bold bitterness from the hops that leads into a roasted chocolate malt layer.  Great beer.

Bottle.  Pours an opaque dark brown with a thin off-white film of a head that leaves thick lines of lacing.  Aroma is a pleasant dark roast with some piney hop character, rich and fruity.  Quite bitter with a combo of piney hop and dark chocolate malt.  Full creamy mouth feel.  Malt and hops are aggressive but balanced enough to remain pleasant.

This beer has a nice combination of dark malts and serious hops, however the hops are primarily for bitterness, which can be used well, but I prefer to get the flavors of hops. The aroma is very subtle mostly suggesting the bitterness. Overall I like the bitterness, I just wish it were accompanied by more flavor.

Pours a dark mahogany color with a medium to large sized foamy canvas head. Notes of milk chocolate, pine, toasted biscuits, brownie, and roasted malt.  Decent mouthfeel, and lengthy finish. Solid beer.

Poured into a tulip glass from a bottle that says best 6/29/10. They love their hops at Stone and I love them for that. Normally you would expect a beer this dark to be sweet and heavy. But this one comes across like some crazy hybrid of just about everything Stone does well and the result is awesome. Pours fairly thick, like a porter say, and as dark as a stout but with more carbonation. A nice, thick toasted brown head forms. The scent is almost all hops with notes of chocolate and roasted malt. The taste is a beautiful melange of hops, dark chocolate, coffee, and raisins. Not too sweet and not too bitter. The good amount of hop bitterness gives it a lighter body and cleaner finish than an imperial stout, making it a very drinkable strong ale.

This beer pours black with a medium tan head leaving some good lacing down the sides.  The aromas are oak, whiskey, raisin and maybe some vanilla.  The palate is a dry sweetness and quite sticky.  Lots of malt in this thing but it is quite well balanced out by the hops.  This was an awesome beer!  Cheers!

Poured from the bottler into a snifter.  Pour produced a brown-black body, with a quickly diminishing head of tan,no lacing.  Alcohol, coffee, and pine are the dominant notes in the aroma.  A balanced bittersweetness, with some roasted coffee notes, make this a strong flavored ale, though I am not picking up on a complex palate, which would make this a great beer.
Has a nice dark pour and gives off a earthy hoppy aroma from the get go. Has the appearance of a stout/porter but has the character and body of a IPA.

bottle from midway mart denton tx.  poured nearly black with some ruby highlights and a beige head that laced the glass.  aroma was just wonderful with pine, juniper, and cotton.  flavor was pine, citrus, and what seemed to be a tiny little bit of dark roast.  heavy body with low carbonation.  absolutely wonderful and maybe my favorite stone beer.

Pours a deep, dark brown with thick tan head. Aroma is very hoppy, pine, citrus peel, basically dominates this beer, signs of brown sugar, licorice and dark fruit once you get past the hop. Flavor is intense hop, very malty body, strong hop presence of pine and citrus, some sweetness, strong bitter. Mouth feel is heavy body with medium carbonation. Overall, good stuff. Very well made beer.
Extreme smell of hops! Great beer.  Smooth head and smooth finish. The hop flavor is intense in this beer. Floral and citrus through the finish but a bit subdued. Did I mention how hoppy this smells?
This smells and tastes like dry-hopped cough syrup. I like a lot of Stone stuff, but this one didnt do it for me.

22oz bottle, best by June 23, 2010.  Served cool into a Duvel tulip.  Pours very dark brown with a large dense & foamy light brown head.  Maintains a nice cap and leaves a few spots of lacing.  Aroma is an initial smack in the face of citrus and tropical fruit hops, a bit of pine, earth, funk as well, but there is this underlying roasted malt underneath, continue to inhale and the chocolate aspect really begins takes shape.  Not only is the aroma very pleasant, but is quite strong as well.  Flavor follows suit, heaps of hop bitterness, pine and citrus, contrasted with a lot of rich chocolate malt in the middle, some caramel, anise, toffee, alcohol.  Big and bold.  Mouthfeel is rich, creamy, starts out soft on the palate, finishes with a little prickly carbonation.
