Im really digging the contrasting chocolate and big bitter hops coming outta these Black IPAs and this one just might be my favorite.
Draft: Black with a tan head, rich nose of everything under the sun from chocolate and fruit to licorice to hops, flavor is sweet, earthy, citrusy, very complex and delicious. Very impressive beer.

On tap at Collins pub.Pours near black with a beige head and clings. Aromas of brown sugar, yeast, and floral hops. Taste is red fruits, toasted malt, and floral hops with a mild citrus aftertaste, although it lingers for quite some time.

Bomber shared with my brother-in-law. I was pretty excited to have this brew because everything that I have had from Stone has been good. This did not disappoint. Poured a deep brown color with a one finger width tan head and mahogany tints around the edges. I thought I saw a bit of a cascade effect after it was poured also. The aroma consists of dark dried fruit, floral hops, and some sweet notes. The taste had the same characteristics as the aroma with some roasted malt thrown in for good measure. I was surprised with how much hop character I could pick up in this dark brew. It grew even more complex as the beer warmed. On paper, these characteristics may sound a bit weird... but this was a very well balanced brew! Another great product by Stone!

Pours a dark amber that appears black in the glass. The slowly cascading head Is tan and leaves thick rings of lacing.The aroma is very hoppy floral and citrus notes, with rich caramel malt. The flavor is similar, and very tasty. Similar to Arrogant Bastard, but hoppier and a bit toastier. Very good.

from a bomber.  Pours a black body with beige / tan head.  Sweet aroma of hops, resiny, piny, nugget, diesel / purple variety, slight licorice, subtle chocolate / roast.  Mouth feel is very smooth and silky, taste is bitter chocolate overlaid by resin / nugget hops, some fruity tartness present, yes, this is sublime.

black, light tan medium head, lots of lace.  sweet malt and light hops in the nose.  malt backbone nicely offset by the hop bitterness.   medium bodied, nice bitter finish.  nice nice bitter finish.  my palate is destoyed.
Dark, opaque cola-like color with a thin light tan head.  Grapefruit aroma.  Roasted malt flavor along with cocoa and an ample hop bitterness.  Like a dark IIPA.
ouch.  soo good it hurts.  you get nailed with the hops, but comes equally as hard with chocolaty malts.  this brewery never stops amazing me.  oh yeh it can knock you down too.

Not sure why this is shown as an American Strong Ale.  I see this as a  Black IPA - This brew should be poured nice and cold to enjoy the Hoppy goodness - be sure to let the beer warm though and drink slowly as this brew transforms into a wonderful smoky, malty porter type brew with major Hoppy goodness.  Very complex and you do want to experience all levels and dimensions of this craft!

My first thought after tasting this is we have a new blend here.. IPP... India Pale Porter.  Dark with a light brown head, with a sweet aroma that is followed by a surprisingly bitter hopppy flavor.   Im not a big fan of the IPA bitter hoppiness, but if you like it, youll love this.  EDIT - As Ive let this sit and warm to the glass, the bitterness has lessened, and this is pleasingly easy to drink.  Still the hoppy aftertaste, but this is quite a complex beer to enjoy.  For that I give it a couple extra points.

Last beer at the Stone beer dinner with the dessert course and it was a perfect pairing because this beer is basically an alchoholic dessert. Has a decieving aroma that made me think they were serving Ruination. Huge hop aroma....but then you taste it and you get chocolate, raisins and molassas...then hops at the end. Awesome beer!
Dark brown, thick, creamy tan head. Cream soda and hops for the aroma. All deliciousness for the flavor. If this is on tap in front of you, then drink it.

22 oz. bottle into a Duvel tulip
Pours a very dark brown (almost black) with a large off-white head, good retention and lacing.  Nice carbonation. Nose is an IPA - hops, citrus, pine with some roasted malt undercurrent.  Taste surprises.  The pine and bitterness are there, but so is some coffee and chocolate.  Medium body.  The finish is some bitterness but not overwhelming.  There is also some alcohol warmth.  This beer was a nice surprise and I will be seeking it out, when available.

On tap at Tria... Poured a dark chestnut brown with a creamy tan head. Real good lacing. Aroma was intoxicating! Hops are definitely the star but theres a balancing chocolate/roasted malt scent coming through. Hops once again dominate the flavor but you cant help but notice the porter-ish flavors that sneak their way in. Palate felt pretty heavy with a dryness on the finish. Very intriguing and enjoyable!

Hoppy grapefruit on the nose, with notes of chocolate malt.  Stone does it again, keeping you on your toes.  The hoppy bitterness and is completely unexpected in this black beer.  Moderately balanced by chocolate malt, full bodied, with no noticable alcohol, finishes with a bite.  This is a great, but equally dangerous beer.

Bottle split with Pat and Tony.  Body pours a deep, hazy, but fizzy chesnut brown with a large beige head and nice lacing.  Aroma is classic Stone hops; aggressive, complex and delicious. Nose has notes of barley, roasted malts, chocolate, figs, sour apple, and pine. Full bodied with a slightly sticky, syrupy palate. Extremely well balanced and does a great job of masking the alcohol.

Pours a brown with a tan head.  Aroma is hoppy with some malt in it.  My first taste reminded me a lot of Stones IPA.  Second go and it had more malt and hints of tobacco.  A lingering bitterness on the back middle of the tongue.  You can get some hop flavor.  Taste like a cross between an old ale and an IPA.

On tap at Willards Tap House in Largo, FL.  Dark brown color with tan foam to the head, and lasting, curtainy lacing. The aroma was mostly hoppy with a hint of the malt. The flavor was like a porter with a potent hop bitterness which linked up to substantial dryness in the finish.  really, really good stuff!

Bottle. 24.5 oz. Split with James and Tony. Pours a deep, hazy, yet bubbly chesnut brown with a large, tw-finger beige head thats equally as fizzy. Head fades fast, but leaves nice lacing throughout. Aroma is of the distinct Stone hops; aggressive as hell and wonerfully bitter. Nose also has notes of barley, roasted malts, chocolate, figs, sour apple, and pine. Full bodied with a slightly sticky, yet not overpowering palate. Very well balanced, and hides the alcohol extremely well. Another great brew from Stone.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2011 On tap at Brixies in Brookfield, IL. and dispensed with a dark brown hue, light tan foam to the head, and lasting, curtainy lacing. The aroma was very resiny, sweet, and earthy, with hints of molasses and subtle smoke. The flavor added to these some woodiness, warming alcohol, and potent, lingering hop bitterness that linked up to substantial dryness in the finish. An impressive brew!  Additions made after enjoying a snifter full again at Lunar Brewing Co..
UPDATED: AUG 7, 2010 nice brew enjoyed with james and pat. pours a dark body. nice head which lace well. the aroma was sweet with mango. flavor is fruity hops surprisingly.

Bottle courtesy of HogTownHarry. 11th Anniversary version, so Im guessing its 2+ years old. Nice deep ruby-brown with a small tan head. Aroma changes a lot as I make my way through the bomber - sometimes rich and roasty, sometimes sweet with dark dried fruit and brown sugar, sometimes musty and vinous. Flavour is similarly complex and variable - some cocoa and coffee here, some raisins and prunes there, a bit of burnt sugar, some charred oak, more coffee, well-aged hops, woody bitterness, some mild boozy warmth. Beautiful stuff - Id love to try a fresh bottle some day!

This is one of my all-time favorites.  I am a fan of big stouts and big IPAs.  This is a great combo; one big-ass black IPA.  You get the roastiness of a  good stout with a huge hop and malt balance.  I have not found a better beer to compliment a cornfed ribeye

22oz - Brown/black pour with a light brown head.  Strange note on nose, maybe celery, unusual but not distracting.  Palate was roasted notes of bittersweet chocolate, coating the mouth and kicking to a hop finish.  Powerful flavors applied judiciously.

Bomber into pint glass.  Pours a dark brown, almost black with a decently dense dirty tan/off-white head.  The aroma is a bit confusing.  It has a solid hop presence, but the malt/yeast profile just seems a bit muddled and amorphous (i.e. not fitting of any traditional style... making it suitable to be classified in the amorphous category "American Ale").  Dont get me wrong, it smells good, with the hops and all, just a bit confusing on the whole.  The flavor is equally confusing.  Again, the hops shine through nicely, but it also has a very roasty character and an almost acidic overtone.  The alcohol is hidden well.  I may be getting a bit of oxidation here, but it might just be the character of the strange malt bill.  It is medium to full body on the palate with minimal smooth carbonation.  Overall: this is a solid beer, but even after the entire bomber, it still confuses me, which speaks to its uniqueness I guess.  I am also stunned that this was the beer to "wow" all the hard-to-please Danes.

Pours black with a three fingers wide caramel colored head. The head fades rather quickly but still leaves a nice ring around the glass with decent lacing and carbonation. Aroma is of caramel, barley, hops, sweetness, and a tad of alcohol. Taste is of dark sweet malts followed by a slight bitter hops kick and the warmth of alcohol. Very smooth and well crafted brew.

Poured from the bottle a very deep brown color with a dense creamy tan head. Aroma had a strong earthy note from bitter hops leaf, light toasted and and chocolate malt under the heft bitterness (strong chinook). Flavor has a strong bitterness very early; leafy, light citrus, mild toasted malt notes, some chocolate late with a mild caramel hitting last. Body is moderate with a mildly dry flavor from the heavy hops bitterness. Nice lacing from this brew. Overall a very tasty beer with the hops really punching your tongue hard.
Dark brown, thick tan head.  Aroma is big pine hoppy, roasty, chocolate, light citrus.  Taste is roasty, chocolate, then a finish of big spicy, pine hops, moderately bitter.
Very good Self Righteous Ale!!!!! Would recommend this fine Ale to everyone. Great Job!

Bomber. Appearance is a very dark brown/black color with a half inch of milky light brown head. Very sharp, piney hop aroma along with some ruby red grapefruit and tropical fruit fragrances. Taste begins with a potently sweet and tangy grapefruit flavor along with some herbal hops, mango, melon and roasted malt. Mouthfeel is creamy and fruity with lots of big hop flavors throughout. It finishes bitter and boozy with a hoppy aftertaste. Very intriguing mix of tropical fruits, hops and roasted malts. Stone always manages to come up with beers that defy categorization like this one.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2010 Great hop front thats full and a little sweet to the nose.  Basically tastes like an IPA but smooths out and finishes quicker and cleaner.  Maybe this is done by the malt that makes it so dark?  Who knows.  Its good beer but really not that unique to me...just like a strong pale ale

Bomber, pint glass.  Never had this one, didnt know what to expect.  Poured way dark, stout-like opaque blackness with a small tan head.  Aroma was underwhelming, some pine, hops, little caramel.  Ridiculously drinkable for such a dark, heavy beer.  Hoppy as fuck while retaining a sweet, malty balance which is neither too sweet or too malty.  The hops are definitely the star, but not to a one-dimensional degree.  The dudes at Stone can afford to be cocky, cuz they back it up with epic ales.  Im usually not that into super dark, heavy beers, but by giving it a hoppy IPA-edge, it winds up being the best of both worlds.  8.7% ABV?  Yes, please.

Black. Tan head of very fine bubbles lasts the duration and leaves splotches of lacing the whole way through the glass. Nose, at first, is just big American hops w/ a load of pine but w/ a strong underpinning of an acrid burnt coffee nature. It almost works but it doesnt quite. The flavor is actually a bit lighter than I expected and much less bitter. it tends more towards the coffee-like elements of the flavor. Really nice thick but soft mouthfeel though the alcohol is a bit distracting here as its rather hot. Dark fruit notes come out as it warms and the warming also seems to accentuated and soften the coffee in the nose. Finishes quick and clean w/o any lingering sweetness and just a touch of coffee-like bitterness. Interesting beer though, honestly, it kind of seems like something that sounded good on paper and maybe doesnt quite work as well in practice.

Bottle from Whole Foods, poured into snifter. Pours a dark ruby brown color with a finger of tan head. Pine and grapefruit on the aroma. Tasted of lemons, and grapefruit with a caramel backbone. Surprisingly hoppy for a dark beer, which I really liked. Good stuff.
has a nice piney/citrus hop aroma.  creamy body.  Has a dark taste, toffee, maybe some raisins.  with some bitter hops on the aftertaste
Dark reddish-brown  pour with a light brown head. Aroma is citrus hops. Thead is thick. Taste is hoppy, roasted malt, a little spicy. It has a little bitterness at the end. OK lacing on the glass.
On tap.  Wonderfully hoppy, much hoppier than expected, and very welcome!  Dont let the color fool you!

Dark garnet black color with a rich mocha colored foam head. Great lacing. Huge hops nose. Orange and other citrus aromas with a roastyness near the end. Solid hop flavor with a great creamy malt finish. Has the body of a stout and the soul of an IPA...oddly wonderful

Pours black, nearly opaque with just a little brown light getting though.  Tan head.  Aroma is weaker than expected, with floral hops over malt tones.  A punch of roasted malt gets rudely pushed aside by hops.  Strange balance between the malt and hop tones, a balance that Im not too fond of, to be honest.  However, it is nice and lively on the tongue, feels velvety.  Finish is also strange, with the bitterness from the hops and the roasted malt. Not their best effort, I feel.

(22oz bottle). pours almost black with a reddish hue and thick tan head. some bitterness with a light background sweetness. not as thick as one might think by appearances which makes it quite drinkable. Feels a little oily/creamy on the lips. Aroma of some coffee (but not too much), some citrus from the hops

Very excited to find this one local here in Jersey.  Smells heavy into the minerals, like a pine tar covered penny found in dark soil.  The flavor of this is pure big west coast hop smack with an earthy overtone that mutes out much of the classic intensity.  The finish remains pretty heavy on the medicinal sweetness and bitter punch.  Mouthfeel is almost a disservice as it is a bit coating so therefore leaves the taste to linger a bit longer than it should.  To reference other brew, this is very similar to Victory Yakima Twilight and a slightly more aggressive Stone Brewdog Bashah.  This wore out its welcome after only one bomber.  Sorry to a great brewery.  Thank You Stone for your efforts.  2010 22oz.

Stone Brewing, how I love thee, let me count the ways


(The back of each and every Stone beer may tell you absolutely nothing about the beer in question but its a humorous delight to read even so.)


He poured his self-righteous self into my snifter in a gloriously arrogant display of deeply burnt browns tinged by earthen blacks and topped by a flamboyant cappuccino head that shamelessly flaunts itself. Lingering in the spotlight, his head cannot diminish the gloriously dark beauty looming beneath. Polished obsidian, earthen browns, and black licorice delights lend their beauty to his irresistible charms. One would not expect to be greeted by freshly picked hops when gazing upon his dark charms, but one should also know never to expect the expected from Stone. Fresh hop cones bleed between my fingers now sticky with pungent oils. I may live in Florida, but at this very moment I have stepped foot into a lush forest of pine, fir, and evergreen as far as the eye can see. Grapefruit whispers upon a mid-morning breeze faintly damp with dew and carrying upon it golden toast, freshly mowed grass, black licorice, and more gentle esters of grapefruit pith. Taking pause to simply savor the moment, I then move on to tasting the moment. Clean and hoppy, he flows smoothly from pine to burnt toast to black licorice then back to more pine before fading into a grapefruit pithy finish. Whole hop cones abound, their oils and resins enhancing the moment while black sweetness is a velveteen river flowing underneath. My breath exudes toast slightly burnt along the edges, burnt caramel, bark, and whole black cherries. Bitter and yet not bitter, sweet and yet not sweet, the balance is on a level of quaffing divinity I have not supped until now. Each component works together in perfect harmony as if blessed by the heavens herself. I wholly understand now while after once crafting this slice of liquid beervana, Stone Brewing simply could not bring themselves to forever retire the Sublimely Self-Righteous Ale. After all, a little arrogance never hurt anyone.


I am not going to continue espousing greatness upon this beer. Simply take what I have said unto heart, seek out a bottle immediately, maybe two, and sup immediately. Dont rush. Do nothing. Just simply relax, pour, smell, savor, and sup. All will be revealed.

22 oz. bottle (Stone 11th Anny 9/07).  Pours a very dark brown color (garnet highlights when put to light) with a large foamy beige head with good retention.  The aroma is dark malts, dark chocolate, some sweetness, and citrus and pine hops.  The flavor has more dark roasted malts, dark chocolate, the malts provide a mild level of sweetness, and the hops have faded a bit but still provide some citrus and pine.  There is still a moderate amount of bitterness to this especially into the finish.  Medium to medium-full bodied and maybe a bit more dry than when fresh.  This is still a very nice beer.  I liked this fresh and am still enjoying this with age.
22 ounce bomber .A dark pour with a big creamy tan head taste of caramel, roasty, citrus, A big woody bitter finish

black/brown with a nice fluffy head.  lots of citrusy hops in the aroma.  big taste with lots of hop bitterness, some dark malt bitterness, slight cream and coffee taste in the background, finishing pretty bitter. med-full bodied.

Bottle from The Rake.  Bite Hat Moon said Sim.  Black with a beige head.  Some alcohol on aroma.  Some coffee and intense roasted malts.  Very good mouth, very roasty indeed.  Lovely roasted smooth beer.  Nice beer.  Lovely, great balance.  Hops are good, but settled down.  Lovely

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2010 aroma of light roast and citrus hops shining through.  flavor is big sharp citrus amongst the mouthful of dirt arrogant bastard, stone trademark insanely developed malt character.  definite lemon and dirt aroma and flavor, with candied coffee, intense sweetness despite the bitterness.  nearly gritty mouthfeel, big lingering bitterness you have to peel off your tongue.

Pours a dark chocolate almost espresso type color with the coca cola caramel head.. The aroma is very intriguing.. I get the hoppiness but then as someone in an earlier rating pointed out, I get a faint sense of horseradish, a little sting to the nose that nudges the aroma along..  Initial hit to the palate is pure stone.. I mean forget the color, this is not a malt dominated ale, this thing hops like a rabbit wearing springs..  A bitter pine, earthy  hop, with some roasted, toasty flavoring at the end.  the first sip was overpowering and surprising but it settles in nicely as it warms..  The bitterness lingers a little too long for my likeing but I know thats just stone tagging their name.. I almost feel as though my palate has still yet to mature to the level where I can truly appreciate a complex ale such as this.. Ill have to review it another year or so....  another innovative ale from stone, this thing really has no catergory but is definitely enjoyable..

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2014 Pours black with a lasting beige head and some spotty lacing.  Aroma is a seemingly contradictory mix of piney hops and dark roasted malt. Notes of grape and alfalfa come into play as well.  Caramel and coffee notes seep into the aroma as it warms.  Mouth-feel is smooth and silky contrasting the flavor which is aggressive.  Tastes of American hops which begin with pine but become almost like horseradish, mint leaves, toffee and bourbon.  The flavor is also quite woody with lavender and violet notes.  finishes less forcefully than I would have expected but still strong and bitter balanced by traces of the dark malt and vanilla.  This is as very complex and interesting beer.  Not to be drank casually but it is excellent as a challenge to ones analytical powers.

Bottle.  Aroma is all hoppy and in your face, a very nice start.  Poured a nice cola brown with a nice foamy cap.  Flavor isnt really concealing is it, lots of hip hoppy hops, piney, slightly floral and a then a touch of molasses in the malts but then its gone.  Palate is a creamy crispy nice mouthful to it.  Overall, I like this, cant you tell?  Very nice.

on draught @ plan b in Simsbury. I agree with some of the past ratings, that the first taste reminded me of Stones IPA, or at least a mix of arrogant bastard and ipa. great combo whatever it is and the balck color does not mean its is malt heavy, quite the opposite, very hoppy and delicious.
What a fantastic offering from Stone. More a black IPA than just strong ale in my memory. It had everything - hops, malt, alcohol, what more could you want.

Draught in Neighbour in San Diego. Very dark with good beige head. The aroma is hoppy but with an unusual medicinal twist. The palate is smooth and almost oily with a little (but enough) carbonation. The flavour is extraordinary. It starts with a sweet fruitiness (oranges) combined with a string dark malt and then moves to a beautiful hoppy bitter finish. An exceptional beer.

Bottle. Black/deep ruby coloured pour with a large beige head. Roasty, hoppy aroma. Tastes roasty, malty, hoppy, caramel, almost creamy. A heavy brew, almost everything that Stone Brewing produces is worth drinking and this is no exception. A decent drop.

22 oz bottle.  Appearance is dark brown/black shot through with a bit of ruby when you hold it up to the light.. Two finger tan head.  Nice, soft citrus-hop aroma.  Flavor starts out with grapefruit citrus hops, transitions into a malty, smoky, chocolatey flavor, and then finishes with a tingle of alcohol and grapefruit again with a lingering smokiness in the back of the throat.  I wasnt sure what to expect from this beer when I picked up at Greens, but as usual Stone doesnt treat me wrong.  A nice St. Pats day present to myself.

bomber poured into a trappist glass.  very dark beer, almost black with a slight reddish hue when held to the light.  head is pale tan and small.  almost disappears quickly but whats left leaves nice lacing.  aroma is mostly hops, resiny and piney with a hint of sweetness but not exactly vanilla.  taste is very similar.  fruity undertones are almost lost behind all the resiny flavors.  the roasty toasty notes that must be there are hard to notice.  long, bitter finish.  a very good, complex beer but the hops are almost overpowering.

aroma is hops and espresso and flowers -- a bit like jasmine chocolate or something.
pours very dark brown topped with beige foam.
flavor is mostly bitterness in front, but its backed by a chocolate-y malty-ness that makes it more balanced; theres a lot of floral something again, and overall an odd but good combination.
medium-bodied, maybe slightly on the thin side given the bold flavors, with a slick feel and long bitter finish.

22 oz bottle... Deep brown pour with a reddish hue , thick beige head , excellent lacing . Aroma of grapefruit , peach and sweet malt .  Very hoppy , piney , fruity flavor . Rich malt sweetness . Long bitter finish . Medium bodied , soft carbonation , oily mouthfeel . Very well balanced , excellent .
FINALLY was available in my area. Ive been wating to try this one for a long time...and it was definitly worth the anticipation. Perfect beer. Enough said.
Piney nose. Slightly assertive with the hops on the palate, but WTF do I expect from any West Coast breweries these day. I am sick of it. Like sucking on a pine cone.
im not a big strong ale fan. i think i was pretty drunk already when i drank this. it wasnt over the top. i didnt mind drinking it

At a tasting, thanks Shachar,small creamy lasting head, dark brown colour with red streaks, aroma of dark bread, dates, figs and some oxidised notes, flavours of dates, dark demerera sugar, and a hint of resin, long bitter aftertaste. Very good.
Aroma is muted citrus hops and mild roast, black body with a tan head, flavor is grapefruit hops, juicy bitters and some mild chocolatey roast, good stuff

Bottle at a tasting: very powerfull dried fruits upfront, in the aroma and in the flavor as well, prunes, dates, figs, raisins, dried apricot and Carob which gave me a good chilhood flashback, brown sugar, toasted and brunt malt, a bit of cocca as it warms up, very rich, full bodied, good hoppy finish, amazing beer.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2011 At a tasting, pours black with a nice beige head, aroma of pine, lemon, pine needles, great freshness, spicy bitterness, some onion, grapefruit, laking any roasted tones, medium to full bodied.
@ a tasting, thanks Shahar, pours black-red hazy with a nice Moka color head, aroma of marmalade, vanilla and a fruit cake, some dried fruit and cherry liquor notes can be sensed, flavors of chocolate, cereals, coffee and some grapefruit notes, finishes bitter sweet with molasses, medium to full bodied. Another great beer from stones.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2011 Beautiful dark black pour off white head .... with a good amount of lacing .... roasted malt and citrusy/piney hop aroma ... taste of sweet caramel malts roasted malts and strong citrusy hop light pine as well  ..... a bitter citrusy hop finish as well with a medium body and a little oily mouthfeel ... a great beer very well balanced well put together .... had it again aged a couple of months and the malt flavors become a little more prominent more of a caramel flavor

22oz.  Poured very dark with a huge thick head.  Bitter aftertaste with lots of chocolate and hops.  Alcohol was noticable, but who cares right?  i thouhgt the complexity of this beer was great.  great beer from stone.

On tap at Stone Brewing Company-Imperial--Black- off white head, Plenty of carbonation. Rich toasted burnt floral hop front. Burnt bitter dry sweet chocolate resinous hop pine body. Puckering Bitter hop spice bitter black malt end. Rich Hoppy Porterish IPA. Rich crisp & spicy.   Great Beer

A: The pour is black in color with lots of visual carbonation, a fluffy tan head, and excellent lacing.

S: The nose is actually fairly complex for an IPA style beer.  Lots of juicy grapefruit aromas with some roasted malt and a resinous pine quality.

T: The flavor is just as good as the nose. Lots of citrus up front with the roasted malt coming out in the middle.  The piney bitterness makes for a great finish.

M: Lots of body on this one, and while it is strong, the alcohol does not overpower any part of this beer.

D: Im so glad they decided to remake their 11th Anniversary as it is one of my favorite Stone beers.  I pick this one up on a pretty regular basis.

On tap at Rosamunde (Mission) to kick off SF Beer Week 2010.  Stoned again by their masterful craftmanship with yeast, malt, and hops.  This brew is a real treat for self-righteous lovers of American-style strong, dark ale.  The brew packs a full blast of bitterness to cut through the 8.7 ABV. Not for the faint of heart, but the path of extremism leads to the palace of wisdom.

Bottle 22fl.oz.Clear dark red brown color with a large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, beige to light brown head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, chocolate, heavy hoppy, grapefruit, grass. Flavor is heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100112]

$7 / 22oz bomb  Stone rarely lets me down, but Im not so sure about this one.  It is drinkable, dont get me wrong, but I am ambivalent.  Has some really weird flavors I cant quite pin down--cough syrup maybe?  Yeah, not sure what to think.  Its sort of a messed up version of their Arrogant Bastard.  Cant recommend.

Bottle. Black with a huge creamy and lacing light brown head. Roast and citrus aroma. Roasted malts flavours, some milky sweetness (oats?), with citrussy hops as refreshers. Nice (even if the name may be pushing the envelope somewhat).
Sampled at High Street Grill Winter Beer Fest. Just great. From the first pour and floral aroma to the bitter dry finish, this is top of the line goodness from our friends in CA.

Sample at the Rake, Southwark, July 2009. Very dark colour. Seemed just like a big IPA, but dark. At the time I wrote nice but unnecessary, suggesting that the darker elements didnt really bring anything extra to the party. But, since then I have tried a few more dark IPA style beers (even if they are defined as an American Strong) and been very impressed by a couple. So perhaps I didnt really get the concept at the time I tried this one. Or perhaps it really didnt benefit from the darker rendition. Either way, I need to revisit this beer.

22oz/650ml bomber poured into a snifter.

It looks like an imperial stout at first. Opaque dark brown body, with a nice light brown head and some visible carbonation. Good lacing and head retention. 

The aroma brings you an incredible combination of floral, juicy citrus-like hoppiness, with some caramel tones, and a nice rich roastiness, with hints of dark chocolate and espresso.
From the first sip, you might mistake it for a nice, full-flavoured west-coast IPA, with a good hop bite and some juicy grapefruit notes. The finish, however, has both the bitterness and some nice lingering chocolatey and coffee-like notes. There is also some dark fruit undertones, and a little bit of smokiness, too. Simply outstanding and extremely satisfying!

The beer coats the palate, very pleasant in the mouth! For a 8.9% beer, the alcohol is very well-masked!

Just because it is so full-flavoured and intense, the drinkability is unlike that of a session ale. But, mind you, it drinks very smoothly and with little effort.

This is easily the best beer Ive tried in months, and I try quite a few each month! How about a round of applause for Stone?

Stone Brewing Company--Stone Sublimely Self-Righteous Ale--2009 Release--22 oz. Bottle--8.70% ABV--90 IBUs.  (4.25 / 5.0)  IPA--Imperial--Black- off white head.  Opaque dark black color.  Rich toasted burnt floral hop front.  Burnt bitter dry sweet chocolate resinous hop pine body.  Puckering Bitter hop spice bitter black malt end.  Rich Hoppy Porterish IBA.  Rich crisp & spicy.  Overpowering after workout.  Sampled 9/5/2009.  $7.99 Each.

Im always a little intrigued when a friend describes something as a "black IPA," bit usually a little on the disappointed side when I try it.  Both descriptors set an expectation that is a touch contradictory; something that is hoppy-sweet and citrusy while at the same time roasty and malty.  The two tastes are powerful ones, and balance between the two is frequently perceived by me as a touch boring.  And RISs that shout about their hop content dont usually taste hoppy to me - just too much going on to pick up the more nuanced note of bitterness, even if they dumped bushels of high-alpha hops into the mix, my tongue just cant seem to enjoy them for everything else going on.

Wow - that is a long lead in to say that this beer is unique to say that it does this integration very well.  It pulls off the balancing act without being boring; in fact it pulls it off so well it does the opposite - this beer is intriguing.  It is dark and there is a dark-roasty-malt note to it, but it is also lightly sweet and citrus-y with pronounced bitterness.  Both notes are there, but Stone has figured a way to make them play well together.  If anything, the hops are more pronounced than the roast, which is the outcome I wouldve chosen (if given a choice).  Appearance is quite pretty with a black-red body and tall white head.  Aroma is as Ive described flavor, and mouthfeel is like a solid IPA - not slick like a DIPA might be or cloying like a RIS frequently is.

All the way around - this is a heck of a beer, and I need to see if I can find some of it here in C-bus.

I bought my bottle down in KY, at Party Source in Newport.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2010 (br-btl painted-gy/bu-lbl, 220z)

§lct-mhgy, thick-bubbly-tan-head, wavy-lace, med-full-body, med-co2.

aroma: ^sweet-dark-malt ^fresh-citrus-floral-hops crml-malt.

flavor: ^fresh-citrus-floral-hops ^crml-malt §dark-§chclt-malt.

i didnt really get any chrrd or chrcl notes in the malt, but it deffinitely has a dark character to it. Not sessionable, as dark charred malt and hop bitterness can be hard on yhe palate.

Pours a big dark brown with some reddish tints, not a very large head... Big citrus hoppy aroma some roasty notes as well.... Creamy body, hops are pungent but not abrasive... Roastiness is top notch, very excellent flavor of citrus and roast... Medium bodied...
UPDATED: JAN 15, 2010 Pours very dark brown. Berries and gorgeous hops on the complex nose. Complex, slightly smoky taste. Strong hops on the long finish. Excellent!

This is a darn good beer.  Different as well.  Pours a deep, dark brownish, black, the aroma is big time grassy hops.  The flavor is malty in the beginning and finishes with some spice and a load of piney hops.  This brew is extremely flavorful and complex.  A another typical Stone stud.

What a smooth enjoyable black IPA. Kind of a hoppier version of Arrogant Bastard - delightful. I could enjoy this one over and over.  Someone else described the pour as "cola", which is right on the mark. Taste is a nice rich malt blend with great hoppiness. Too bad I cant get this locally. Thanks to Updebrew for this one...

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2010 Indeed some sort of dark IPA, as the divine hoppiness clearly highlights this brew.  Citrusy and piny perfectly aggressive bitterness, distant notes of espresso, lasting aftertaste.  8,7% ABV ? Get out of here!   It seems impossible as it is soooo easy  to drink.  Fellow American friends, take pride: to me, forget belgian, english or german beers, you are now the new leaders of the world concerning the quality of beers.  Vous êtes très impressionnants!   9-4-9-5-18   ADDED:  I think that this brew, for unknown reasons, gave me headaches on the next morning, twice; I funnily felt as this headache was going to happen just as I got the bottle to pour myself a glass, yesterday.  Also, I liked it quite less on this second occasion; did it have something to do with the best before date, 03-10-10, coming up very soon.  I dont know but my rating is going down...

Bottle/22 - Pours a very dark black/brown in color with a tight, creamy tan head that produced some very nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma is hoppy... both citrus and pine, but also very floral too... with some coffee and some chocolate.  Flavor is medium bitter with plenty of hops... more of the pine than the citrus.  Not so much of the coffee, but a hint of chocolate and strong of darkly roasted malts.  Finish is long and bitter with the roasted malts hanging on.  I would tend to classify this as a dark Imperial IPA rather than an American strong ale...  *Really* Good!

22 oz bomber - this beauty pours an almost black with a thin tan head. Aroma is quite citrusy, piney hop with some hints of chocolate and coffee. Flavor is a huge bitter citrusy (grapefruit) hop with piney notes and some floral taste as well.  Finish has plenty of bitterness and some roastiness....  Great brew

20091229  Bomber from State Line.  Oddly never rated the 11th anniversary despite having had a bunch of the stuff.  And then, although I kept an eye out for this one, I just never came across it in any stores.  But here we are, and Im digging it again.  Dark cola brown with small, fading head.  Aroma is full of dank, resinous hops with a dose of grapefruit, teaberry, yellow cake.  Interesting, inviting.  Medium bodied with even, if a bit prickly, carbonation.  Long almost stinging bitterness is spicy, resinous, pithy, and herbal.  The style is getting plenty of airtime these days, but this is for certain one of the first of the dark IPAs I ever had, and probably one of the ones that first nailed it.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2012 Extremely floral aroma.  Deep brown color withi nice tan head.  Floral hop earthiness flavors and finish.

 Notes: 09 GABF and as 11th anniversary ale
Sampled in a 22oz. A very well made strong ale. Good quality alcohol. Pours clear brown with a nice golden hue. Very nice light head on it. Drinks very smooth and well made.
UPDATED: DEC 4, 2010 Black with an off-white head. Huge hoppy aroma of peach and oranges. Fruity and resinous hop flavour - quite sweet and quite bitter. Licorice notes and a slightly roast finish

Dark, dark brown pour with a thick and lasting tan head.  This one has a pretty hoppy nose with some malty sweetness evident.  Full-bodied, lively carbonation, smooth mouthfeel.  Flavor is again, pretty hoppy.  Piney, resinous, citrus towards the end, dark roasted malts, lingering bitterness.

Large bottle. This was released originally as the 11th Anniversary Ale.  Ive also had the pleasure to get a taste of the 13th Anniversary, and based on these two I now do vow to taste every one from here on out. This is an excellent beer. I can best describe it as an imperial IPA disguised as a brown ale. Or maybe a black IPA? Whatever the classification it scores big with me. The hop aroma comes charging out of the bottle as soon as it opens and the hop taste stays throughout along with many other complex flavors. Highly recommended.

The name says a lot from a brewery only slightly less self-righteous than Rogue! Four guys tasting and I am the only one that thought it was drinkable. Reviewing many ratings, I have to guess we had a bad bottle, but its worth it to note that this beer tastes like it will age well, and probably improve over the next 2 years.

First released in January of 2009, with an ABV of 8.7%. But, this is a re-make of the 2007 Stone 11th Anniversary Ale, so it looks like it will be available in limited quantities every year. I am very interested to see how this beer progresses both in the current bottling and future versions.
great great brew, very hoppy flavor. great winter time beer or just great overall!   you must try this

I dont do it often... and Im not proud to say that I do it at all.... but here is another perfect rating.  Maybe at another time I drink again and re-rate but I must say it is amazing.  Pours dark dark amber/brown.  lite brown head.  Great taste of something sweet.  Aroma is arrousing to the nose. NO complaints at all.

Dark with little to no head.  Aroma is of hops but with slight malt nose.  Flavor is primarily hops, pine, citrus but the malt provides a hint of chocolate/roastiness.  Mouthfeel is full on the tongue with minimal carbonation.  Hefty and potent.

750ml: snifter:  pours nearly black with red hue...thin, tan head ring.  Nose reveals loads of malts, dark and dirty! Cooked, roasted, sugary... some bitter coffee tones as well.  The esters hit your tongue immediately, followed by crisp and bitter hops... the body is actually very creamy and coats the mouth.  The bitters are available again in the after taste...lingering under the tongue. Warming the brew reveals dark fruits and sugars... very deep and dark, really a complex yet easily drinkable brew!

Bottle. Pours a black color wit a small tan head. Has a roasted malty hoppy aroma with hints of licorice and chocolate. Has a roasted malty bitter hoppy flavor with some weak hints of licorice and chocoalte. Has a roasted malty hoppy bitter finish with a long bitter aftertaste.

translucent dark brown with ruby light shining through under a big, creamy cap of mocha-colored head.  Aroma smacks of hops, but thats just a hint at the flavor.  The first taste brings a strong hop presence, but theres another big flavor -- smoke.  Other aromas are peach and a bit of booze.

Warms and really opens up, reminds me a lot of Beer Heres "Dark Hops" but with a little more complexity.  Tasty, but its a struggle to get through a bomber alone with such strong flavors.

Appearence a jet black  tar with a smooth creamy head. 75cl bottle. Lovely aroma of malt chocolate; figs, coffee and licorice. Can taste dark chocolate; caamel, black liquerish, a slight note of butterscotch and vanilla. A really lovely complex beer. The alcohol is heart warming. This is simlar to Arrogant Bastard Ale which I also love. if you also enjoy imperial stouts you would love this ale. I wonder how well it travelled.
great ipa, but this ones black. piney, resinous, but with a mellow dark malt base. full-bodied and hoppy at the same time
Sharp hops that taste fresh for how black this beer is. Dark brown and a light roast complex thats dry and smokey. Nice beer, Im llking these black IPAs.
Pours a muddy dark brown color with a small white head. Aroma is big citrus hops sweet malt, some caramel notes. Flavor is very hoppy very malty. Big in a lot ofways but balanced. Nice beer.
UPDATED: MAY 28, 2010 Pours black with a brown head. Great aroma of roasted malt, coffee and hop. Flavor is similar. One of my favorite Stone brews.

Draft at RLRL. Blackest brown, tan carbonation. Huge piney, dank, resinous hops in the nose and flavor. Malt provides just a bit of toastiness, balance, and color. Full/medium body, balanced. Easy to drink for what it is. Solid IIPA.

Another great addition from Stone.  I wouldnt categorize this is an American Strong though.  This brew tends to sway me more towards a dark IPA.  It has all the same characteristics....save the color.  Good looking dark brown with ruby highlights.  Nice sized, sticky two-finger tan head.  The aroma is resinous candied grapefruit and malt...some lingering alcohol sugars.  Medium-to-full size body.  Flavors of an IPA still dominate my inital findings.  Medium bitterness, grapefruit pith, pine sap with a mild florality coupled with  soft brown sugar notes.  Finishes slightly bitter.  Nicely balanced.

This is a deceiving beer because it is dark in color but tastes much more like a Double IPA (which it is.)  The dark malt is overtaken by the hoppiness.  Most of the sweetness of the hops taken away.  A little too bitter (not sure if it is the hop choice or just my expectation.)  Still a good beer and I am glad I gave it a try.

Bottle thanks to richlikebeer. Has a dark brown color to it with a little white head. Has a bit of a hoppy smell to it. Big hop taste also with a little caramel in it. Would be better if it werent so hoppy

Pours a deep, opaque chocolaty brown with a thick, fine-bubbled, light tan head that hangs around for a bit. Aroma is strongly hoppy and has a hint of spice. Fiercely hoppy flavor makes drinking this beer like drinking a pine tree; it is fairly bitter but not ferociously so. Thick and silky smooth texture leaves a nice tingle and a hint of honey sweetness.
bitter at first  but than you cant get enough of this fine nectar  small haed  hoppy aroma  slight bitterness in the after taste
This brew smells potent and aged for sure. It is dark and had plenty of sediment for being aged a year. It has a strong flavor as it should with malts and boozy notes.

Draft at redlight redlight.  Pours black and opaque, full bodied but not excessively for an IPA.  The nose is amazing.  Smells like a beautiful North Western forest: overwhelming pine, earthiness, and hints of a fresh rain fall.  The flavor is smoother than one would expect, at least for a hop head.  Still the hop profile is up front and powerful, but a nice maltiness balances it all perfectly.  Good beer?  Great beer.

1st June 2008. Very dark brown beer. Hoppy like an IPA. The hops are smooth and juicy with very little bitterness. The dark malt is also smooth and provides some balance to all the hops. Creamy malt finish. Lovely.

Bottle thanks to glouglou. Pours black with a big head. Nose is nicely hoppy. Hops are citrusy and piny. Taste is hoppy with a nice roastiness. Finish is piny, woody and roasty at the end. Slightly oily and quite dry. Finish is quite bitter. Really nice beer.

As Stone XI Anniversary Ale.  See thru mahogany with a large airy and frothy monster head that leaves wispy lacing.  Aroma of heavy citrus, caramel, chocolate, grains and alcohol.  Taste of citrus, molasses, toffee, caramel and a touch of pine and alcohol.  Low carbonation and moderate bitterness.  Perhaps a touch cloying and finishes up with an alcohol bite.  Good but not outstanding.

22 oz Bottle -- Pours black with a big tan head.  Lots of fruity and floral notes going on in this beer.  Very interesting aromas of hops, chicory, grapes, and passion fruit.  Great balance of flavors, sweet upfront, bitter and sour in the back.

Dar, nearly black pour with a decent tan head. Huge hops and roasted malt aroma. The flavor is great! Hops and touch of the roasted flavor. The alcohol is well hidden and the finish is smooth and dry.
Another home run by Stone.

22 oz. bottle. Colour... nearly black with a THICK head. Nose... very piney hops and some faint coffee. Palate... quite roasty up front then comes the hop wave! Hay, tea leaf, chickory, light bodied coffee, a little booze in the back palate and a delightfully lingery finish.
Bottle.  Black beer with a roasted and malty aroma.  The flavour is rich and roasted.  Overall a nice deeply roasted beer.

Bouteille de 22 oz. Arômes très intenses de houblon résineux et pamplemousse. Robe noire, très légèrement translucide, belle mousse mocha. En bouche, le malt chocolat et légèrement grillé réussit à percer le mur de houblon résineux et aromatique. Finale moyennement amère et légèrement sucrée. Lalcool transparaît dans larrière-goût. Une belle création.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Dark brown pour with a long lasting beige head. Good carbonation. Aromas of chocolate, quite flowery, hops, malts. Flavours of citrus, summer fruits, burnt malts, raspberry. Quite complex. Finishes very hoppy indeed.

Bottle.  Black with a beige rocky foam.  Aromas are molasses and liquorice with lots of herbal notes and rich black coffee.  Flavours are rich, bitter roast coffee with liquorice.  Some cream with bitter dark chocolate with raisins and dates.  Fruity and dark with an oily palate.  Strong warming alcohol.

Black color.  Aroma is of intense hops, pine, and some coffee in the undertones.  Taste is full of hops with some pine and floral characters in the back end..  Aftertaste leaves a floral hop flavor.  Pretty good.
Very impressed with the balance of malt and hops.  After the initial roasted coffee hits the hops start to come thru as piney and grapefruit.  Would like to age out a couple of years.

(Draught) Poured almost black wtith small tan coloured head. Aroma of hops, pine and malts. Palate was full bodied with medium carbonation. Tasted of malts, roastedness, hops, lightly molasses and hint of liquorice. Aftertaste was malty and bitter.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2011 First sampled at Flying Saucers Second Annual Fall Beer Festival in Austin on October 24, 2009.  Most fortunately, now available on Texas shelves.  First off, this has a really good-looking super-fine, bold head thats very strong and thick and dense and big... when you shake the glass the head wobbles back and forth, in-tact.  A very strong head, and beautiful lacing.  Although it looks dark-brown as it pours, it has a deep, silky black color in the glass.  Black and beautiful.  Ana loves the artwork.  Aroma of expected Stone hoppiness.  The color is misleading (youd think I would have adjusted to the whole idea of black IPAs by now so I wouldnt be so shocked)... at this darkness at first I would have expected some roasted malts in the nose, but its mostly all hops - fresh and green - with an almost hay-like character.  Although dominated by hops, there is a bit of sweetness in the aroma.  In the mouth, it reminds me of a malty (but not roasted) IPA, more on the double IPA end of the spectrum with a caramelly-syrupy malt that teams up with a double IPA hop strength.  What roasted malts that have come through has given it just a hint of roast character, just enough darkness in the flavor so it doesnt take away from the hoppiness.  I think if Stone made a beer that was any more malty, well, it wouldnt seem like a true Stone beer.  When it first enters your mouth theres almost a pungent, peppermint or candy cane-like flavor that carries through.  Its very soft and creeamy in the mouth.  The malts do add just enough to the finish, though, with a roasted bitterness and a fumey-roasted hop experience that comes up the throat and into the nose.  Overall, it has a very unique roasted character to it, probably thanks to the fine selection and quantity of hops teamed up with the specialty malts used in this beer.  Proof that Stone is truly a fine brewer.

Dark in color, almost opaque. Light thick brown head with a nice amount of lace left on the sides of the glass. The first taste was a surprise, it tasted more like a Pale Ale with a small amount of roasted malts. As the beer warmed up the alcohol comes through more and more. It finishes very smooth.

22oz From Total Wine. really black and opaque. a slight shade of dark rubt when held before bright light. Thick foamy head that lasts and laces the glass well. Piney hop aroma, spruce, some peach in there also with a late detection of a nutty roasted malt. Medium body and only slightly oily. Flavor is a good balance of hops and malt, There is nothing really outstanding about this beer but it is a really well made brew.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Bottle. Pours black with small light brown head Aroma is roasty with some coffee and citrus hop notes. Flavor is bitter with roasted notes and a slight alcohol burn on the back of the mouth. Very complex.
Draught/  Poured dark brown with medium head, Aroma of alcohol, chocolate and coffee.  Flavour is coffee, citrus and malt.  Bitter finish with some caramel.  A very complex beer that must be sipped.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Bottle.  Pours a deep, dark brown with a thin off-white head.  Aroma is citrus hops with sweet malts.  Notes of citrus, caramel, grass, and pine stand out.  On the palate it is bitter and a little dry.  The flavor pulls out a roasted malt taste, along with a bit of dark chocolate.  It finishes bitter and dry.  Wow, this was a great beer.  Very complex.  I would consider it to be more of a black IPA.

Pours dark and deep from the 22oz. bottle into a pint glass: Great head retention and minimal carbonation which allows for an outlash of complex flavors to hit the palatte immediately. An intense malt finish hits the back of the mouth and results in a lingering bitterness. Other notable flavors include citrus hops, faint caramel, bitter dry chocolate, dry coffee beans, and a little bit of wood. Drinkability: Ahh-mazin. Rebuy: Again and again. #152 on 18102009, DG.

Bomber.  Pours cola-color with tan head and plenty of fizz running up the sides of the glass.  Aroma is surprisingly sweet of citrus and sugar.  Initial flavor is 100% Stone, deeply bitter and hoppy, then turning to a lighter, sweeter side that re-exhibits some of the citrus from the nose.  Some anise creeps into the palate on subsequent sips, and I do suspect that this will show its complexity even more as it warms. Body is crisp and very effervescent, consistent with the bubbly poor.  Really fine beer!
Awesome beer, hits strong and bitter, but as it warms up becomes very flavorful, still learning the language

This beer pours dark with a substantial head that continues to bubble long after the beer has been poured.  The beer smells surprisingly hoppy for such a dark beer.  There also appears to be some citrus hidden somewhere in the aroma.  This beer tastes like a dark, malty IPA.  It is a bit bitter around the edges of the mouth, but it is still easy to drink.  It has a lot of body without being thick or heavy in the mouth.  This beer has a nice combination of crisp drinkability and body that you dont find in many beers.

Bottle. Deep, dark, ruby red pour. Strong raisin notes. Some hops as well. Light chocolate notes. Very strong, dry hop taste. Slight alcohol notes. Nice balance between the malt and the bitter hops. Very good beer from Stone.

Dark brown pour, like coke, with a tan oily head. Surprised (in a good way) by the aroma, very hoppy, almost like an Imp IPA. Strong pine/resiny hops, grapefruit and some other sweet dried fruit (maybe dates) with a little bit of a roasted malt. The flavor starts out with the strong hops, followed by a very nice roasted chocolate body and then back to the grapefruity hops on the lingering aftertaste. Fantastic beer, wasnt sure what to expect with the limited details on the bottle, but as usual this offering from Stone does not disappoint.
Pours black with a beige head.  Aromas are grapefruit, coffee, and chocolate.  Flavor is complex with some chocolate, roastedness and hop charateristics of grapefruit and pine.

Bottle. Pours a dark dark brownish black color with a foamy, but small beigish head. Nose is grapefruity hops all up in your bidness, tingles the nostril, its wonderful. Palate is firm with a stingy feeling and a velvety film to the finish. Flavors of light chocolate and caramel mix and mash with a steady bitter hop note and there is an epic battle in your mouth. You are the winner.
wow another classic from stone.... went very well with a pastrami sanwich... hit the spot... maybe  of my favorite stone brews

Draft at The Comet in Northside.  Pours almost black with a small creamy tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, fruits, bitter hops, coffee.  Flavor is a lot more of the same, but also some pine, caramel, and citrus fruits.  Very smooth, medium-full bodied, complex, and well-balanced.  This was great and I need to try it again.

Pours solid black with a frothy milky tan head. Aroma is pine, grapefruit, roast chocolate, berry. and dark fruit. Taste is very balanced between wicked bitter hops and floral pineapple hops with a bitter roast coffee finish. Nice body with smooth carbonation.
Tasty brew. Great nose. Wonderful aroma. Cant get too specific cause Im seeing double. Miracle that its getting down at all. Super smooth. No alcohol. Delicious.

Sampled at the Butters Last Supper tasting. Pours a surprising jet black with fair light tan head, like that of a stout. Nose is stupendous pineapple and grapefruit citrus hops. Flavor takes over with a distinct light resiney piney hop bitterness.  Extremely smooth and well hidden abv. with awesome label art. More beers need to be like this one.

Pours a lasting ring of tan head with a dark brown body.  Roasted, toasted malts and grapefruit aroma.  Brown sugar, little soy sauce, bread, grapefruit, even some mange, pineapple and apricot on the flavor.  Bitter, sticky, sweet, fruity, dry finish.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2009 Dark as night, pours like still black water then head explodes into thick almost cream-like head. Aroma of hops, lots of grass. Malt-rich caramel coffee flavors. also grass hop. Beautiful brew.

On tap at rattle n hum.  Intense coffee and deep cocoa flavors.  Some vanilla and macadamia nut as well.   Smooth, crisp and fantastic.   Rich hop tang underneath.   Without a doubt one of the best American strong ales.

Good lord. Black pour with a decent off-white head. Aroma is big and hoppy and backed by dark roasted malts. Flavor is much the same: rich and full-bodied; sweet maltiness and citrusy hop character. Like an IPA gone over to the dark side. Very nice.

Poured a pitch-black color ale with a off-white foamy head. Aroma of bitter hops with some light roasted malt notes. Taste is a mix between some roasted malt with lots of west-coats bitter hops. Body is quite full with some carbonation and alcohol is not noticable. Finishes with undertones of cedar-wood and sweet black coffee-weird. Seems like a black IPA. Interesting take on the style though.
Pours black as a stout but the flavor was a hop bomb.Huge hop flavor with a hoppiy bitter finish

very strong hop nose.  somewhat green and herbaceous.  some pine notes.  color is a deep red black with a fine head of nice tan bubbles.  taste is strong with front hops.  more of the pine presence.  Body is fluid but also very tangy as the hops assault the tongue.  finish is good bitters.  another hop masterpiece.  not for the faint of heart.

It aint bragging if you can back it up and thats what Stone has done.  Would one think it weird if it was called a midnight IPA?  Big aroma of malty chocolate and fruit.  First impression is one of bitter chocolate malt followed by a judicious hop bite.  Very creamy mouth akin to a nice imperial stout.  Another home run by one of my favorite breweries.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2009 Dans Bachelor Party Extended Weekend Rating #8 of 90. 2007 11th anniversary Bottle. Pours pitch black with brown edges. For a black IPA, this smells much more like a stout or porter, but the hops are definitely there. The flavor is excellent hop mixed with dark chocolate and roasted malt. Very delicious from start to finish. Props to Dan for bringing this out. 

(ReRate 10/9/09) SSR Growler from Stone. What an amazing beer. This one made it back on the flight from SD to IND and actually waited patiently in the growler for 19 days before I finally popped the swing top...not to worry, I was amazed at the freshness considering the traveling distance and time passed. Compared to the XI bottle, this had a much stronger fresh hop aroma that dominated the nose. Taste was very fresh as well with an excellent citrus hop flavor. If you close your eyes you swear its an ipa, but if you just look at it without smelling or tasting you would expect at least SOME roasted malt of coffee/chocolate. This is one of the greatest/wierdest beers Ive ever had....HOW did they get it SO dark without it tasting like a dark beer? Now I am curious to revisit the XI bottle (and age an SSR bottle) to see if it just takes time for the dark flavors to come out. After tasting the SSR from tap and all the hops it brought with it, Im not convinced it wasnt my imagination that picked out the dark flavors in the XI bottle I previously rated. Im mezmorized right now.

Pours dark brown color with tan head. Citrus hops and caramel malt aromas. Lots of juicy citrus flavors combined with big caramel maltiness. Medium body with average carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel.

I already knew this was going to be a dark IPA but it sure is black. Smell is initially fruity out of the bottle and reminiscent of the vaunted 10th. Second smell from the glass is chocolate and hops! This one is weird, has a chocolate taste, some hops with fruitiness and roastiness at the end. Good stuff and makes me want to revisit Averys 14th anniversary ale. The mouthfeel is nice and creamy but I am not sure that I could drink more than one bomber. For some reason the chocolate and hop combination makes me think of chocolate mints.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-12-2007 14:54:23

I am not usually a big fan of Stone beers. I usually think they are slightly overrated. This black full bodied dark IPA was amazingly breathtaking. It starts off roasty and finishes like an IPA. Gives a whole new meaning to "dark beer."

2 Liter Growler on tap from Stone Brewery. Dark Brown with a tan head. Aroma of hops and Dark/Smoked Malts. At first taste the bitterness from the hops make you cringe but if you have ever tried other Stone beers they do not hold back when it comes to flavor. After you get over the initial burst of hops you get a good taste of the malts. I feel as of they mixed a smoked porter with a ton of hops and came up with this beautiful mixture. Thank you Stone for making my Weekend.

Stone can call this whatever they want, its a Black IPA and I love it.  Dark pour with aroma of hops and deep roasted malts.   head with nice lacing.  Flavor is of chocolate and wood with the always impressive Stone hop kick.  Awesome beer.

Black with a tan head, aroma is a little fruity and slightly hoppy. Taste is malty and sweet with a little hops in the finish. Not as aggressively hoppy as other Stone beers, but thats mainly because the sweetness is at the forefront. However, the hops do linger on the tongue longer. Overall a very good beer, glad they brought this back.

Bottle. Poured a dark brown with a light brown head. Aroma had a combination of sweet fruits and citrus fruits. The citrus fruits tended to dominate the nose with  some piney notes underneath. The flavor was full of hops which lead to a piney taste with citrus undertones.
the 11th anniversary ale was so good and in demand that they re-released it as this brew

Pint on tap @ Beer Engine.  Dark black pour, medium brown head that diminishes to a ring.  Good lacing.  Smells like citrusy wet dog/hot sauce and tastes about the same but like its been roasted over BBQ wood chips/coals.  So strange but definitely a good one.

badass bomber. Dark ale w/ whitish head. Nose is subtle hops, coffee/choc. Taste is so full; I mean I get a deep malts w/ a crazy in&out smokiness, with a crisp piney hop bitterness, & wrapped up w/ a tongue numbing alcohol linger. This beer is all about you.

Pours brown with a thick khaki head. Aroma is delicious citrusy hops with a nice caramel and roasted malt background. Flavor is more malt with a bitter hop finish. Similar to stones other ASAs but maybe slightly more balanced. A good beer.

I had been staring at this beer in my refrigerator all weekend, then I finally got a chance to open last night and it was well worth the wait. The brewers at the Stone Brewing Company, located in Escondido, CA, pride themselves on being able to consistently produce such fine works of art like this truly self-righteous ale. This beer was first produced in 2007 as their annual anniversary edition release and was such a huge hit they had to make more. When you poor it into the glass the color is black as pitch with nose that similar to most imperial IPAs with notes of grapefruit that dissipate to hints of red fruits. The palate was bitter, but a balanced bitterness that comes from both the hops and malts, with hints of cranberries in the beginning and finishes long and dry. ABV 8.7%.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2011 Black with a small brown head.  Roasted malt and citrusy hops on the aroma.   Powerful hops hit you upon sipping this, then the sweet toffee and bitter chocolate of the malts comes through, with the bitterness of the hops still lingering into the finish.  This beer really sold me on the black IPA idea.
Like a Black IPA. Delicious.  Bottle thanks to either JW77, Daknole, or Ryan.

XI Anniversary bottle from Euclid Liquor shared with JoeTheYounger... Had the bottle side by side with the Sublimely Self Righteous.. Pours pitch black with a creamy tan head..  Aroma was sweet cream, caramel with touch of hops.. Flavor was still slightly hoppy with some sweetness... Medium carbonation.. Like Joe I prefered the older "cougar" version of this beer.

22 0z Stone 11th bottle from Euclid Liquor. Bottle complements of DuffmanSW. He also bought a Sublimely Self Righteous to do a side by side comparison. I like the 11th a little bit more, its a little more complex due to age. Aroma of caramel and sweet cream with some hops still present. Pours dark black color with thin white head. Hops have faded a bit but you can still taste them. The 11th aged like a MILF would. Very complex but you still want to savor every drop.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2010 On tap at the brewery 07-10-09.  Pours a beautiful dark brown with nice tan head.  Great looking beer with a really unique aroma dominated with chocolate and citrus (orange?).  Would have love to tasted this blind as the aromas were a bit confusing to the senses.  Pretty well balanced with a nice bitter chocolate finish.  My notes are also saying that there was a nice woody aroma and touch of dry wood in the taste, though Im not sure how that came about.
This is a review from a Stone XI bottle, so the hops have faded a bit, but surprisingly not too much.  The Stout lover can now sneak an IPA without anyone knowing.

Bottle.initial thoughts were that this was an IPA crosses with a brown ale.Dark and pored with a small head. Some bitterness with hops present plus a taste that resembled a high class stout.How can they get all those styles into one beer?
Notes from Seattle International Beer Festival. A fantastic brew, as expected. Aftertaste like dark chocolate. As dark as a stout. Nice and bitter. One of my new favorite beers.
Well, Stone pretty much has the right idea:  pack as much flavor as possible in there, and the rest is a formality.  Hoppy up front, roasty on the back end... DELICIOUS THROUGH AND THROUGH.

Bottle.  Poured dark brown/black with a finger or brown head.  Awesome hoppy aroma, lots of pine, citrus, hint of tropical fruit.  Suprisingly medium body.  Flavor much like an amped up hopped out IPA with a bit of sweet malt character.  Finish was bitter.  Well done indeed!

Bottle. Black pour with nice brown head. This is more like a IIPA hopbomb than an American Strong Ale. Perhaps the hop explosion will subside as this ages and allow for the the rest of this complex brew to come out.

I loved this beer as the 11th anniversary, and i am so happy to see it again.  Pitch black with a large tan head.  The aroma is thick with hops.  Citrus, pine and bitter coffee invite me to smell and smell.  Much lighter body than expected but still very good.  Awesome flavor...Sharp bitterness, hop flavor, dry dark malt bitterness and a little bit of fruit.  It finished bone dry.  Sharp lingering bitterness, slight roast (robust porter/dry stout), and a wisper of wood.  Excellent brew!!!!!

22oz bomber. Pours black with subtle dark brown highlights and an immense, soft, pocked tan head that leaves a few thin but wide sheets of lace on the glass. The aroma starts with a pungent blast of hops. It smells like Chinook (and I should know because I still have Chinook resin on my fingers from harvesting them from my own plant this afternoon). There are other notes in there, too - perhaps grapefruit (centennial or amarillo?). And there is some alcohol and a touch of dry, dark roasted grain (like a background note of espresso). The flavor starts hoppy and bitter (since bitterness is usually registered at the back of the tongue, this must be some tannic/astringent mouthfeel influencing the flavor). This is some serious stuff. It is very hoppy - tingly pine needles and resin all over the tongue. After a few sips, fruity notes (prunes with chocolate?) appear up front. Instead of being balanced by malt sweetness (or at least a wave of bready, even if dry, malts), it is instead backed by a wave of drying roasty coffee-ish blackness. Intense. Its assault on the palate does not let up. At mid-palate, there are subtle smoky, almost woody, notes along with a very slight chocolatey/caramel malt sweetness. But the sweetness is brief. There is some fruity ester quality deftly tucked in there, but it is subtle. The finish is oh-so-dry with a big wave of roasty intense stoutiness following by surges of insane hop bitterness. This beer is very bitter. The mouthfeel is unbelievably good - velvety, full-body with a luscious loftiness from just the right level of carbonation. There is also a peculiar dryness and light astringency all over - but not enough to detract from the otherwise brilliant texture. Overall, slightly disappointing. Dont get me wrong - it seems like a wonderful beer in most aspects, but overall it is just not balanced enough. Ruination was intensely bitter but provided better balance. With a touch of sweetness somewhere in there, this could have been so much better. It is still a very nice beer, but the more I drink the more I find myself wishing it were a little less astringent - a little less brutal. Perhaps I only feel this way because Im drinking the whole bomber by myself. Had I been just drinking 11ounces, my palate might not be feeling so abused right now...
Pours dark with a nice dark head.  Aroma is of dry hops.  Taste is nice and clean, but not super interesting.  Finish tastes largely of bitter hops.  Pretty good, but not stellar.

Bottle XI pours a dark almost black/brown. Aroma is grapefruity with a hint of raisins. Flavor is nice and malty with a very hard bitter that just continues to grow on you. Carbonation and mouthfeel are smooth and full. Very nice.
Almost black in color, great scent with pine dominating, great bitter taste.....more please...

Had it on tap a couple weeks ago in Boulder at West End Tavern.  At the time, it was described as a stone IPA with roasted dark malts.   It was so much more.   I love ABA and this was somewhere between ABA and their IPA.  Outstanding.    Sorry I cant be more descriptive of all the flavors.

A black beer with little head. When looking at this beer you do not expect it to smell like it does. The nose is wonderful, it is so fruity with pine, which I did not expect for being black. The taste was fruit, citrus, pine, & very bitter with chocolate undertones that comes at the end. This is such a different amazing beer that I hope becomes available where I live.

my 1000th rating!!!

pours a jet black with a large khaki head, and great lacing.

smell is faint at first, dark fruits, hops, and some sour malt in the back.

taste is strong, dry, dark fruits, touch of chocolate, a little caramel, sour malt, lots of hops, a little licorice, a tad bit of citrus, and a woodiness, end is dry and very bitter.

I was so happy that Stone decided to make this a regular brew, as I loved the XIth anniversary beer.  Pours near black with a small tan head.  Aroma is citrusy, piney hop with notes of chocolate and coffee.  Flavor is big huge bitter citrusy hop with nice floral and piney notes as well as a little roastiness and a big bitter finish.  Very good.  The aged actual XIth anniversary bottles are showing even better (they still have some at liquor barn springhurst in Louisville)

500 mL bottle into tulip. Pours a deep brown almost black with a two-finger tan head that has good retention and leaves some spotty lacing. Aroma is very powerful: lots of dark fruits, prunes, molasses, dark chocolate, strawberries, and big grapefruit hops that makes for an odd combination like a Belgian Strong Ale and IPA combined. Taste is just that: refreshing grapefruit hops are most prominent but as this warms it becomes more about dates, prunes and then moves to coffee, dark chocolate, cocoa, and some smokiness. I really havent tried a black IPA before, this is the closest to it and I find it fascinating.

A very dark pour, almost a dark ipa in its own way. The smell has strong notes of green vegetables like bruseel sprouts. The simco hops are prevalent in both the smell and the initial taste, however they are very well balanced so as not to be too bitter on the palate. This is an excellent hoppy beer. Another stone classic.

Sweet Jesus, this is a good beer.  On tap into a tulip glass.  Pours black with a thick tan head with excellent retention and lacing.  Absolutely beautiful beer.  Aroma is lots of pine and citrus hops.  Flavor is very hop-forward, but mellows into nice caramel sweetness.  Full, thick, viscous mouthfeel.  Basically, this beer has the look and mouthfeel of a very nice stout with the aroma and flavor of a good DIPA.  Whats not to love?

Poured from Bottle into Tulip glass.

Pours jet black with a booming, fluffy light-tan head that never fully dissolves and creates a dense layer atop the glass. The aroma is filled with sticky, resinous hops and has some hints, although very subtle, of chocolate. Flavor is piney hops and sweet malt upfront and is accompanied by some touches of roasted malt and dried fruit. Its a medium bodied beer that is sticky and has a good amount of carbonation. Out of all the "Black" IPAs that Ive tried this one certainly sets the bar. I had no idea what this beer looked like before I poured it into my glass and was surprised it was as black as it was. The aroma is purely delicious.
On Tap at City Beer:  Pours black with white head.  Nose is pine, hops, and chocolate.  Palate is just right, extremely easy drinking.  Hoppy makes me happy and this one made me happy.  Recommended.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2009 On tap at Stone Bistro.  Appears dark brown with a cream-colored head  just a shade lighter than your average stout.  Aroma is brightly floral with a hint of black-ashy malt.  Lemonade and bubblegum come to mind in the nose.  The palate is medium-light, allowing this ale to swish easily over ones tongue.  Self-Righteous starts with a blend of floral hops and crème brulee (a toasted/caramel blend of flavors).  The finish is indeed quite bitter and clean-tasting, with some late smoke.  Overall, this is a pretty interesting concoction, much like Southern Tiers Iniquity but better.  It is a fantastic drinking experience for its ability to shock you with the juxtaposition of black coloration and floral, IPA like body.  Reminded me of a black Arrogant Bastard with a bit more smoke!
update on Stone 11th Anniversary Ale 11/1/09 notes: bomber.  Pours brown with heavy lacing and a beige head.  Aroma is dried strawberries, pine, and milk chocolate.  Palate is medium, very lightly carbonated.  Flavor is a interesting blend, very hard to put a finger on.  Piney hops, semisweet dark chocolate, honeydew, dark malt, bubble gum sweetness.  Well, Im not sure if my rating of this beer should affect its near-finalized score; it is clearly a hoppy beer that has been matured to its detriment.  And I knew that coming in, but it was worth a try.  At this point, Sublimely Self Righteous is a way more satisfying black IPA. 3.4.

Great aroma with that slight bit of malt in there. Nice strong IIPA hoppiness in the flavor. Has got  slight more bitter finish than I would prefer, but a great all round beer. Would get more if I could find them.

So happy they made the 11th stick around!  Pours a dark black with about an inch of head fading away slowly but leaving some nice lacing on the glass with the first few sips.  Medium bodied beer.  On the aroma I am getting hops, some of that west coast citrus, get those dark roasted malts hiding in there a bit as well.  I like what they were going for here and the other black IPAs or beers that are calling themselves this pale in comparison to me.  Stone has set the benchmark here.

22oz bottle, pours a black with a large tan head, so much lacing! Aroma is mild bitter chocolate and some pine hop. Flavor is initial bitter, a tinge of sweetness. Bitter dark chocolate, coffee, pine hops.

Pours a dark black with a thick brown head, tons of lacing, small amount of carbonation. Lots of grapefruit and bitter dark chocolate in the aroma. The taste is very bitter, overwhelming at first, theres also a really nice sweetness to it. This beer continues to get better and better as I drink it. By the 5 or 6th sip you cant taste the alcohol anymore and the bitterness has become really nice. This beer is super hoppy. Wow what a great surprise. Like a triple IPA with a little bit of chocolate and a slight sweetness to it. Amazing!

22 oz.  Anniversary ale bottle.  Dark brown/black pour.  Frothy tan head.  A little musty smelling, with piney hop and some roast and burnt malt.  Taste has plenty of roasted malt, some dark chocolate.  Very clean finishing with biter coffee, bakers chocolate, pretty dry.  Medium bodied with good carbonation.  I think 1 year of age would have been about perfect, this was just a little over.  The 2 years really mellowed the hops, which was good for me.  Good balance of malt, roast and hops.  A real nice drinker, with only slightly high abv, which is not noticeable at all anyways.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: The aroma is roasty, and hoppy, and a dank basement aroma (wierd).  Some unsweetned chocolate in there too.  The aroma is crazy, and very enticing.  The appearance makes it resemble a stout, deep brown/black, tan head.  The flavor is roasty, chocolatey, piney hops (the only thing that separates this from a stout in flavor).   The mouthfeel is thick, syrupy, with noticable carbonation - nice.  The finish is where the piney hops dominate, and linger for a while.  Nicely crafted brew, very enjoyable.  Its hard to put a label on this guy.  To me, I think its a variation of a stout blasted with hops.  Complex and interesting in both aroma and flavor.

Athens, Ga. - Five Points Bottle Shop - 22 oz bomber. Pours an almost tar black with a tight khaki colored head that sticks around a while. Fresh "cat urine" like hop aroma (in a good way) with loads of sprucey goodness that sits just right. Flavor is hoppy indeed with some nice licorice hints to sit alongside the usual grapefruity hoppiness. Hints of chocolate come through in the back end. Sticky, rich mouthfeel. Have yet to tire of Stones products.

Another nice beer from Stone.  Pours a dark brown color with a huge head.  I wasnt sure to make of it at first, but one whiff had me sold.  It had a strong hoppy aroma.  Not seeing the bottle prior to the pour, I was thinking this was some sort of stout.  Not so!  Nice fruity/citrusy aroma with a taste that matches.  Very crisp, light, and smooth.  Try this one!

Source:22 oz bottle from Chucks in Bowling Green. 
Glass:Tripel Karmeliet tulip. 
Appearance:Dark brown pour with a one finger brown head.  
Aroma:Hint of roast, citrus and floral hops. 
Flavor:Roasty base with a strong citrus finish. 
Palate:Medium body with solid carbonation.
Overall:I absolutely love this beer.  Doesnt get any berrer.

(on tap at Trinity in Colorado Springs). Pours a very dark brown color. Small tan head. Strong hop aroma. Strong hop flavor with light alcohol, and very light malt. Avg duration. Light bitterness. Slick texture. Good lacing. Heavy carbonation.
bottle, dark almost black brown with tall tan foam, aroma has a hoppy , chocolate presence, flavors of malty cocoa, hoppy lime, grapefruit peel, medium bodied finish

Thanks to mar for the bottle.

This beer has a mild head that fades immediately, probably due to its age. Bottles as Stone 11th this one came out September 2007, drank 6/24/09.

Nose is of brown sugar, caramel, light hops. The tastes is toasted brown sugar, with a great carbonation that dances on the tongue. The body is absolutely perfect, and the lingering flavor on the palette is astoundingly delicious. Color is dark brown but clear, nice lacing on the glass.

Overall this beer has superb balance, is extremely complex in both nose and taste and I love it.
